('81', 0, 3, 6, 189) You may circulate it.

('81', 0, 5, 9, 288) 2. LETTER TO AMRIT KAUR
('81', 0, 6, 10, 312) August 18, 1941
('81', 0, 7, 11, 328) MY DEAR IDIOT, This thing about the post is vexing.
('81', 0, 7, 12, 380) But what is one to do with a village P[ost] O[ffice]?
('81', 0, 7, 13, 434) The second vexing thing is your indifferent condition.
('81', 0, 7, 14, 489) Why should you not feel first class?
('81', 0, 7, 15, 526) Could it have anything to do with your having taxed yourself too much over Jamnalal?
('81', 0, 7, 16, 611) He is in rapturesover the kindness shown to him by you all— meaning you and your.
('81', 0, 7, 17, 693) 1 The thought has just occurred to me and I have passed it on to you.
('81', 0, 7, 18, 763) Anyway it is time you got well.
('81', 0, 7, 19, 795) We had a glorious day here.
('81', 0, 7, 20, 823) We had prayers at which Gurudev’s songs were sung, the morning “Jivana jakhan 2” by Sushila and the “ Anand lok[e] 3” in the evening by Prabhakar who is proving a fine singer.
('81', 0, 7, 21, 999) We had a pice collection from every adult and more from those who could pay more.
('81', 0, 7, 22, 1081) The Ashramites not having any money of their own spun for one hour and got one pice for their labour at market price.
('81', 0, 7, 23, 1199) Maganlal gave Rs. 2,500, Janakibehn Rs. 110, Sushila Rs. 500 in 10 instalments, i.e., Rs. 50 out of her salary.
('81', 0, 7, 24, 1311) Therefore, we have a goodly sum in Sevagram.
('81', 0, 7, 25, 1356) Ashadevi went out for collection and prayer in Wardha.
('81', 0, 7, 26, 1411) I have not yet had the report.
('81', 0, 7, 27, 1442) But it was good there too.
('81', 0, 7, 28, 1469) Vallabhbhai’s condition is bad.
('81', 0, 7, 29, 1501) You must have seen the report.
('81', 0, 7, 30, 1532) Let us see what happens.
('81', 0, 7, 31, 1557) It is a big load on the mind.
('81', 0, 7, 32, 1587) Mridula leaves today for Bombay.
('81', 0, 7, 33, 1620) She has come to solve her little difficulties.
('81', 0, 8, 34, 1667) 1 Omission as in the source 2 These words are in the Devanagari script.

('81', 1, 3, 6, 1923) 3. LETTER TO SUSHILA NAYYAR
('81', 1, 4, 7, 1951) August 18, 1941
('81', 1, 5, 8, 1967) SUSHILA, You were to leave one of your pens here.
('81', 1, 5, 9, 2017) I do not find it here.
('81', 1, 5, 10, 2040) If it is with you, it is all right.
('81', 1, 5, 11, 2076) I do not want a new pen.
('81', 1, 5, 12, 2101) There is a postcard from Nagpur today addressed to you.
('81', 1, 5, 13, 2157) It is a reply to your letter : ‘‘The prisoner is not legally allowed to meet anyone.
('81', 1, 5, 14, 2242) And he does not wish to meet anyone in particular.’’ So even if the telephone had been answered, you would have got the same reply.
('81', 1, 5, 15, 2374) I hope you did not have much trouble and could catch the train easily.
('81', 1, 5, 16, 2445) If you remember, write to me how many minutes before time you reached.
('81', 1, 5, 17, 2516) Do not fix appointments anywhere.
('81', 1, 5, 18, 2550) I do not wish to place any burden on you.
('81', 1, 5, 19, 2592) It would hurt me taking even a moment from your studies.

('81', 2, 2, 3, 3249) SEVAGRAM, via WARDHA, August 19, 1941
('81', 2, 3, 4, 3287) AMRIT, Your note.
('81', 2, 3, 5, 3305) How strange my letter crossed yours.
('81', 2, 3, 6, 3342) You have used the same or a synonymous term.
('81', 2, 3, 7, 3387) You must get rid of your illnesses now.
('81', 2, 3, 8, 3427) If Shummy and others relieve you and think that you might flourish under humble surroundings I shall gladly nurse you to health.
('81', 2, 3, 9, 3556) If I am solely responsible, I shall not be nervous.
('81', 2, 3, 10, 3608) No more today.
('81', 2, 4, 11, 3623) From the original: C.W 4057. Courtesy: Amrit Kaur.

('81', 2, 5, 13, 3689) 6. LETTER TO TARACHAND
('81', 2, 6, 14, 3712) August 19, 1941
('81', 2, 7, 15, 3728) DEAR DR.
('81', 2, 7, 16, 3737) TARACHAND, Many thanks for your cheque which I am passing to the Deenabandhu Memorial Fund.
('81', 2, 7, 17, 3829) If you do not like the disposal I can easily alter it.
('81', 2, 7, 18, 3884) I have purposely not moved in the Hindi matter because of the extraordinary riots in Dacca and elsewhere.
('81', 2, 7, 19, 3990) The matter has to be settled but the values have changed.
('81', 2, 7, 20, 4048) As I read the signs of the times the matter does not admit of piecemeal treatment.
('81', 2, 7, 21, 4131) I drafted my statement.
('81', 2, 7, 22, 4155) Sunderlalji did not like it much.
('81', 2, 7, 23, 4189) Meanwhile the disturbances affected me deeply and I stayed immediate action, my views remaining the same.
('81', 2, 8, 24, 4295) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI
('81', 2, 9, 25, 4325) From a copy: Pyarelal Papers, Courtesy; Pyarelal

('81', 3, 1, 2, 4414) 7. LETTER TO INDRAVADAN N. DIVYENDRA
('81', 3, 2, 3, 4451) August 19, 1941
('81', 3, 3, 4, 4467) BHAI INDRAVADAN, Searching for the envelope sent by you would take some time, and, moreover, you have no reason to complain since you are getting one pice worth more than what you spent.
('81', 3, 3, 5, 4654) If we exclusively look after the cow, the buffalo will not perish, but if we exclusively look after the latter both the cow and the buffalo will perish.
('81', 3, 3, 6, 4807) If we try to look after both, then also both would perish.
('81', 3, 3, 7, 4866) All the world over people use mostly cow’s milk.
('81', 3, 3, 8, 4915) From the medical point of view, too, cow’s milk is more beneficial.
('81', 3, 4, 9, 4983) Vandemataram from M. K. GANDHI BHAI INDRAVADAN N. DIVYENDRA GOODS OFFICE SABARMATI, B.B. & C. I. RLY.
('81', 3, 5, 10, 5085) From a photostat of the Gujarati: G.N. 121

('81', 4, 5, 7, 6008) 10. LETTER TO DEVDAS GANDHI
('81', 4, 6, 8, 6036) SEVAGRAM, via WARDHA, August 20, 1941
('81', 4, 7, 9, 6074) DEVDAS, I read your letter addressed to Mahadev.
('81', 4, 7, 10, 6123) He has been held up in Bombay.
('81', 4, 7, 11, 6154) I think you should not have published a report like that without verifying it.
('81', 4, 7, 12, 6233) And even if you published it, to have made unfounded comments on it was certainly wrong.
('81', 4, 7, 13, 6322) [I] 1 cannot save you.
('81', 4, 7, 14, 6345) And, moreover, you have given the name of the Chief Justice.
('81', 4, 7, 15, 6406) I am afraid you will be found guilty.
('81', 4, 7, 16, 6444) You had better consult a lawyer and publish, before attending the court, an apology saying that your correspondent was unable to prove the truth of his report.
('81', 4, 7, 17, 6604) I think this would be a graceful step.
('81', 4, 7, 18, 6643) Or you may apologize in the court without defending yourself.
('81', 4, 7, 19, 6705) I am suggesting this from the moral and legal point of view.
('81', 4, 7, 20, 6766) But ultimately do as Sir Tej Bahadur and Munshi advise.
('81', 4, 7, 21, 6822) I am sending a copy of this letter, together with your letter, to Mahadev.
('81', 4, 7, 22, 6897) You have signed in full, but I can decipher neither “Devdas” nor “Gandhi”.
('81', 4, 7, 23, 6972) The civilized rule is that the letters even in a signature should be as neat as pearls.
('81', 4, 8, 24, 7060) Blessings from BAPU
('81', 4, 9, 25, 7080) From a photostat of the Gujarati: G.N. 2142
('81', 4, 10, 26, 7124) 1 One word is illegible in the source.

('81', 12, 8, 19, 17600) 27. FOREWORD TO “ A DISCIPLINE FOR NON VIOLENCE” 1
('81', 12, 9, 20, 17651) SEVAGRAM, August 24, 1941 A Discipline for Non violence is a pamphlet written by Mr. Richard B. Gregg for the guidance of those Westerners who endeavour to follow the law of satyagraha.
('81', 12, 9, 21, 17837) I use the word advisedly instead of ‘pacifism’.
('81', 12, 9, 22, 17885) For what passes under the name of pacifism is not the same as satyagraha.
('81', 12, 9, 23, 17959) Mr. Gregg is a most diligent and methodical worker.
('81', 12, 9, 24, 18011) He [has] had first hand knowledge of satyagraha, having lived in India and that too for nearly a year in the Sabarmati Ashram.
('81', 12, 9, 25, 18138) His pamphlet is
('81', 12, 10, 26, 18154) 1 To its first Indian edition published by Navajivan Publishing House, Ahmedabad
('81', 13, 0, 1, 18235) 14 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('81', 13, 1, 2, 18276) seasonable and cannot fail to help the satyagrahis of India.
('81', 13, 1, 3, 18337) For though the pamphlet is written in a manner attractive for the West, the substance is the same for both the Western and the Eastern satyagrahi.
('81', 13, 1, 4, 18484) A cheap edition of the pamphlet is therefore being printed locally for the benefit of Indian readers in the hope that many will make use of it and profit by it.
('81', 13, 1, 5, 18645) A special responsibility rests upon the shoulders of Indian satyagrahis, for Mr. Gregg has based the pamphlet on his observation of the working of satyagraha in India.
('81', 13, 1, 6, 18813) However admirable this guide of Mr. Gregg’smay appear as a well arranged code, it must fail in its purpose if the Indian experiment fails.
('81', 13, 1, 7, 18952) M. K. GANDHI
('81', 13, 2, 8, 18965) A Discipline for Non violence
('81', 13, 3, 9, 18995) 28. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('81', 13, 4, 10, 19022) WARDRA, August 24, 1941 Being vitally connected with immigration problems and having been in South Africa for twenty years, I am naturally interested in the Indo Burma Immigration Agreement.
('81', 13, 4, 11, 19213) It has caused me deep pain.
('81', 13, 4, 12, 19241) I have collected as much literature as I could on the subject.
('81', 13, 4, 13, 19304) I have studied as much of it as was necessary to enable me to form anopinion and as was possible during the very limited time at my disposal.
('81', 13, 4, 14, 19446) My study has led me to the conclusion that it is an unhappy agreement.
('81', 13, 4, 15, 19517) It is panicky and penal.
('81', 13, 4, 16, 19542) In the papers I find no reason to warrant any panic nor do I find any warrant for the severe punishment meted out to the Indians resident in Burma.
('81', 13, 4, 17, 19690) The burden of proving the right to remain in Burma has in every case been thrown on the Indian resident.
('81', 13, 4, 18, 19795) One would have thought that the least that should have been done was to have automatically recognized as fully domiciled every Indian found in Burma on the date of promulgation of the Agreement.
('81', 13, 4, 19, 19990) I am acquainted with the immigration laws of South Africa and other countries.
('81', 13, 4, 20, 20069) In every case the restrictions have been imposed by legislation and, after fairly full opportunity being given for the expression of public opinion, legislation has been preceded by considerable lapse of time for the ventilation of views on the mere proposal for legislation.
('81', 13, 4, 21, 20345) In this case secrecy and mystery have surrounded the Agreement which has been sprung upon an unsuspecting public.
('81', 14, 0, 1, 20459) VOL. 81 : 18 AUGUST, 1941 8 FEBRUARY, 1942 15
('81', 14, 1, 2, 20505) The whole thing appears still more hideous when we recall the fact that only a few years ago Burma was an integral part of India.
('81', 14, 1, 3, 20635) Does the partition make India a leper country the presence of whose inhabitants must carry heavy penalties including the tickets of leave such as criminals carry?
('81', 14, 1, 4, 20798) They do not cease to be less offensive because they bear the inoffensive name of passports andpermits.
('81', 14, 1, 5, 20901) I should be prepared to understand the validity of the permit and passport system when the necessity is clearly established.
('81', 14, 1, 6, 21026) I must refuse to believe that this Agreement is in response to a vital cry from the great Burmese nation with which the people of India never had any quarrel and with which India had enjoyed cultural contact long before the advent of the foreigner from the West.
('81', 14, 1, 7, 21289) We can never be in Burma or the Burmans in India foreigners in the same sense as people from the West.
('81', 14, 1, 8, 21392) There has been free commerce and emigration to Burma for hundreds of years.
('81', 14, 1, 9, 21468) This drastic Agreement is an undeserved slur both on India and Burma.
('81', 14, 1, 10, 21538) This Agreement is a brutal reminder that both India and Burma are under the British heel and that the Government of India Act and the Government of Burma Act gave no real freedom to the respective peoples.
('81', 14, 1, 11, 21744) They give no scope for full growth to us.
('81', 14, 1, 12, 21786) I fear that this statement of mine will not please the Premier of Burma who may think that the Agreement is a popular Act.
('81', 14, 1, 13, 21909) He will soon discover the error, if he has not already, that he has not served his people but that he has played himself into the hands of those who would want to exploit Burma to the exclusion of any rivals.
('81', 14, 1, 14, 22118) I must admit that Indians have been partners with the Westerners in the exploitation of Burma, but with this fundamental difference, that the Westerner went to Burma with his gun, while the Indian went on sufferance as he has always done in every part of the world.
('81', 14, 1, 15, 22384) We cannot exist in Burma for one single day without Burmese goodwill.
('81', 14, 1, 16, 22454) I would plead with the Burmese Ministers and the Burmese people that they should wait for the regulation of immigration till both of us are free and independent for such regulation.
('81', 14, 1, 17, 22636) I flatter myself with the belief that when that happy day arrives, as it must, such matters will regulate themselves, for we shall never want to impose our nationals on one another.
('81', 14, 1, 18, 22818) But I have strayed.
('81', 14, 1, 19, 22838) My purpose just now is to show that this Agreement must be undone inasmuch as it breaks every canon of
('81', 15, 0, 1, 22941) 16 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('81', 15, 1, 2, 22982) international propriety.
('81', 15, 1, 3, 23007) It becomes less defensible in that an Indian 1 instead of an Englishman was sent to negotiate the Agreement.
('81', 15, 1, 4, 23116) It is an old and familiar trick, that of putting up an Indian to perform a disagreeable task.
('81', 15, 1, 5, 23210) Nor is it relevant that the Agreement had the approvalof local Indian opinion.
('81', 15, 1, 6, 23289) For the Agreement is an insult to the whole nation, not merely to the particular individuals whose material interests lie in Burma.
('81', 15, 1, 7, 23421) But even if it was relevant, there should be evidence to show the volume and character of that opinion.
('81', 15, 1, 8, 23525) When I come to examine the Baxter Report 2, which became the prelude to the Agreement, it contains nothing to justify the Agreement.
('81', 15, 1, 9, 23658) This was the reference made to Mr. Baxter:
('81', 15, 2, 10, 23701) The enquiry will be directed to ascertaining:
('81', 15, 3, 11, 23747) 1. the volume of Indian immigration; 2. to what extent it is seasonal and temporary and to what extent permanent; 3. in what occupations Indians are mainly employed and the extent to which they are unemployed or underemployed; 4. whether in such employment Indians either have displaced Burmans or could be replaced by Burmans, due regard being paid to both the previous history of such occupations and their economic requirements; and 5. whether in the light of the statistics obtained and other relevant factors any system of equating the supply of Indian unskilled labour to Burmans’ requirements is needed.
('81', 15, 3, 12, 24358) Thus it was purely a fact finding commission.
('81', 15, 3, 13, 24404) Here is the fact found by the Commission:
('81', 15, 4, 14, 24446) There is no evidence of any kind to suggest that Indians have displaced Burmans from employment which they had previously obtained.
('81', 15, 4, 15, 24578) Indian labour in the past has been supplementary rather than alternative to Burmese labour.
('81', 15, 4, 16, 24670) That surely does not justify the restrictions imposed by the Agreement on the movement of Indians in Burma.
('81', 15, 4, 17, 24778) The recommendations made in the Report appear to me to be in excess of the reference and therefore of no effect.
('81', 15, 4, 18, 24891) Add to this the fact that the opinion of the assessors finds no mention in the Report.
('81', 15, 4, 19, 24978) It may not have weighed with the Commissioner but surely it should have found mention in the Report.
('81', 15, 5, 20, 25079) 1 Girija Shankar Bajpai; vide “Letter to Amrit Kaur”, 27 7 1941
('81', 15, 6, 21, 25143) 2 James Baxter, Financial Adviser, with two assessors, U Tin Tut and Ratilal Desai, was appointed by the Government of Burma to examine the question of Indian immigration into Burma.
('81', 15, 6, 22, 25326) The report was submitted to the Government of Burma in October 1940.
('81', 16, 0, 1, 25395) VOL. 81 : 18 AUGUST, 1941 8 FEBRUARY, 1942 17
('81', 16, 1, 2, 25441) Now let me for a moment examine the pertinent sections of the Act.
('81', 16, 1, 3, 25508) Here they are: Section 44(3) of the Government of Burma Act, 1935, says:
('81', 16, 2, 4, 25581) The provisions of Sub section (2) of this Section shall apply in relation to British subjects domiciled in India and subjects of any Indian State as they apply in relation to British subjects domiciled in the United Kingdom, but with the substitution in the provision to the said Sub section for references to the United Kingdom or references to British India, or as the case may be, that Indian State:
('81', 16, 3, 5, 25984) Provided that nothing in this Sub section shall affect any restriction lawfully imposed on the right of entry into Burma of persons who are British subjects domiciled in India or subjects of any Indian State, or any restriction lawfully imposed as a condition of allowing any such persons to enter Burma.
('81', 16, 3, 6, 26289) Section 138 of the same Act:
('81', 16, 4, 7, 26318) His Majesty may by Order in Council direct that, during such period as may be specified in the Order, immigration into Burma from India shall be subject to such restrictions as may be specified in the Order (being such restrictions as may have been mutually agreed before the commencement of this Act between the Governor of Burma in Council and the Governor General of India in Council and approved by the Secretary of State, or in default of agreement as may have been prescribed by the Secretary of State), and no other restrictions:
('81', 16, 5, 8, 26855) Provided that any such Order may be varied by a subsequent Order in Council in such manner as appears to His Majesty necessary to give effect to any agreement in that behalf made after the commencement of this Act by the Governor with the Governor General of India or the Governor General of India in Council.
('81', 16, 5, 9, 27165) The first read as a whole does not appear to contemplate any interference with the present Indian population.
('81', 16, 5, 10, 27275) The second is decisive.
('81', 16, 5, 11, 27299) According to this Section restriction by agreement cannot be imposed on the present Indian settlers.
('81', 16, 5, 12, 27400) I have no doubt whatsoever that the Secretary of State for India should not pass the Order in Council and should withhold his assent to the Agreement.
('81', 16, 5, 13, 27551) Any restriction should be a matter for legislation by the Burmese Assembly in consultation with and with the co operation of the Government of India.
('81', 16, 5, 14, 27701) It is pertinent to the examination of the Agreement to know what declarations were made by His Majesty’s Ministers when the Act was passed.
('81', 16, 5, 15, 27841) Here is the assurance of Sir Thomas Inskip, the then Minister for Co ordination and Defence, on the subject:
('81', 16, 6, 16, 27950) Nobody wants to discriminate between British subjects domiciled in India
('81', 17, 0, 1, 28023) 18 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('81', 17, 1, 2, 28064) or Indian States’ subjects when they go to Burma, any more than one wants to discriminate between the British when they go to British India.
('81', 17, 1, 3, 28205) Mr. Butler (then Under Secretary of State for India) also stated in the House of Commons:
('81', 17, 2, 4, 28295) In connection with unskilled Indian labour, the Governor of Burma is asked to confer with the Governor General with a view to ,regulating the immigration of unskilled labour into Burma.
('81', 17, 2, 5, 28481) The reason we cannot make a simple rule is that we have to make this differentiation in regard to unskilled labour, while at the same time we do not want to stop the free entry of Indians in general.
('81', 17, 2, 6, 28681) Such declarations may have no validity in the interpretation of the Act in a court of law.
('81', 17, 2, 7, 28772) But politically considered they have or should have the effect of promissory notes.
('81', 17, 2, 8, 28856) The Agreement is a clear breach of the declarations quoted by me.
('81', 17, 2, 9, 28922) I am glad that responsible Indian public opinion is being expressed in unmistakable terms in condemnation of the Agreement.
('81', 17, 2, 10, 29046) The Bombay Chronicle, 25 8 1941

('81', 39, 0, 1, 61294) 40 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('81', 39, 1, 2, 61335) 74. FOREWORD TO “PRACTICAL NON VIOLENCE”
('81', 39, 2, 3, 61376) It is simply a coincidence that these essays on “Practical Non violence” are being published in pamphlet form almost simultaneously with Richard Gregg’s A Discipline for Non violence 1. The votary of non violence should read the two together.
('81', 39, 2, 4, 61619) Kishorelal Mashruwala is like R. Gregg a deep student of non violence.
('81', 39, 2, 5, 61690) Though he has been brought up in that faith, he never takes anything for granted.
('81', 39, 2, 6, 61772) He believes only what he has tested.
('81', 39, 2, 7, 61809) Thus he has come to accept non violence by hard thinking.
('81', 39, 2, 8, 61867) He has in his own life and practice proved its efficacy in a variety of conditions—political, economic, social and domestic.
('81', 39, 2, 9, 61992) His essays have, therefore, a value all their own.
('81', 39, 2, 10, 62043) They should help the believer in non violence in sustaining his faith and the honest unbeliever in resolving his doubts.
('81', 39, 2, 11, 62164) M. K. GANDHI SEVAGRAM, August 31, 1941
('81', 39, 3, 12, 62203) Practical Non violence
('81', 39, 4, 13, 62226) 75. A DIFFICULT PROBLEM
('81', 39, 5, 14, 62250) A person who is scientifically inclined does not take the truth of anything for granted; he tries to prove it himself.
('81', 39, 5, 15, 62369) In this way he develops his own intellect and also obtains knowledge of the potentialities of things.
('81', 39, 5, 16, 62471) Why does an apple fall off the tree, why does it not fly up?
('81', 39, 5, 17, 62532) It is said that this question arose in Newton’s mind and he discovered the law of gravitation.
('81', 39, 5, 18, 62627) Is the earth flat like a plate?
('81', 39, 5, 19, 62659) Is it stationary?
('81', 39, 5, 20, 62677) Such questions arose in Galileo’s mind and he discovered that the earth is spherical like an orange and revolves on its axis.
('81', 39, 5, 21, 62803) Such discoveries have produced great results.
('81', 39, 5, 22, 62849) A khadi worker should adopt a similar scientific attitude.
('81', 39, 5, 23, 62908) Newton or Galileo did not ponder over the problem of Daridran arayana and of serving Daridranarayana.
('81', 39, 5, 24, 63010) They followed an intellectual quest.
('81', 39, 5, 25, 63047) The khadi worker has however to find a solutionto the problem of feeding the hungry masses.
('81', 39, 5, 26, 63139) That is why their attitude should be all the more scientific.
('81', 39, 5, 27, 63201) Why khadi?
('81', 39, 5, 28, 63212) Why not mill cloth?
('81', 39, 5, 29, 63232) Also, why not foreign cloth?
('81', 39, 5, 30, 63261) Why cotton cloth?
('81', 39, 5, 31, 63279) Why not silk?
('81', 39, 5, 32, 63293) Why not jute or woollen textiles?
('81', 39, 5, 33, 63327) Why the charkha?
('81', 39, 5, 34, 63344) Why not the takli?
('81', 39, 5, 35, 63363) I can go on filling pages with questions
('81', 39, 6, 36, 63404) 1 For Gandhiji’s foreword to this pamphlet, vide “Forward to “A Discipline For Non Violence”, 24 8 1941
('81', 40, 0, 1, 63508) VOL. 81 : 18 AUGUST, 1941 8 FEBRUARY, 1942 41
('81', 40, 1, 2, 63554) like these but I do not propose to exhaust all the possible questions.
('81', 40, 1, 3, 63625) I want to touch upon only one question here.
('81', 40, 1, 4, 63670) Suppose for a moment that for one reason or the other India does not have or cannot run textile mills, also suppose that no cloth can be imported from abroad, can we then provide sufficient khadi to all the Indians?
('81', 40, 1, 5, 63886) We should not be satisfied with meeting the demand somehow.
('81', 40, 1, 6, 63946) The East India Company did this and to some extent this was done even earlier.
('81', 40, 1, 7, 64025) In those days people were forced to spin and to weave on minimum wages.
('81', 40, 1, 8, 64097) This custom was called begar.
('81', 40, 1, 9, 64127) We have to confess with regret that begar is an ancient custom.
('81', 40, 1, 10, 64191) It was not introduced by the British.
('81', 40, 1, 11, 64229) We may perhaps be able to produce enough khadi through begar.
('81', 40, 1, 12, 64291) But khadi workers cannot be trained to undertake such inhuman work.
('81', 40, 1, 13, 64359) Our intention is to help the spinners earn such wages as would ensure, after eight hours’ hard labour, wholesome and nutritious food, necessary clothing, comfortable houses and other amenities necessary for a happy home.
('81', 40, 1, 14, 64580) If it is proved that khadi cannot succeed under these terms and conditions, we should modestly accept the limitations of khadi and also restrict our activity.
('81', 40, 1, 15, 64739) Let me state my view here.
('81', 40, 1, 16, 64766) I have adopted khadi in the belief that khadi has all the above mentioned capacity.
('81', 40, 1, 17, 64850) I cannot adduce irrefutable evidence in support of my view.
('81', 40, 1, 18, 64910) Many of my activities are undertaken in good faith or intuitively.
('81', 40, 1, 19, 64977) But they are not conducted on the basis of inspiration alone; I have tried to place my convictions on a sound scientific foundation while propagating them.
('81', 40, 1, 20, 65133) I have made and am still making all possible experiments based on reason and I encourage my co workers to do so.
('81', 40, 1, 21, 65246) We have not found a solution to the problem posed above; we may perhaps never get it and I know it is a difficult problem, a complex problem.
('81', 40, 1, 22, 65388) It does involve a lot of statistics as also knowledge of economics, psychology, particularly of the Indian mind, and also of ethics.
('81', 40, 1, 23, 65521) A mere statistical solution will not do, nor will a mere economic solution, because we cannot ignore our most fundamental and vital principles.
('81', 40, 1, 24, 65665) We do not want to spread khadi through coercion.
('81', 40, 1, 25, 65714) We want to do our work by changing people’s sense of values and habits.
('81', 40, 1, 26, 65786) Hence our researches should proceed from all angles.
('81', 40, 1, 27, 65839) Khadi workers should intensify their efforts to solve this difficult problem.
('81', 40, 1, 28, 65917) This is enough for the day.
('81', 40, 1, 29, 65945) [From Hindi] Khadi Jagat, August 1941
('81', 41, 0, 1, 65983) 42 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('81', 58, 1, 2, 89180) 113. LETTER TO AMRIT KAUR
('81', 58, 2, 3, 89206) Unrevised September 5, 1941
('81', 58, 3, 4, 89234) MY DEAR IDIOT, I write this during the silent hour, i.e., before dinner and before the post.
('81', 58, 3, 5, 89327) I have not heard from Agatha nor from Henry 1. But I saw H.’s article in a magazine which contained the attack.
('81', 58, 3, 6, 89439) I thought I should correct him.
('81', 58, 3, 7, 89471) If you want to see the article I can send it to you.
('81', 58, 3, 8, 89524) And as I did not know H.’s address I wrote to Agatha.
('81', 58, 3, 9, 89578) Of course you were right in refusing the Hyd.
('81', 58, 3, 10, 89624) invitation as you would be in refusing every other.
('81', 58, 3, 11, 89676) I sent it to you so that you may know it and send a reply.
('81', 58, 3, 12, 89735) You were bound to refuse.
('81', 58, 3, 13, 89761) Before you take up anything you must be thoroughly restored.
('81', 58, 3, 14, 89822) Even as it is, you are giving a good account of yourself.
('81', 58, 3, 15, 89880) You remember the pamphlet containing the Lahore resolution 2 on Pakistan!
('81', 58, 3, 16, 89954) Two copies have been traced in the library.
('81', 58, 3, 17, 89998) I never anticipate evil.
('81', 58, 3, 18, 90023) So the answer to your question stands deferred till the .evil overtakes us but which shall not.
('81', 58, 3, 19, 90119) Is that satisfactory answer, if it is any?
('81', 58, 3, 20, 90162) Do you remember your question?
('81', 58, 3, 21, 90193) For the time being you need do nothing about Narendra Dev.
('81', 58, 3, 22, 90252) I shall inquire.
('81', 58, 3, 23, 90269) I do not know anything about the Dehra Dun offer.
('81', 58, 3, 24, 90319) Prabhavati wrote for the transfer of Jayaprakash on the ground of ill health, which is patent.
('81', 58, 3, 25, 90414) Her application is summarily rejected.
('81', 58, 3, 26, 90453) They can’t do anything because it is right.
('81', 58, 3, 27, 90497) They yield only to pressure bordering on violence.
('81', 58, 3, 28, 90548) We are on that portion of Ramayana which relates Narad’s confusion because he had to be corrected.
('81', 58, 3, 29, 90647) Truly does God confound the wisdom of those whom He seeks to destroy.

('81', 59, 3, 5, 91531) 114. INTERVIEW TO H. V. KAMATH 1
('81', 59, 4, 6, 91564) SEVAGRAM, September 5, 1941
('81', 59, 5, 7, 91592) Q. Has the entry of Russia into the war altered its complexion and India’s attitude thereto?
('81', 59, 6, 8, 91685) A. The entry of Russia into the war has not materially altered the complexion of the war.
('81', 59, 6, 9, 91775) Expression of oral sympathy with Russia as a victim of aggression is not wrong but no purpose will be served by so doing so long as we cannot translate it into action.
('81', 59, 6, 10, 91943) Russia is not wholly free from blame inasmuch as she has allied herself with imperialist power though it may be for the purpose of self existence only.
('81', 59, 6, 11, 92095) Had Jawaharlalji, who is a close student of international politics, not been behind the bars and thus free to express his views, his opinion in the matter would have weighed with me.
('81', 59, 7, 12, 92278) Q. Can you, Mahatmaji, envisage the emergence of a non violent new world order in the Atlantic Charter?
('81', 59, 7, 13, 92382) I am not able to envisage in the Atlantic Charter the emergence of a non violent new world order of my conception.
('81', 59, 8, 14, 92497) Q. What is your attitude towards the acceptance of office in the Viceroy’s Executive Council by Congressmen such as Sjt.
('81', 59, 8, 15, 92618) Aney 2 and Mr. Nalini Ranjan Sircar 3?
('81', 59, 8, 16, 92657) A. I do not approve of the acceptance of office by Congressmen such as Sri Aney and Nalini Babu.
('81', 59, 8, 17, 92754) Such action on their part has undoubtedly given a handle to the British Government for carrying on propaganda in America to the effect that India should now be satisfied in that even well known ex Congressmen have joined the Viceroy’s Council.
('81', 59, 9, 18, 92998) Q. Is the satyagraha movement proceeding to your satisfaction?
('81', 59, 9, 19, 93061) In what way is it
('81', 59, 10, 20, 93079) 1 H. V. Kamath, Organizing Secretary of the All India Forward Bloc, submitted this report for Gandhiji’s approval who revised it in places, though not very materially.
('81', 59, 10, 21, 93247) 2 Madhav Srihari Aney who joined as member in charge, Overseas Indians 3 Who joined as member in charge, Education, Health and Lands
('81', 60, 0, 1, 93380) VOL. 81 : 18 AUGUST, 1941 8 FEBRUARY, 1942 61
('81', 60, 1, 2, 93426) different from the 1930 movement 1?
('81', 60, 1, 3, 93462) Has the policy of non embarrassment any political
('81', 60, 2, 4, 93512) value or significance?
('81', 60, 2, 5, 93535) What will be your attitude in case the Government conceded the
('81', 60, 3, 6, 93598) right of freedom of speech?
('81', 60, 3, 7, 93626) Is there any likelihood of intensification of the struggle in
('81', 60, 4, 8, 93688) the near future?
('81', 60, 4, 9, 93705) A. The satyagraha movement is proceeding to my entire satisfaction.
('81', 60, 4, 10, 93773) Pressure on a scale comparable to that of the 1930 movement is not being put on the Government, it is true, but that movement was different in character from the present one.
('81', 60, 4, 11, 93948) But the main fact that the struggle is going on constitutes sufficient moral pressure, so much so that the British Government’s position in America does not appear to be quite comfortable.
('81', 60, 4, 12, 94137) The policy of non embarrassment is a logical consequence of non violence and in that way a political necessity, but I do not expect the British Government to reciprocate my chivalrous stand.
('81', 60, 4, 13, 94328) There is no possibility of the Government conceding the right of freedom of speech, but if they did so honestly, I am bound to call off the movement.
('81', 60, 4, 14, 94478) Bona fide recognition of free non violent speech would mean a large step towards independence.
('81', 60, 4, 15, 94573) Intensification of the struggle is not likely during the pendency of the war.
('81', 60, 4, 16, 94651) Intensification will come at the close of the war if it became necessary.
('81', 60, 5, 17, 94725) Q What is your attitude to the local kisan and mazdoor struggles?
('81', 60, 6, 18, 94791) A. I extend my sympathy to all local kisan and mazdoor struggles for their legitimate demands and such struggles cannot amount to embarrassment of the Government.
('81', 60, 6, 19, 94954) My attitude cannot be otherwise, considering that I myself have been the author of such struggles in the past.
('81', 60, 7, 20, 95065) Q. In view of the fact that the word ‘non violence’ does not appear in the Congress Constitution, what is the duty of Congressmen as regards non violent conduct?
('81', 60, 7, 21, 95227) A. Though the word ‘non violence’ does not appear in the Congress Constitution, it does in resolutions.
('81', 60, 7, 22, 95331) Though there be no resolution of a plenary session of the Congress on the subject of non violence, I expect Congressmen to abide by the A.I.C.C. resolution so long as it is not modified or altered by a plenary session.
('81', 60, 8, 23, 95550) Q. Acharya Kripalani recently, in reply to Sardar Sardul Singh Caveeshar, said
('81', 60, 9, 24, 95629) that the Forward Bloc is not a part of the Congress organization.
('81', 60, 9, 25, 95695) The statementon
('81', 60, 10, 26, 95711) Kripalaniji’s part has created not a little confusion and misunderstanding among
('81', 60, 11, 27, 95792) several Congressmen.
('81', 60, 11, 28, 95813) I personally hold that the position of the Forward Bloc in the
('81', 60, 12, 29, 95876) Congress is quite similar to that of the Congress Socialist Party.
('81', 60, 12, 30, 95943) Could you kindly
('81', 60, 13, 31, 95960) 1 Dandi March and Salt Satyagraha
('81', 61, 0, 1, 95994) 62 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('81', 61, 1, 2, 96035) enlighten me with your opinion on the subject?
('81', 61, 1, 3, 96082) A. Though the Congress Constitution does not recognize separate groups within the Congress organization, Congressmen who owe allegiance to such groups have every right to remain in the Congress in their individual capacity if the groups are not inconsistent with the Congress resolution and policy.
('81', 61, 1, 4, 96381) I never insisted that Congressmen who do not subscribe to my interpretation of non violence should leave the Congress.
('81', 61, 1, 5, 96500) The Congress Socialist Party is just as much not a part of the Congress organization as the Forward Bloc.
('81', 61, 1, 6, 96606) The Congress Constitution makes no mention of either as being component parts of the Congress organization.
('81', 61, 1, 7, 96714) The Forward Bloc and the Congress Socialist Party are on a par with each other so far as their being part of the Congress organization is concerned.
('81', 61, 2, 8, 96863) Q. Have you, Mahatmaji, full faith in a Divine Power moulding our destiny?
('81', 61, 3, 9, 96938) A. Yes, I have full faith in a Divine Power guiding the destinies of India and of the world.
('81', 61, 3, 10, 97031) It is this living faith that sustains me in the present crisis.
('81', 61, 3, 11, 97095) The Hindu, 5 11 1941
('81', 61, 4, 12, 97116) 115. LETTER TO SARANGADHAR DAS
('81', 61, 5, 13, 97147) SEVAGRAM, WARDHA, September 6, 1941
('81', 61, 6, 14, 97183) DEAR SARANGADHAR DAS, Rajkumari is resting in Simla.
('81', 61, 6, 15, 97236) She won’t be back before October.
('81', 61, 6, 16, 97270) Your letter to her gives a piteous tale.
('81', 61, 6, 17, 97311) This is my advice.
('81', 61, 6, 18, 97330) The men whose statements you have translated had no notion of the working of ahimsa.
('81', 61, 6, 19, 97415) If they had the courage of non violence they could not have come away alive except by converting their assailants miscalled Police without retaliation.
('81', 61, 6, 20, 97567) That would mean ahimsa of the highest order.
('81', 61, 6, 21, 97612) This does not come except by long previo us training.
('81', 61, 6, 22, 97666) It is rarely seen.
('81', 61, 6, 23, 97685) But if one cannot exhibit such courage, one must not be a coward.
('81', 61, 6, 24, 97751) One has not only the right but it is a duty to retaliate in a vigorous manner.
('81', 61, 6, 25, 97830) This again requires great courage.
('81', 61, 6, 26, 97865) I have, seen it exhibited successfully.
('81', 61, 6, 27, 97905) It should not matter how heavy the odds are.
('81', 61, 6, 28, 97950) Resistance may mean death.
('81', 61, 6, 29, 97977) It must be faced in preference to a cowardly resignatio to brutal and indecent treatment.Iti this self defence which is not taboo to a Congressman.
('81', 61, 6, 30, 98125) It is the inherent right and the bounden duty of a man to defend honour non violently if he knows how, otherwise violently.
('81', 61, 6, 31, 98249) There is no other way.
('81', 61, 6, 32, 98272) Such a man will soon
('81', 62, 0, 1, 98293) VOL. 81 : 18 AUGUST, 1941 8 FEBRUARY, 1942 63
('81', 62, 1, 2, 98339) be able to learn the virtue of non violence.
('81', 62, 1, 3, 98384) But that is only by the way.
('81', 62, 1, 4, 98413) My advice is clear and emphatic.
('81', 62, 1, 5, 98446) There is too much of this assaulting in Orissa, assuming the truth of statements that have been sent to me from time to time.
('81', 62, 1, 6, 98572) If you have assimilated my advice you will act in a methodical and deliberate manner.
('81', 62, 1, 7, 98658) You will be at liberty to publish this letter with a carefully thought out programme as to how to go about it.
('81', 62, 1, 8, 98769) You may send me the draft manifesto for approval or you may come when you like for a discussion before acting.
('81', 62, 1, 9, 98880) The matter is too important to be ignored.
('81', 62, 2, 10, 98923) From a copy: C.W. 10443. Courtesy: Government of Orissa

('81', 78, 13, 20, 123282) But it will take you forward.

('81', 78, 14, 28, 123809) 1 The addressee had written: “And I see no disgrace in accepting help from a foreign power in order to protect India’s nationalism and unity— that power may be Britain today, and who knows which other power after the War!

('81', 79, 0, 1, 124113) 80 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('81', 79, 1, 2, 124154) Freedom won through non violent means will need no help, or it will need the entire world’s.
('81', 79, 1, 3, 124247) All this is so clear that you should have no difficulty in understanding it.
('81', 79, 1, 4, 124324) But if you do have any, please find some time to come over here at least to get your doubt resolved.
('81', 79, 1, 5, 124425) This is a very important issue.

('81', 79, 1, 7, 124540) The fight about Pakistan is a fight between two brothers.
('81', 79, 1, 8, 124598) One can get reconciled to one brother being defeated at the hands of the other; but the one who wins with the help of a third party will himself become a slave and also make the other a slave.
('81', 79, 1, 9, 124791) Whom are the British helping today?
('81', 79, 1, 10, 124827) Where does Pakistan exist in the present situation?

('81', 79, 1, 12, 124954) He who seeks to realize that dream may be no more than a dust particle floating in the sky but after all it is floating.
('81', 79, 1, 13, 125075) Its dream lifts it above; it does not cast it down.
('81', 79, 1, 14, 125127) Its exercise of individual freedom makes it shine brightly in the sky.
('81', 79, 1, 15, 125198) Whose help can it require?
('81', 79, 1, 16, 125225) And if all the particles get together, that is, recognize their individuality, then they themselves will be the sky.
('81', 79, 1, 17, 125342) Can you conceive a sky without particles?

('81', 79, 1, 21, 125570) If I go on further I would be only wasting time.
('81', 79, 1, 22, 125619) But what need to argue at length with the wise?

('81', 80, 9, 17, 127325) question.

('81', 80, 11, 21, 127506) the cause of Indian independence for which the Congress is fighting?” Gandhiji replied: If I did not believe so I would have come out with a statement without any prompting from you.
('81', 80, 11, 22, 127689) But I sincerely believe that my silence is much more eloquent than any words that I may utter.

('81', 85, 5, 20, 135537) I don’t think anything else is possible.
('81', 85, 5, 21, 135578) And please also remember that ultimately the people themselves will decide these questions and bypass us all.
('81', 85, 5, 22, 135688) I would, therefore, advise you to extricate yourself from this business, or to proceed on the basis of certain fundamental principles.
('81', 85, 5, 23, 135823) It will be enough if you cling to even one.

('81', 95, 7, 10, 149702) 181. WORK FOR EVERYONE
('81', 95, 8, 11, 149725) I have sent a message for women and children to this effect: 2
('81', 95, 9, 12, 149788) Enough khadi can be produced if children up to the age of twelve and women gave a few hours of their spare time to spinning and other processes of khadi production.
('81', 95, 9, 13, 149953) I had asked Krishnadas Gandhi to work out some figures to prove the above contention.
('81', 95, 9, 14, 150039) I give below an abstract of the findings.
('81', 95, 9, 15, 150081) India’s population was estimated at about 35 crores in the 1931 census.
('81', 95, 9, 16, 150153) Children in the age group of eight to twelve numbered about 4_ crores and women and girls above the age of 12 numbered about 11 crores.
('81', 95, 9, 17, 150289) If the children devoted four hours to cleaning, carding and spinning and if the women devoted four hours to cleaning, carding, spinning and weaving daily, enough khadi can be produced.
('81', 95, 9, 18, 150474) It can be shown by calculation that the children can produce every day yarn of ten to twelve counts that can be woven into 90 lac square yards of khadi, whereas the women can produce every day two crore square yards of twenty counts in addition to weaving the ninety lac square yards of khadi out of the yarn spun by the children.
('81', 95, 9, 19, 150805) It has been calculated that the entire process from the cleaning of cotton to weaving a 20 counts square yard of cloth involves 18 hours of labour on the part of one person.
('81', 95, 9, 20, 150979) Out of this half an hour will go to the cleaning of cotton, two hours for carding, 12 hours for spinning, one hour for
('81', 95, 10, 21, 151098) 1 This was in reply to the addressee’s letter forwarded by the jail authorities on September 17, 1941. 2 Vide”Message to People of Ahmedabad”, 8 9 1941
('81', 96, 0, 1, 151250) VOL. 81 : 18 AUGUST, 1941 8 FEBRUARY, 1942 97
('81', 96, 1, 2, 151296) unwinding the yarn, one hour for making and fixing the warp and sizing and one and a half hours for actual weaving.
('81', 96, 1, 3, 151412) This is the breakdown of the total of 18 hours.
('81', 96, 1, 4, 151460) It is based on the average skill of an average person.
('81', 96, 1, 5, 151515) An efficient worker may complete this process in just 15 hours.
('81', 96, 1, 6, 151579) On a rough estimate the women and children can, with such skill as they have, produce about 30 square yards of khadi for every person in this country by working four hours a day for 300 days in a year.
('81', 96, 1, 7, 151781) My object in publishing this abstract is to encourage an institution to undertake an experiment to corroborate it.
('81', 96, 1, 8, 151896) Any family can easily produce all the cloth that it requires by introducing a charkha and a loom in their home.
('81', 96, 1, 9, 152008) Suppose there are 35 individuals in an institution including four children in the age group of 8 to 12 and 11 women above the age of 13. All men, of course, will be busy with other activities.
('81', 96, 1, 10, 152201) Ten out of the eleven women and all the four children can devote three to four hours every day to cleaning, carding, spinning and weaving according to their convenience.
('81', 96, 1, 11, 152371) One of the ten women will help the four children and will also weave the yarn produced by the children.
('81', 96, 1, 12, 152475) The remaining nine women will undertake all the work from cleaning to weaving.
('81', 96, 1, 13, 152554) According to the calculations given above, the four children together with one woman will produce at least three fourths of a square yard of 10 to 12 counts khadi every day and the 9 women will easily produce two square yards of 20 counts khadi every day.
('81', 96, 1, 14, 152810) If we calculate for 300 days in a year, all of them will together produce 225 square yards of coarse khadi and 600 square yards of fine khadi.
('81', 96, 1, 15, 152953) Thus a total of 825 square yards of cloth will be available for the 35 persons or, in other words, everyone will get 23_ square yards of cloth.
('81', 96, 1, 16, 153097) As the efficiency grows every individual will be able to get 27_ square yards of cloth.
('81', 96, 1, 17, 153185) It should be remembered that so much cloth can be produced even in less time by using the now improved charkhas and carding bows.
('81', 96, 1, 18, 153315) If every home has a charkha and a loom we can produce the cloth we need with very little effort.
('81', 96, 1, 19, 153412) It will create a great contentment in the home.
('81', 96, 1, 20, 153460) We can only imagine what an impact this can have on our lives and how it can inspire all the people.
('81', 96, 1, 21, 153561) But for oneself one can instantly discover this bliss.
('81', 96, 1, 22, 153616) Sevagram, Charkha Dwadashi, September 18, 1941 [From Hindi] Khadi Jagat, September 1941
('81', 97, 0, 1, 153704) 98 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('81', 97, 1, 2, 153745) 182. BLANKETS FOR SOLDIERS
('81', 97, 2, 3, 153772) It is a good augury that votaries of non violence often raise fine questions of principle.
('81', 97, 2, 4, 153863) Man advances through such spirit of inquiry, but there is a prerequisite condition to it.
('81', 97, 2, 5, 153953) The inquiry should not be like that of a person who strains at a gnat and swallows a camel.
('81', 97, 2, 6, 154045) Raising such questions profit only him who is ever vigilant in major matters and whose practice keeps pace with the progress of the principle.
('81', 97, 2, 7, 154188) Let me illustrate what I mean.
('81', 97, 2, 8, 154219) A certain khadi bhandar received an order for woollen blankets from the military.
('81', 97, 2, 9, 154301) The bhandar authorities asked me whether they could accept it replied that they could.
('81', 97, 2, 10, 154388) The question of principle raised was whether it did not amount to helping the war.
('81', 97, 2, 11, 154471) As a matter of abstract principle, it will have to be conceded that the acceptance was a breach.
('81', 97, 2, 12, 154568) But in that case, we must leave India and every country engaged in the war.
('81', 97, 2, 13, 154644) Because we help war in purchasing the very food we eat.
('81', 97, 2, 14, 154700) We do the same when we travel by train or buy postage stamps.
('81', 97, 2, 15, 154762) Our use of the currency itself is an aid to war.
('81', 97, 2, 16, 154811) In fact we are hardly able to do any act which is free from the taint.
('81', 97, 2, 17, 154882) The truth is that no one is able to act upon a great principle, like that of non violence, in its entirety.
('81', 97, 2, 18, 154990) Like the geometrical line, it can only be imagined, but never drawn.
('81', 97, 2, 19, 155059) In practice, we have to be content with drawing only such fine lines as we can with our instruments.
('81', 97, 2, 20, 155160) There is no wall which can be called ‘straight’ according to Euclid.
('81', 97, 2, 21, 155229) And yet, walls have stood the test of time for thousands of years.
('81', 97, 2, 22, 155296) It is the same with ahimsa.
('81', 97, 2, 23, 155324) We must put it into practice as best as we can.
('81', 97, 2, 24, 155372) It would have been easy for me to forbid the sale of the blankets.
('81', 97, 2, 25, 155439) It was a question of only a few thousand rupees, a small amount for an establishment whose turnover is in lakhs.
('81', 97, 2, 26, 155552) But the prohibition would have been a matter of shame for me.
('81', 97, 2, 27, 155614) I could have done so only by concealing my real view of the matter.
('81', 97, 2, 28, 155682) Where should I draw the line from which such prohibition should commence?
('81', 97, 2, 29, 155756) If I were a grain merchant, should I decline to sell it to soldiers?
('81', 97, 2, 30, 155825) Or, if I were a chemist, should I refuse to sell quinine and other drugs to them?
('81', 97, 2, 31, 155907) If I should, what c ould be the reason for my doing so?
('81', 97, 2, 32, 155963) Does my ahimsa prevent me from entertaining such customers?
('81', 97, 2, 33, 156023) In other words, does it require of me to look into the occupations of my customers?
('81', 98, 0, 1, 156107) VOL. 81 : 18 AUGUST, 1941 8 FEBRUARY, 1942 99
('81', 98, 1, 2, 156153) clear reply is that provided I deal in goods which conduce to the welfare of society, I may not look into the occupations of my customers.
('81', 98, 1, 3, 156292) This means that I may sell my innocuous articles even to soldiers.
('81', 98, 1, 4, 156359) SEVAGRAM, September 18, 1941 [From Hindi] Khadi Jagat, September 1941
('81', 98, 2, 5, 156429) 183. UNCERTIFIED KHADI
('81', 98, 3, 6, 156452) One who purchases uncertified khadi is ignorant of the purpose of khadi, which was conceived as a simple means to remove the poverty of Daridranarayana, which alone can improve India’s economic condition and ultimately win freedom.
('81', 98, 3, 7, 156684) Therein lies the importance of khadi and if khadi has to play its role in removing the poverty of the millions it must be under the control of some organization or State authority.
('81', 98, 3, 8, 156865) Crores of spinners would be willing to spin for eight hours for a paltry pice for they must fill their bellies.
('81', 98, 3, 9, 156977) Khadi made from yarn spun by them may be called hand spun but by its use we certainly will not be serving Daridranarayana.
('81', 98, 3, 10, 157100) The Charkha Sangh has therefore at once increased the spinners’ wages and attempts are being made to improve the economic condition of other artisans.
('81', 98, 3, 11, 157251) Those who sell uncertified khadi are guilty of theft from khadi artisans.
('81', 98, 3, 12, 157325) To purchase such khadi is to acquire stolen property.
('81', 98, 3, 13, 157379) This is atrocious.
('81', 98, 3, 14, 157398) The Charkha Sangh therefore appeals to business people to take up some other trade instead of selling [uncertified] khadi.
('81', 98, 3, 15, 157521) The public should purchase khadi from khadi bhandars of the Charkha Sangh or its certified depots only.
('81', 98, 3, 16, 157625) I hope all khadi lovers will agree that khadi, be it dear or cheap, should be purchased only through the Charkha Sangh and such khadi alone should be recognized as khadi.
('81', 98, 3, 17, 157796) Sevagram, September 18, 1941 [From Hindi] Khadi Jagat, September 1941

('81', 130, 1, 2, 204363) 246. LETTER TO MAGANLAL P. MEHTA
('81', 130, 2, 3, 204396) September 28, 1941
('81', 130, 3, 4, 204415) MAGANLAL, I learnt, by chance, only the day before yesterday about your having failed.
('81', 130, 3, 5, 204502) You have not failed only in one subject.
('81', 130, 3, 6, 204543) This indicates that you lack aptitude for law.
('81', 130, 3, 7, 204590) This is true of many people.
('81', 130, 3, 8, 204619) There have been great men who were deficient in certain capacities.
('81', 130, 3, 9, 204687) Everybody cannot be a mathematician.
('81', 130, 3, 10, 204724) One should follow the path indicated by one’s gifts.
('81', 130, 3, 11, 204777) I would, therefore, urge you to give up your ambition of passing the examination and to devote yourself exclusively to your business.
('81', 130, 3, 12, 204911) Whatever little knowledge of law you have acquired will remain with you.
('81', 130, 3, 13, 204984) I do wish, of course, that you should improve your English.
('81', 130, 3, 14, 205044) But if you are disinclined to that labour, I will not insist on that either.
('81', 130, 3, 15, 205121) I should also like you to be tested thoroughly by an able professor and you should then agree to learn whatever subject he finds you have an aptitude for.
('81', 130, 3, 16, 205276) I wish, too, that you should come here as early as possible and take the children to Rangoon.
('81', 130, 3, 17, 205370) Urmi is pining for Rangoon all the time.
('81', 130, 3, 18, 205411) She has now got tired of Sevagram.
('81', 130, 3, 19, 205446) Appa has not been happy here from the very beginning.
('81', 130, 3, 20, 205500) In these circumstances, the children will not progress.
('81', 130, 3, 21, 205556) From every point of view, therefore, I suggest that you come over here, have a discussion and then go to Rangoon.

('81', 135, 8, 33, 212754) 258. GUARD AGAINST CREDIT
('81', 135, 9, 34, 212780) In this business of khadi, as in any other, I know that we sell on credit to increase the sales but ultimately suffer losses.
('81', 135, 9, 35, 212906) While I was practising law in South Africa I used to examine the accounts of hundreds of businessmen who were my clients.
('81', 135, 9, 36, 213028) They used to provide 25 per cent for bad debts.
('81', 135, 9, 37, 213076) As a result they would charge a very high rate of profit.
('81', 135, 9, 38, 213134) Some of them would go bankrupt.
('81', 135, 9, 39, 213166) My experience of conducting Indian Opinion, Navajivan, Young India and Harijan has shown me that we escaped losses because we never sold on credit.
('81', 136, 0, 1, 213314) VOL. 81 : 18 AUGUST, 1941 8 FEBRUARY, 1942 137
('81', 136, 1, 2, 213361) did this policy adversely affect the number of our subscribers.
('81', 136, 1, 3, 213425) One direct benefit of this policy was that only those subscribed to these periodicals who cared for them.
('81', 136, 1, 4, 213531) There can however be no comparison between khadi and other kinds of business.
('81', 136, 1, 5, 213609) Khadi is an altruistic affair.
('81', 136, 1, 6, 213640) It is conceived as service to the starving millions.
('81', 136, 1, 7, 213693) Then why should we sell khadi on credit?
('81', 136, 1, 8, 213734) My personal conviction therefore is that under no circumstances and to no person should we sell khadi on credit.
('81', 136, 1, 9, 213847) If we firmly followed this policy we shall spare ourselves much unnecessary expenditure and can even bring down the price of khadi.
('81', 136, 1, 10, 213979) And simultaneously we shall be able to give our customers satisfaction.
('81', 136, 1, 11, 214051) It is a general rule of the Charkha Sangh that no bhandar under its jurisdiction shall release goods on credit.
('81', 136, 1, 12, 214163) I am afraid everyone has not been able to observe this rule hundred per cent.
('81', 136, 1, 13, 214241) I submit that mere enunciation of a rule whose importance we cannot appreciate is not much good.
('81', 136, 1, 14, 214338) I hope, therefore, that all khadi workers will clearly understand the policy of not giving credit and then follow it unfailingly.
('81', 136, 1, 15, 214468) [From Hindi] Khadi Jagat, September 1941

('81', 137, 11, 27, 216359) 262. SPEECH AT GOSEVA SANGH MEETING
('81', 137, 12, 28, 216395) NALWADI, September 30, 1941 You should adopt a simple and brief constitution without provision for so many categories of members.
('81', 137, 12, 29, 216525) All the members should be of one category and there should be no patrons at all.
('81', 137, 12, 30, 216606) Those who contribute will do so not for the sake of name.
('81', 137, 12, 31, 216664) Some of them may contribute anonymously and may not even like to disclose their names.
('81', 138, 0, 1, 216751) VOL. 81 : 18 AUGUST, 1941 8 FEBRUARY, 1942 139
('81', 138, 1, 2, 216798) You don’t stand to gain by having various categories of membership.
('81', 138, 1, 3, 216866) The members are not going to have any privileges.
('81', 138, 1, 4, 216916) Our purpose is to render service, not to enjoy privileges.
('81', 138, 1, 5, 216975) Even ten or twenty members capable of rendering concrete service would suffice.
('81', 138, 1, 6, 217055) Every member must be bound by the condition to use only cow’s milk, ghee, etc., and leather made from dead cattle.
('81', 138, 1, 7, 217170) In this no laxity should be permitted.
('81', 138, 1, 8, 217209) A small committee to carry on the work of the society may be formed.
('81', 138, 1, 9, 217278) I formed the opinion, even while in South Africa, that we would have to give up the lure of buffalo’s milk and ghee.
('81', 138, 1, 10, 217395) Cow protection helps protection of the buffalo also.
('81', 138, 1, 11, 217448) It cannot be that everybody would give up buffalo’s milk but there is real danger of people giving up cow’s milk.
('81', 138, 1, 12, 217562) If, therefore, we do not protect the cow, both the buffalo and the cow are sure to be doomed.
('81', 138, 1, 13, 217656) Our fault is—this is a fault found in all men, but more particularly among Indians—that we grab what is easily available and we let go what is difficult to obtain.
('81', 138, 1, 14, 217820) People find khadi, village industries organization and the like inexpensive and convenient.
('81', 138, 1, 15, 217912) They prefer buffalo milk because it is sweet and cheap.
('81', 138, 1, 16, 217968) Since the times of the Vedas we have been glorifying the cow— not the buffalo.
('81', 138, 1, 17, 218047) Had the cow not been so glorified, it would have perished and along with it the buffalo.
('81', 138, 1, 18, 218136) I have studied the comparative figures of the cows and buffaloes in India.
('81', 138, 1, 19, 218211) Both are in plenty but neither of them is making any progress.
('81', 138, 1, 20, 218274) So long as it pays him, the milkman keeps the cow or the buffalo after which he sells them to the butcher.
('81', 138, 1, 21, 218381) The butcher utilizes the proceeds for purchasing more cattle.
('81', 138, 1, 22, 218443) The cow protectionwallahs purchase these cows or buffaloes in order to save them from the butcher’s knife.
('81', 138, 1, 23, 218550) A couple of cows are saved in this manner but it spells disaster for the cow in general.
('81', 138, 1, 24, 218639) The correct remedy, therefore, lies in forgetting the cow already sold and in investing funds for improving the breed, raising its value and in teaching cattle keepers their dharma.
('81', 138, 1, 25, 218821) Let no one fear that the buffalo will become extinct if all give up its milk and ghee.
('81', 138, 1, 26, 218908) As I have already told you this will hardly happen and even if it did there would be no harm.
('81', 138, 1, 27, 219002) The buffalo will return to the jungle.
('81', 138, 1, 28, 219041) What we must protect is the cow and, because the milk of both is useful, the buffalo will also be saved along with the cow.
('81', 138, 1, 29, 219165) But if instead of following the scientific method everybody, in the name of cow protection, sets about acting according to his own fancy, both the cow and the buffalo are sure to he doomed.
('81', 138, 1, 30, 219355) It was mainly owing to our ignorance that so many other things in our country similarly met their doom.
('81', 138, 1, 31, 219459) We can realize our duty towards the
('81', 139, 0, 1, 219495) 140 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('81', 139, 1, 2, 219537) animal world and discharge it by wisely pursuing our dharma of service to the cow.
('81', 139, 1, 3, 219620) At the root of cow protection is the realization of our dharma towards the sub human species.
('81', 139, 1, 4, 219714) But our service to the cow is service only in name and all of us are therefore tending to forget our dharma.
('81', 139, 1, 5, 219823) Statistically speaking, India has one fourth of the world’s cattle population.
('81', 139, 1, 6, 219902) But the plight of our cattle is worse than that of the human population, bad as it is.
('81', 139, 1, 7, 219989) One who serves the cow must take cow’s milk only and not goat’s milk.
('81', 139, 1, 8, 220059) I take goat’s milk out of my helplessness.
('81', 139, 1, 9, 220102) But the members of the Cow protection Society must take only cow’s milk and ghee and use only leather made from dead cows and buffaloes.
('81', 139, 1, 10, 220239) Where even cows and buffaloes are being slaughtered, how can one get leather made from dead goats?
('81', 139, 1, 11, 220338) Mankind has till this day taken it for granted that the goat is born only to be butchered.
('81', 139, 1, 12, 220429) Today being Dussehra, in Calcutta thousands of goats must have been sacrificed to Goddess Kali.
('81', 139, 1, 13, 220525) Ghee should not present any problem for the rich.
('81', 139, 1, 14, 220575) Just as they carry with them some lavender, Eau de Cologne and a toothbrush, similarly they should also have cow’s ghee or else they should not think of cow protection.
('81', 139, 1, 15, 220744) The problem of milk is not as simple as that of ghee.
('81', 139, 1, 16, 220798) In Almora cow’s milk is not available at any cost.
('81', 139, 1, 17, 220849) The same condition prevails in Orissa.
('81', 139, 1, 18, 220888) We can make milk by dissolving mava 1 in water.
('81', 139, 1, 19, 220936) We use Horlicks powder because it is a good thing and easily digestible.
('81', 139, 1, 20, 221009) But why should we not make a similar powder here?
('81', 139, 1, 21, 221059) We should acquire the scientific knowledge and make it locally so that powder milk could be available even at the top of the Himalayas.
('81', 139, 1, 22, 221195) Jamnalal’s health is not so good that he can be allowed to go to jail again.
('81', 139, 1, 23, 221272) If he falls ill after going there I shall not be able to bear it.
('81', 139, 1, 24, 221338) This struggle is going to be a prolonged one.
('81', 139, 1, 25, 221384) When the time comes I shall myself ask him to leave everything and go to jail.
('81', 139, 1, 26, 221463) But today it is my duty not to send him to jail.
('81', 139, 1, 27, 221512) What should be his field of activity then?
('81', 139, 1, 28, 221555) He placed before me a few suggestions such as Harijan [work], khadi, cow protection, etc.
('81', 139, 1, 29, 221645) Of them I liked cow protection.
('81', 139, 1, 30, 221677) He was associated with this work from its inception and whatever work has so far been done has not been wasted.
('81', 139, 1, 31, 221789) It was by and large being conducted according to my own understanding and advice.
('81', 139, 1, 32, 221871) Now it will be run under Jamnalalji’s guidance.
('81', 139, 1, 33, 221919) Cow protection is service to the dumb creation.
('81', 139, 1, 34, 221967) Today Harijans are weak but tomorrow they can become strong and make progress on
('81', 139, 2, 35, 222048) 1 Milk boiled to solid form
('81', 140, 0, 1, 222076) VOL. 81 : 18 AUGUST, 1941 8 FEBRUARY, 1942 141
('81', 140, 1, 2, 222123) their own, for they possess all the human faculties.
('81', 140, 1, 3, 222176) If tomorrow Harijans rise and take possession of temples, I shall dance [for joy].
('81', 140, 1, 4, 222259) But the cow has no such strength.
('81', 140, 1, 5, 222293) She can be strong and healthy only if we feed her.
('81', 140, 1, 6, 222344) She will always be a docile animal.
('81', 140, 1, 7, 222380) You may hit or even kill her, but she cannot revolt against you.
('81', 140, 1, 8, 222445) Who is then going to protect her?
('81', 140, 1, 9, 222479) Jamnalal’s spiritual craving will be satisfied by serving the cow.
('81', 140, 1, 10, 222546) I have, therefore, entrusted this work entirely to him and he will run it with his business instinct as well as his altruistic disposition.
('81', 140, 1, 11, 222686) Cow protection is a stupendous task.
('81', 140, 1, 12, 222723) We will have to study this science in a dispassionate manner.
('81', 140, 1, 13, 222785) We must bring together all those who have studied this subject from the modern scientific angle.
('81', 140, 1, 14, 222882) We should have a band of efficient gosevaks who can go where demanded.
('81', 140, 1, 15, 222953) If Swami Ananda wishes to come he may, though he can carry on the work in Thana itself.
('81', 140, 1, 16, 223041) He should decide about the area of his activity and concentrate his energy there.
('81', 140, 1, 17, 223123) In this way, let us take the map of India and divide it into ten or hundred divisions.
('81', 140, 1, 18, 223210) The person in charge of each division will send in his report.
('81', 140, 1, 19, 223273) There are a number of goshalas in India which should be inspected and run on proper lines.
('81', 140, 1, 20, 223364) If an expert is required anywhere we should be in a position to send one.
('81', 140, 1, 21, 223438) It requires a man of purity to become a servant of the cow.
('81', 140, 1, 22, 223498) A person of ability alone will not do.
('81', 140, 1, 23, 223537) I see no need of touring at present for this work.

('81', 140, 1, 25, 223660) To begin with, from now on we can supply cow’s milk in Wardha itself to those who are prepared to use it.

('81', 143, 7, 10, 227422) 269. LETTER TO SUSHILA NAYYAR October 1, 1941
('81', 143, 8, 11, 227468) SUSHILA, Pyarelal courted arrest today.
('81', 143, 8, 12, 227508) It was a beautiful sight.
('81', 143, 8, 13, 227534) All of us went up to the outskirts of Sevagram.
('81', 143, 8, 14, 227582) Even after that we continued to walk in procession.
('81', 143, 8, 15, 227634) The village people washed his feet at every step, did arati and thus the procession went on to Barbadi.
('81', 143, 8, 16, 227738) Most probably an account of the proceedings will go along with this.

('81', 143, 11, 24, 228157) 270. MESSAGE TO STATES’ PEOPLE
('81', 143, 12, 25, 228188) October 1, 1941 I hold strong and decided views on the relationship between the Princes and the people.
('81', 143, 12, 26, 228292) I am convinced that, in the new world order, which is bound to follow the insensate butchery, dignified by the name of war, the Princes will have place only if they become true servants of
('81', 144, 0, 1, 228481) VOL. 81 : 18 AUGUST, 1941 8 FEBRUARY, 1942 145
('81', 144, 1, 2, 228528) the people, deriving their power not from the sword but from the love and consent of the people.
('81', 144, 1, 3, 228625) Such being my fixed view, I advise the people of the States to cultivate patience and prepare themselves for the responsibilities that will devolve on them, willy nilly, by assiduously doing mute constructive work.
('81', 144, 1, 4, 228840) This does not mean submission to active and acute tyranny, of which I have so many accounts coming to me.
('81', 144, 1, 5, 228946) This the victims must resist in the best manner they can.
('81', 144, 1, 6, 229004) The only best manner I know is the way of non violence, otherwise called conscious and deliberate self suffering.
('81', 144, 1, 7, 229118) But cases of individual torture and degradation have come under my notice.
('81', 144, 1, 8, 229193) If they are true and if the tortured persons do not know the way of non violence, they will resist the tortures with all the violence they can summon from within and die in the attempt to resist the torture and the degradation.
('81', 144, 1, 9, 229421) That violent resistance will almost count as non violence, even as the resistance of a mouse to a ferocious cat will count.
('81', 144, 1, 10, 229545) I have in mind an unarmed man under torture by an armed company of torturers.
('81', 144, 1, 11, 229623) No man, however weak in body, if he has the will to resist and the capacity to die bravely, need feel helpless against odds, however heavy.
('81', 144, 1, 12, 229763) I would like the Princes to accept my claims to be their true friend.
('81', 144, 1, 13, 229833) As such, I would like to tell them that the way to read the signs of the times is to realize the utter helplessness of the sword.
('81', 144, 1, 14, 229963) The Biblical saying is going to prove true sooner than we had expected: “For all they that take the sword shall perish by the sword.” The Hindu, 3 10 1941

('81', 149, 5, 11, 236400) 282. SPEECH AT GANDHI JAYANTI MEETING
('81', 149, 6, 12, 236438) October 2, 1941 However mean or insignificant the work may be, God values it more, provided it is done for service and without any hope of return.
('81', 149, 6, 13, 236585) Thus sweepers’ work is more valuable if it is done selflessly and with the motive of serving.
('81', 149, 7, 14, 236679) Gandhiji appealed to the audience to help in cow protection work, in preserving the cow which was now perishing due to neglect.
('81', 149, 7, 15, 236807) The evil, if not checked, would, he said, result in serious deterioration of the agricultural wealth of the country.
('81', 149, 8, 16, 236924) In conclusion, he appealed to them to develop charkha and spinning.
('81', 149, 8, 17, 236992) I do not value my Jayanti Day, but I call it ‘Charkha Jayanti’.
('81', 149, 9, 18, 237056) Gandhiji told the villagers that he would come every night amongst them for prayer, provided they liked it, as this would establish increased contact with them, but they must be punctual and regular.
('81', 149, 10, 19, 237256) The Hindu, 3 10 1941

('81', 150, 0, 1, 237782) VOL. 81 : 18 AUGUST, 1941 8 FEBRUARY, 1942 151
('81', 150, 1, 2, 237829) 284. STATEMENT IN COURT 1
('81', 150, 2, 3, 237855) SEVAGRAM, October 3, 1941 It is no pleasure for me to appear before this court for the third time except the natural pleasure one derives from the performance of one’s duty.
('81', 150, 2, 4, 238029) But for the peremptory call of duty I should not have reappeared before this court.
('81', 150, 2, 5, 238113) Deep meditation for which jail life provides an ample opportunity has convinced me more than ever of the correctness of the Congress resolution to offer civil disobedience in vindication of the right of free speech to the extent of inviting those who listen to oppose the war in every shape or form.
('81', 150, 2, 6, 238413) The rivers of blood that are daily flowing in this war which is without parallel in barbarity and ferocity should convince even the confirmed sceptic of the utter immorality of the war.
('81', 150, 2, 7, 238599) Except for hypnotism which hardens even the sense of perception, there should not be any difficulty in preceiving the crime against humanity which the present war means.
('81', 150, 2, 8, 238769) It is difficult to strike the balance between the right and the wrong.
('81', 150, 2, 9, 238840) The right can only belong to the party that washes its hands clean of blood guiltiness and dares the aggressor by accepting the law of self–suffering through non violent action to do his worst.
('81', 150, 2, 10, 239034) Though seemingly the Congress fight is in defence of the right to preach against association with all wars or at least this war, it is none the less an effort to convince the world of the immeasurable superiority of non violent action over the violent resistance even in a cause considered just.
('81', 150, 2, 11, 239330) Let no one attribute ineffectiveness to the studied mildness of the Congress action.
('81', 150, 2, 12, 239415) Actions appearing insignificant have led before now to astounding results.
('81', 150, 2, 13, 239490) Those of us who are privileged to take part in the struggle have a living faith that our civil disobedience will lead to a result fraught with the greatest benefit to mankind.
('81', 150, 2, 14, 239666) The Hindustan Times, 4 10 1941
('81', 150, 3, 15, 239697) 1 Drafted by Gandhiji for Pyarelal who filed this after the charge was framed against him for offering individual satyagraha.
('81', 150, 3, 16, 239823) He was awarded 12 months’ simple imprisonment; vide also “Letter to Rammanohar Lohia”, 11 5 1941
