('81', 168, 1, 2, 264283) 320. SPEECH AT A. I. S. A. MEETING
('81', 168, 2, 3, 264318) WARDHA, October 7, 1941 Today I must speak on one or two fundamental questions.
('81', 168, 2, 4, 264398) You must all have read Pandit Jawaharlal’s letter in Khadi Jagat.
('81', 168, 2, 5, 264464) Jawaharlal’s language generally tends to be strong.
('81', 168, 2, 6, 264516) But I feel that this is a good letter.
('81', 168, 2, 7, 264555) We must pay attention to its purport.
('81', 168, 2, 8, 264593) He is discontented.
('81', 168, 2, 9, 264613) He asks why we have not been able to do more work.
('81', 168, 2, 10, 264664) He feels we have not given enough consideration to the matter.
('81', 168, 2, 11, 264727) I would not entirely agree.
('81', 168, 2, 12, 264755) We have been giving consideration to the matter from time to time and even today we are seized of it.
('81', 168, 2, 13, 264857) But I must admit our sadhana, our tapasya, has not been adequate.
('81', 168, 2, 14, 264923) This is the point made by Jawaharlal.
('81', 168, 2, 15, 264961) His very name evokes thoughts of awakening and inspiration.
('81', 168, 2, 16, 265021) Jawaharlal has always recognized the importance of khadi but after he went to jail he has come to feel more acutely on the subject.
('81', 168, 2, 17, 265153) We must give due thought to his letter.
('81', 168, 2, 18, 265193) The news coming in from all sides shows that the demand for khadi has sharply increased.
('81', 168, 2, 19, 265282) It has risen so much that we are not in a position to meet it.
('81', 168, 2, 20, 265345) The demand for charkhas too is so great that we can never cope with it!
('81', 168, 2, 21, 265417) What can we do?
('81', 168, 2, 22, 265433) In many places, the money value of the work, which was a few hundred rupees, is now a few thousand rupees.
('81', 168, 2, 23, 265540) You may have heard that in Ranchi, Bihar, while the sale of khadi at the last Jayanti was of the order of Rs. 600, it has now risen to Rs. 10,000. What I say is that we must go on producing as much khadi as we can.
('81', 168, 2, 24, 265755) We should not let ourselves be deterred by the fear that it might not be sold.
('81', 168, 2, 25, 265834) We must never allow ourselves to think for a moment that khadi cannot be sold.
('81', 168, 2, 26, 265913) Yes, we may not have enough capital to substantially increase the production of khadi.
('81', 168, 2, 27, 266000) In that case we should try to find the capital.
('81', 168, 2, 28, 266048) We must carefully consider what should be our technique of work.
('81', 168, 2, 29, 266113) Someone has written saying that a lot of yarn has piled up with him and asked how he is to get it woven.
('81', 168, 2, 30, 266218) We must have the resources to have such yarn woven or exchanged for khadi.
('81', 168, 2, 31, 266293) We must be able to accept all the yarn that comes and supply in exchange such khadi in such quantities as we can.
('81', 168, 2, 32, 266407) We must also so improve the quality of our yarn that even the least efficient weavers may be able to weave it.
('81', 168, 2, 33, 266518) It is said that we cannot spin any yarn of the strength of mill yarn.
('81', 168, 2, 34, 266588) This is to some extent true.
('81', 168, 2, 35, 266617) But this does not satisfy me.
('81', 168, 2, 36, 266647) May be we cannot compete with mills in the quality of the yarn.
('81', 168, 2, 37, 266711) Even so the difference should not be too great
('81', 169, 0, 1, 266758) 170 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('81', 169, 1, 2, 266800) and it should gradually diminish.
('81', 169, 1, 3, 266834) Today our yarn leaves much room for improvement.
('81', 169, 1, 4, 266883) We have not made the progress that is desired in this field.
('81', 169, 1, 5, 266944) There is much work that we have to do.
('81', 169, 1, 6, 266983) We must discover and show to the people ways of producing good and strong yarn.
('81', 169, 1, 7, 267063) A lot of research into the subject is needed.
('81', 169, 1, 8, 267109) We have not paid sufficient attention to the matter.
('81', 169, 1, 9, 267162) We have been slack.
('81', 169, 1, 10, 267182) We must decentralize our work.
('81', 169, 1, 11, 267213) Yarn should be woven where it is spun.
('81', 169, 1, 12, 267252) We have been able to do so much since middle class people took to spinning Now if they will also take up weaving we can rally the weavers round us and take them forward.
('81', 169, 1, 13, 267422) We should make efforts in this direction also.
('81', 169, 1, 14, 267469) The demand for charkhas is on the increase everywhere.
('81', 169, 1, 15, 267524) This too shows that more and more people are taking to spinning.
('81', 169, 1, 16, 267589) For myself I have decided that we cannot send charkhas to every place from outside.
('81', 169, 1, 17, 267673) They should be manufactured locally.
('81', 169, 1, 18, 267710) I am beginning to think that dhanush takli alone can solve the problem.
('81', 169, 1, 19, 267782) It can be made everywhere.
('81', 169, 1, 20, 267809) The Yeravda charkha has its place and it will remain.
('81', 169, 1, 21, 267863) But it cannot be made everywhere.
('81', 169, 1, 22, 267897) It would be well if we could provide taklis to the millions.
('81', 169, 1, 23, 267958) But the plying of the takli calls for devoting special time, labour and attention.
('81', 169, 1, 24, 268041) It is also possible we may not be able to produce yarn in sufficient quantities on the takli.
('81', 169, 1, 25, 268135) It is not that with the dhanush takli as much yarn can be produced as with any other charkha.
('81', 169, 1, 26, 268229) It is easy to ply and easy to make.
('81', 169, 1, 27, 268265) It can be made even without the aid of a carpenter.
('81', 169, 1, 28, 268317) The making of the spindle for it may present some difficulty but not much.
('81', 169, 1, 29, 268392) For even if a spindle is a little crooked, it can serve in a dhanush takli.
('81', 169, 1, 30, 268468) We can make millions of dhanush taklis in a day.
('81', 169, 1, 31, 268517) I admit I will have a little difficulty in the beginning in making people interested in it even as I had in making them interested in khadi but it will soon be overcome.
('81', 169, 1, 32, 268687) We have to put a spur to the work of attaining self reliance in khadi.
('81', 169, 1, 33, 268758) This can be done only through the dhanush takli.
('81', 169, 1, 34, 268807) I cannot agree with the suggestion that charkhas should be manufactured in a few factories and then sent out to every place from there.
('81', 169, 1, 35, 268943) If we thus centralize the charkha it will be finished.
('81', 169, 1, 36, 268998) Everything connected with the charkha should be made where the spinning is done.
('81', 169, 1, 37, 269079) That is why I have suggested that every home should have a dhanush takli in it.
('81', 169, 1, 38, 269159) Till we have fully gone into the thing we should not indulge in a mere intellectual discussion of the problem.
('81', 169, 1, 39, 269270) Only he has a right to participate in any discussion on the matter who has plied a dhanush takli for nine hours every day for a month.
('81', 169, 1, 40, 269405) He will have a right to express a view.
('81', 169, 1, 41, 269445) I therefore suggest that you should give thought to the dhanush takli.
('81', 169, 1, 42, 269516) But not merely because I am advocating it.
('81', 169, 1, 43, 269559) If your experience refutes my point you should not go merely by
('81', 170, 0, 1, 269623) VOL. 81 : 18 AUGUST, 1941 8 FEBRUARY, 1942 171
('81', 170, 1, 2, 269670) what I say.
('81', 170, 1, 3, 269682) I had spoken of giving spinners a daily wage of eight annas but so far we have not been able to go beyond three annas.
('81', 170, 1, 4, 269801) Supposing we were to have the same experience here?
('81', 170, 1, 5, 269853) This is a matter for research and experiment.
('81', 170, 1, 6, 269899) In the same way we have to think about the yarn.
('81', 170, 1, 7, 269948) We should think of developing the capacity to weave whatever yarn may come to us.
('81', 170, 1, 8, 270030) We must in any case accept the self sufficient yarn.
('81', 170, 1, 9, 270083) The people who bring the yarn should accept the price we can give for it.
('81', 170, 1, 10, 270157) Whether it is in the form of money or khadi we must not refuse to pay.
('81', 170, 1, 11, 270228) If we cannot arrange for yarn thus received to be woven, then we may say in Jawaharlal’s words that our creative faculties have become atrophied— we have lost our ability to think.
('81', 170, 1, 12, 270409) This would be a defeatist attitude.
('81', 170, 1, 13, 270445) We do not want to accept defeat.
('81', 170, 1, 14, 270478) If we cannot take the weavers in our fold nothing will get done.
('81', 170, 1, 15, 270543) But we cannot go by mere faith.
('81', 170, 1, 16, 270575) Today they are using mill yarn.
('81', 170, 1, 17, 270607) We have to change this situation.
('81', 170, 1, 18, 270641) We have to give them handspun yarn.
('81', 170, 1, 19, 270677) My feeling is that the War is not going to end soon.
('81', 170, 1, 20, 270730) No import of cloth will he possible.
('81', 170, 1, 21, 270767) Prices of textiles will also rise.
('81', 170, 1, 22, 270802) Only Indian mills will be manufacturing cloth for use in India.
('81', 170, 1, 23, 270866) A time may come when they will not be able to supply all our requirement.
('81', 170, 1, 24, 270940) Cloth in India will then become scarce.
('81', 170, 1, 25, 270980) In China too such a situation had arisen.
('81', 170, 1, 26, 271022) But the Chinese are a hard working people.
('81', 170, 1, 27, 271065) They started the charkha in every home and in their own way quickly solved the problem.
('81', 170, 1, 28, 271153) Our method will be a little different but the effort required will be as much or more.
('81', 170, 1, 29, 271240) A day may come when people will ask us for cloth.
('81', 170, 1, 30, 271290) It would be a disgrace to tell them that we could not supply it.
('81', 170, 1, 31, 271355) We shall also have to think about cotton.
('81', 170, 1, 32, 271397) It is my firm conviction that if we produce cotton in the manner it should be from the point of view of khadi we shall soon be free of the need for imports.
('81', 170, 1, 33, 271554) If we produce cotton to feed the mills this will not be possible.
('81', 170, 1, 34, 271620) I feel that the principle of producing cotton for mills is opposed to the principle of producing it for khadi.
('81', 170, 1, 35, 271731) The convenience of the mills requires that cotton should be intensively grown in a few areas.
('81', 170, 1, 36, 271825) Their aim will be to see that if cotton growing is too scattered it should be brought together and concentrated in one place.
('81', 170, 1, 37, 271951) But khadi requires that cotton should be grown in every village.
('81', 170, 1, 38, 272016) No village should have to depend on another village for its cotton requirement.
('81', 170, 1, 39, 272096) Khadi cannot afford transport of cotton from one village to another.
('81', 170, 1, 40, 272165) We must immediately pay attention to the question how we can make cotton row in every village.
('81', 170, 1, 41, 272260) Another matter has been placed before me for my consi deration.
('81', 170, 1, 42, 272324) Many of our khadi bhandars are very small.
('81', 170, 1, 43, 272367) The question is
('81', 171, 0, 1, 272383) 172 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('81', 171, 1, 2, 272425) whether in the interest of economy it will not be better that each such bhandar should be looked after by no more than one person.
('81', 171, 1, 3, 272556) What we will have to consider in this connection is whether these bhandars are to remain open for a fixed time or as long as possible.
('81', 171, 1, 4, 272691) If we want to make our lives khadi based we shall have to devise certain rules as regards khadi bhandars.
('81', 171, 1, 5, 272797) The rules will be different for towns and villages.
('81', 171, 1, 6, 272849) For the towns I think we should follow the practice of English shopkeepers.
('81', 171, 1, 7, 272925) They open shops according to their convenience.
('81', 171, 1, 8, 272973) They keep them closed on Sundays.
('81', 171, 1, 9, 273007) They don’t care about the customers.
('81', 171, 1, 10, 273044) Gradually the customers become used to it.
('81', 171, 1, 11, 273087) We also want to establish new habits.
('81', 171, 1, 12, 273125) We should also make certain rules and fix a time for the opening of shops.
('81', 171, 1, 13, 273200) The same consideration should apply to shops in rural areas.
('81', 171, 1, 14, 273261) In South Africa there is one shop for an area of thousands of bighas.
('81', 171, 1, 15, 273331) People come in mule carts to make their purchases.
('81', 171, 1, 16, 273382) Sometimes the shopkeeper is not there, since there only one person to look after the shop.
('81', 171, 1, 17, 273473) But people are used to it.
('81', 171, 1, 18, 273500) Similarly, it is not necessary for us to keep our bhandars open all the time.
('81', 171, 1, 19, 273578) But the matter needs to be considered.
('81', 171, 1, 20, 273617) Thus we shall have to give systematic thought to all these matters.
('81', 171, 1, 21, 273685) We want to make of khadi an integrated way of life.
('81', 171, 1, 22, 273737) We have to deal with artisans, spinners and weavers.
('81', 171, 1, 23, 273790) In the sphere of production our aim is to pay equal wages to all.
('81', 171, 1, 24, 273856) So far we have extorted forced labour from the spinners.
('81', 171, 1, 25, 273913) This doctrine of paying the lowest wage and taking maximum work for it has been taken from the Arthashastra of Kautilya.
('81', 171, 1, 26, 274034) We must change this doctrine for a new one.
('81', 171, 1, 27, 274078) We shall give the same wage to spinners as we give to weavers.
('81', 171, 1, 28, 274141) Those who produce cotton should also prosper.
('81', 171, 1, 29, 274187) And yet we want that the burden on the buyer should be light.
('81', 171, 1, 30, 274249) Thus we wish to create a socialist society.
('81', 171, 1, 31, 274293) The socialism that India can digest will be of this kind.
('81', 171, 1, 32, 274351) It will be the socialism of the poor, but of the well to do poor.
('81', 171, 1, 33, 274417) The ideal of khadi is thus the promotion of a wholly socialistic way of life.
('81', 171, 1, 34, 274495) In brief, we have to give thought to all the processes of khadi— from the growing of cotton to the selling of cloth.
('81', 171, 1, 35, 274612) When we have thus succeeded in bringing about a self sufficient socialist polity we shall no more be at the mercy of foreign markets.
('81', 171, 1, 36, 274746) Our society will be like a self sufficient agriculturist.
('81', 171, 1, 37, 274804) To an agriculturist his land is his capital.
('81', 171, 1, 38, 274849) He eats what the land yields.
('81', 171, 1, 39, 274879) If some year there is a failure of crops he starves.
('81', 171, 1, 40, 274932) He does not beg and he does not plunder.
('81', 171, 1, 41, 274973) That is all I had to say.
('81', 171, 1, 42, 274999) We must pay special attention to
('81', 172, 0, 1, 275032) VOL. 81 : 18 AUGUST, 1941 8 FEBRUARY, 1942 173
('81', 172, 1, 2, 275079) weaving.
('81', 172, 1, 3, 275088) I have always said that just as we insisted that we should be good carders we should also insist that we should become good weavers.
('81', 172, 1, 4, 275221) [From Hind] Khadi Jagat, October 1941

('81', 186, 0, 1, 294954) VOL. 81 : 18 AUGUST, 1941 8 FEBRUARY, 1942 187
('81', 186, 1, 2, 295001) three divisions 1 of Central Provinces.
('81', 186, 1, 3, 295041) I have received two letters from Agra Jail also.
('81', 186, 1, 4, 295090) The prisoners there have spun a good deal of yarn.
('81', 186, 1, 5, 295141) They did not have all the facilities for spinning.
('81', 186, 1, 6, 295192) But after Dhirendra Majumdar had reached the Jail, how could he rest content without making everyone spin?
('81', 186, 1, 7, 295299) He is one of the pillars of the Charkha Sangh.
('81', 186, 1, 8, 295346) He was not expected to go to jail.
('81', 186, 1, 9, 295381) But the Government sometimes becomes over generous.
('81', 186, 1, 10, 295433) It picks up some people without any ostensible reason.
('81', 186, 1, 11, 295488) Shri Maithilisharanji is also there.
('81', 186, 1, 12, 295525) He too was arrested without any good reason.
('81', 186, 1, 13, 295570) He is a famous poet and he has sent me a poem also.
('81', 186, 1, 14, 295622) But today poetry does not flow from his pen; it flows from the yarn that he spins.
('81', 186, 1, 15, 295705) I have sent him today a short reply 2. In that letter, too, I have said that with every round of yarn he and his co prisoners have spun, they have brought swaraj so much the nearer.
('81', 186, 1, 16, 295887) What I wrote to the poet is not mere rhetoric.
('81', 186, 1, 17, 295934) I mean what I say.
('81', 186, 1, 18, 295953) According to my definition, there cannot be true swaraj as long as there is exploitation.
('81', 186, 1, 19, 296043) Mere change from British to Indian rule does not mean swaraj.
('81', 186, 1, 20, 296105) As long as one class dominates over another, as long as the poor remain poor or become poorer, there will be no swaraj.
('81', 186, 1, 21, 296225) In my swaraj the millions will live happily.
('81', 186, 1, 22, 296270) They will get good food, decent house and enough clothing.
('81', 186, 1, 23, 296329) By good food I do not mean that they will eat sweets.
('81', 186, 1, 24, 296383) But everyone must get pure milk, pure ghee and sufficient fruit and vegetables.
('81', 186, 1, 25, 296463) I know I am talking tall because the poor today do not even know what fruit is.
('81', 186, 1, 26, 296543) During the mango season, they get a few mangoes and during the guava season they have a few guavas.
('81', 186, 1, 27, 296643) They do not get any other fruit except these and a few other.
('81', 186, 1, 28, 296705) They do not get even clean and nutritious foodgrain.
('81', 186, 1, 29, 296758) They have to live on rotten rice, coarse grain and dirty salt.
('81', 186, 1, 30, 296821) I wish everyone gets what they call a balanced diet as also a clean and comfortable house.
('81', 186, 1, 31, 296912) This according to me is real freedom.
('81', 186, 1, 32, 296950) I have written those words to Maithilisharanji with this kind of freedom in view.
('81', 186, 1, 33, 297032) We have never produced as much yarn as we have produced this year.
('81', 186, 1, 34, 297099) The reports that I get from the prisons make me dance for joy.
('81', 186, 1, 35, 297162) Maithilisharanji writes to me that in the Agra Jail his Communist companions also join in spinning although they have no respect for my views.
('81', 186, 1, 36, 297305) No one compelled them.
('81', 186, 1, 37, 297328) They started spinning on their own.
('81', 186, 1, 38, 297364) This is the way of ahimsa.
('81', 186, 2, 39, 297391) 1 Nagpur, Berar and Mahakoshal 2 Vide the preceding item.
('81', 187, 0, 1, 297449) 188 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('81', 187, 1, 2, 297491) I have also received reports from the Gujrat (Punjab) jail.
('81', 187, 1, 3, 297551) I am not suggesting that everyone spins.

('81', 187, 1, 20, 298613) They all ask, ‘What will be the outcome of this struggle?
('81', 187, 1, 21, 298671) It is very slow and has no effect on the Government.
('81', 187, 1, 22, 298724) The Government does not seem to care.

('81', 187, 1, 24, 298822) They are not even arrested.
('81', 187, 1, 25, 298850) How can such a struggle be effective?’ They may say what they like, but my feeling is that my fight is going on according to my plan.
('81', 187, 1, 26, 298984) I am satisfied with its momentum.
('81', 187, 1, 27, 299018) At present I do not want to increase it further.
('81', 187, 1, 28, 299067) This does not mean that it will never gain momentum.
('81', 187, 1, 29, 299120) When the occasion demands it will be accelerated.
('81', 187, 1, 30, 299170) But this is not the occasion for it.
('81', 187, 1, 31, 299207) Everything is good or bad in a particular context.
('81', 187, 1, 32, 299258) There are occasions when mere bread is very useful.
('81', 187, 1, 33, 299310) But when it is inopportune even jalebi 1 is harmful.
('81', 187, 1, 34, 299363) So when an opportune time comes, our fight will be intensified.
('81', 187, 1, 35, 299427) Some people expect a miracle this very day.
('81', 187, 1, 36, 299471) In ahimsa there is no scope for such sudden miracles.
('81', 187, 1, 37, 299525) Ahimsa does not admit of sudden spurts.
('81', 187, 1, 38, 299565) But those who will can always see the miracles of ahimsa.
('81', 187, 1, 39, 299623) We watch the sky every day but we see no miracles there.

('81', 187, 1, 41, 299746) They see new miracles every moment.
('81', 187, 1, 42, 299782) And the sky is only a small fragment of Divine Power.
('81', 187, 1, 43, 299836) That Divine Power is also the source of ahimsa which
('81', 187, 2, 44, 299889) 1 A sweetmeat
('81', 188, 0, 1, 299903) VOL. 81 : 18 AUGUST, 1941 8 FEBRUARY, 1942 189
('81', 188, 1, 2, 299950) works according to the Divine Law.
('81', 188, 1, 3, 299985) That Law is so mysterious that even its miraculous effects do not appear to be such.
('81', 188, 1, 4, 300070) They look like a natural course of events.
('81', 188, 1, 5, 300113) Our non violent struggle will also evolve according to the same Law.
('81', 188, 1, 6, 300182) When independence comes through non violence it will blossom forth so naturally that we may never notice the miracle having taken place.
('81', 188, 1, 7, 300319) Some people say that this is the opportunity to pressurize the Government.

('81', 188, 1, 10, 300618) The Congress is a responsible trustworthy organization.
('81', 188, 1, 11, 300674) Its resolutions are serious, sincere and without exaggeration.
('81', 188, 1, 12, 300737) The Bombay Resolution pins its faith on the policy of non violence.
('81', 188, 1, 13, 300805) It has a passage 2 which should keep Congressmen always alert and watchful.
('81', 188, 1, 14, 300881) When the policy of non violence has been so clearly stated in the Bombay Resolution, how can we say that England’s difficulty is our greatest opportunity?
('81', 188, 1, 15, 301036) How can the Congress say that we should give her one more blow when England is herself collapsing?
('81', 188, 1, 16, 301135) And who knows whether England is actually collapsing?
('81', 188, 1, 17, 301189) Outwardly of course it looks like that.
('81', 188, 1, 18, 301229) But I do not believe it.

('81', 188, 1, 20, 301287) During the Boer War also there was an occasion when it appeared that England was almost defeated but the situation took a sudden turn and she came out victorious.
('81', 188, 1, 21, 301450) Today also we do not know who is going to win.
('81', 188, 1, 22, 301497) We do not want any one party to be defeated.
('81', 188, 1, 23, 301542) We wish that all the warring parties should come to terms and live like brothers.
('81', 188, 1, 24, 301624) How can you expect me to say that either Germany or Russia or Britain and America should be defeated?
('81', 188, 1, 25, 301726) I would pray that no one is defeated and they all live like brothers.
('81', 188, 1, 26, 301796) Ahimsa dictates : ‘Consider no one your enemy.
('81', 188, 1, 27, 301843) Love even him who considers you his enemy.’ How can we then think of taking advantage of England’s predicament?
('81', 188, 1, 28, 301955) You may say, ‘Then we are sure to be destroyed.
('81', 188, 1, 29, 302003) We will suffer defeat at the hands of the British.’ This betrays lack of faith.
('81', 188, 2, 30, 302083) 1 Vide “To Satyagrahis”, 2 10 1940.
('81', 188, 3, 31, 302119) 2 Which reads : “They can have no ill will against them (the Britishers), and the spirit of satyagraha forbids the Congress from doing anything with a view to embarass them.”
('81', 189, 0, 1, 302294) 190 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('81', 189, 1, 2, 302336) follower of non violence suffers defeat at no one’s hands.
('81', 189, 1, 3, 302395) I may repeat once again that ‘defeat’ has no place in the dictionary of ahimsa.
('81', 189, 1, 4, 302475) Victory and defeat are the results of violent war.
('81', 189, 1, 5, 302526) In ahimsa there is only victory and nothing else.
('81', 189, 1, 6, 302576) At the moment I cannot tell you how our ahimsa is ultimately going to succeed.
('81', 189, 1, 7, 302655) Not to embarrass Britain does not mean that we should help them.
('81', 189, 1, 8, 302720) They are resorting to violent methods.
('81', 189, 1, 9, 302759) We have to stand firm on our principle of ahimsa.
('81', 189, 1, 10, 302809) This will no doubt create some difficulty for them.
('81', 189, 1, 11, 302861) But we cannot help it.
('81', 189, 1, 12, 302884) How can we give up a principle which is bound to lead to the welfare of the world including that of Britain?
('81', 189, 1, 13, 302993) But if we violate our principle, we shall be guilty of violence.
('81', 189, 1, 14, 303058) I wish you to keep this in mind.
('81', 189, 1, 15, 303091) People ask me, ‘What will be the outcome of this satyagraha?
('81', 189, 1, 16, 303152) All types of people, good, bad and indifferent, have joined it.
('81', 189, 1, 17, 303216) Even cheats and rogues are courting arrest in the name of satyagraha.’ I know there is not a single province where undesirable men have not courted arrest.
('81', 189, 1, 18, 303372) But I also know that there is not a single province where people who measure up to my standards have not gone to jail.
('81', 189, 1, 19, 303491) That is why I have not launched a mass movement.
('81', 189, 1, 20, 303540) If I launch a mass movement, people may perhaps jump into it.
('81', 189, 1, 21, 303602) What will the British do in that case?
('81', 189, 1, 22, 303641) They will enact another Jallianwala Bagh.
('81', 189, 1, 23, 303683) I am not afraid of it, but I do not want to give them an opportunity to do so.
('81', 189, 1, 24, 303762) If we remain strictly non violent and then they force a Jallianwala upon us, I could not care less.
('81', 189, 1, 25, 303862) But I say once again that it will be a good omen for India if even a handful of men whom we know to be true remain steadfast to their pledge.
('81', 189, 1, 26, 304004) That will pave the way for an all out non violent struggle.
('81', 189, 1, 27, 304064) All this needs an element of honesty.
('81', 189, 1, 28, 304102) It is a primary condition.
('81', 189, 1, 29, 304129) Those Congressmen who have to faith in khadi, who decry untouchability in public but observe it in their homes, who, being Hindus, hate the Muslims, or who, being Muslims, hate the non Muslims, do not deserve to be satyagrahis.
('81', 189, 1, 30, 304357) Such persons cannot help our cause even by going to jail.
('81', 189, 1, 31, 304415) They are like thieves and dacoits who also go to jail.
('81', 189, 1, 32, 304470) They are not satyagrahis but only law breakers.
('81', 189, 1, 33, 304518) They cannot produce any wholesome results.
('81', 189, 1, 34, 304561) Why should they go to jail disrupting their homes and forgoing their income?
('81', 189, 1, 35, 304638) We wish that only a handful of satyagrahis should go to jail; but their conduct should be such as to produce a moral effect.
('81', 190, 0, 1, 304763) VOL. 81 : 18 AUGUST, 1941 8 FEBRUARY, 1942 191
('81', 190, 1, 2, 304810) Civil disobedience is a powerful weapon.
('81', 190, 1, 3, 304851) But for employing it, we must fulfil the thirteen point constructive programme 1 which I have outlined.
('81', 190, 1, 4, 304955) Till then this weapon cannot be effective.
('81', 190, 1, 5, 304998) I know that the crores of people in India cannot court arrest.
('81', 190, 1, 6, 305061) Nor is that necessary.
('81', 190, 1, 7, 305084) But it is essential that crores of people should have faith in the constructive programme.
('81', 190, 1, 8, 305175) Khadi is the pivot of the constructive programme.
('81', 190, 1, 9, 305225) It is essential that crores of people should wear khadi; they should not wear foreign or mill made cloth and they should not observe any untouchability.
('81', 190, 1, 10, 305378) If they are not prepared to do even this, how can freedom be won through ahimsa?
('81', 190, 1, 11, 305459) What right do they have to desire freedom, who are not prepared to take even a little trouble?
('81', 190, 1, 12, 305554) If we wish to win swaraj through ahimsa, this is the only way.
('81', 190, 1, 13, 305617) If, however, we wish to use force, then Hitler would point the way.
('81', 190, 1, 14, 305685) There are only two courses open—either Hitler’s, that is, the way of violence, or mine, that is, the way of non violence.
('81', 190, 1, 15, 305807) Hitlerism and Churchillism are in fact the same thing.
('81', 190, 1, 16, 305862) The difference of only one of degree.
('81', 190, 1, 17, 305900) By presenting this yarn and this money to me, you are telling me that you do not want to tread the path of violence.
('81', 190, 1, 18, 306017) It is my belief that a time will come when everyone in India will realize that the only correct course is to follow ahimsa.
('81', 190, 1, 19, 306141) The day is soon arriving for khadi when the entire country will be convinced that any cloth other than khadi must be discarded.
('81', 190, 1, 20, 306269) I shall utilize all the money I have received on the occasion of Khadi Jayanti for encouraging khadi.
('81', 190, 1, 21, 306371) People ask me, ‘Why do you not ulitize this money for Congress work?’ In a way khadi work is also Congress work.
('81', 190, 1, 22, 306484) But it is only the parliamentary programme or the movement against the Government that people regard as Congress work.
('81', 190, 1, 23, 306603) This is a wrong notion.
('81', 190, 1, 24, 306627) This amount will be utilized only for khadi work.
('81', 190, 1, 25, 306677) It is to be considered how this money received from the three divisions of the Central Provinces is to be utilized for the purposes of khadi.
('81', 190, 1, 26, 306819) These three divisions may jointly or separately send schemes for their areas.
('81', 190, 1, 27, 306897) Jajuji 2 will welcome and give them due consideration.
('81', 190, 1, 28, 306952) If we do not accept these schemes, we shall give reasons for rejecting them.
('81', 190, 2, 29, 307029) Many people send yarn to me by post.
('81', 190, 2, 30, 307066) I do not understand why they do so.
('81', 190, 2, 31, 307102) The amount spent on postage is more than the value of the
('81', 190, 3, 32, 307160) 1 Vide “Implications of Constructive Program”, 13 8 1940
('81', 190, 4, 33, 307217) 2 Shrikrishnadas Jaju
('81', 191, 0, 1, 307239) 192 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('81', 191, 1, 2, 307281) I wish people would send me ready made khadi.
('81', 191, 1, 3, 307327) Even from the jail they should send khadi woven out of yarn spun by them.
('81', 191, 1, 4, 307401) Today people ply the charkha.
('81', 191, 1, 5, 307431) But I wish that they learn operating the handloom.
('81', 191, 1, 6, 307482) They should send me woven khadi.
('81', 191, 1, 7, 307515) I do not need khadi for myself.

('81', 191, 1, 10, 307860) As years pass the quality of our yarn should improve.

('81', 191, 1, 13, 308009) It would be enough if just a specimen is sent to me.
('81', 191, 1, 14, 308062) All of us should devote greater energy and talent to khadi work.
('81', 191, 1, 15, 308127) This can be done even in jail.
('81', 191, 1, 16, 308158) Those who have been to prison once have to go there again and again.
('81', 191, 1, 17, 308227) There is no question of going back.
('81', 191, 1, 18, 308263) It does not mean that we shall do so indiscriminately.
('81', 191, 1, 19, 308318) We shall have to use our discretion.
('81', 191, 1, 20, 308355) How can we send to prison again a person whose health has been shattered during imprisonment in spite of the best efforts?
('81', 191, 1, 21, 308478) It will be a kind of violence.
('81', 191, 1, 22, 308509) Some people ask me : ‘Why should the same persons go to jail again and again?
('81', 191, 1, 23, 308587) Why not select new men so that the satyagraha continues without causing much strain?’ I have already said that a non violent war has its own strategy.
('81', 191, 1, 24, 308738) We cannot follow Hitlerian tactics.
('81', 191, 1, 25, 308774) A barbaric war is being fought in Europe with large scale massacres.
('81', 191, 1, 26, 308843) Young, old, even invalids, are being annihilated.
('81', 191, 1, 27, 308893) Even barbaric war demands sacrifices.
('81', 191, 1, 28, 308931) In a non violent war there is no scope for sacrifices on such a gigantic scale.
('81', 191, 1, 29, 309011) Here we seek to employ moral pressure.
('81', 191, 1, 30, 309050) This will entail sacrifices on the part of a select few.
('81', 191, 1, 31, 309107) We have not been called upon to make any great sacrifices till now.
('81', 191, 1, 32, 309175) What are our sacrifices worth if we are not prepared to face even the hardship of prison life time and again?
('81', 191, 1, 33, 309285) There is one other question.
('81', 191, 1, 34, 309314) Should we carry on the struggle within the four walls of the prison?
('81', 191, 1, 35, 309383) Many problems arise there also.
('81', 191, 1, 36, 309415) The matter of A, B and C classes creates much bitterness.
('81', 191, 1, 37, 309473) What should we do there?
('81', 191, 1, 38, 309498) These classes are a creation of Congressmen themselves.
('81', 191, 1, 39, 309554) I am convinced that these classes will ultimately be abolished.
('81', 191, 1, 40, 309618) In the mean time, there is much scope for improvement in the diet of C class prisoners.
('81', 191, 1, 41, 309706) I have already said that doctors can bring about the much

('81', 192, 1, 2, 309812) needed improvement in this matter if they so desire.
('81', 192, 1, 3, 309865) But granting that the doctors cannot do anything, even then this struggle will have to continue.
('81', 192, 1, 4, 309962) The satyagrahis will repeatedly go to prison.
('81', 192, 1, 5, 310008) Prison life will be full of hardships.
('81', 192, 1, 6, 310047) It will mean starvation and even if it causes death in some cases I shall be prepared to face that eventuality.

('81', 218, 0, 1, 344577) VOL. 81 : 18 AUGUST, 1941 8 FEBRUARY, 1942 219
('81', 218, 1, 2, 344624) 400. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('81', 218, 2, 3, 344652) WARDHAGANJ, October 21, 1941 The publication of the statement attributed to Shri Jayaprakash Narayan, which he is stated to have attempted to smuggle from his place of detention, does not, so far as I can see, lead us anywhere.
('81', 218, 2, 4, 344880) 1 If the motive was to discredit the organization of which Jayaprakash Narayan is a distinguished member, it must fail.
('81', 218, 2, 5, 345000) Assuming the correctness of the charge against Jayaprakash Narayan, the method advocated by him is against the policy of truth and non violence adopted by the Congress, and he deserves the severest condemnation.
('81', 218, 2, 6, 345212) But it ill becomes the Government to condemn or discredit it.
('81', 218, 2, 7, 345274) Frankly, all nationalist forces, no matter by what name they are described, are at war with the Government.
('81', 218, 2, 8, 345382) And, according to the accepted canons of war, the method adopted by Jayaprakash Narayan is perfectly legitimate.
('81', 218, 2, 9, 345495) He has had his training in America for seven long years and is a student of the methods adopted by Western nations in their fight for freedom.
('81', 218, 2, 10, 345638) To practise deception, to resort to secret methods and even to plot murder, are all honourable and turn the perpetrators into national heroes.
('81', 218, 2, 11, 345781) Are not Clive and Warren Hastings British heroes?
('81', 218, 2, 12, 345831) If Jayaprakash Narayan was in the British Diplomatic Service and by secret diplomacy achieved something of importance, he would be covered with distinction.
('81', 218, 2, 13, 345988) The sensation with which the event has been disclosed to the Indian world is ill conceived.
('81', 218, 2, 14, 346080) The annotations in the communique are probably wholly unwarranted.
('81', 218, 2, 15, 346147) When it is borne in mind that Jayaprakash Narayan is an untried detenu, the annotations look very like hitting below the belt.
('81', 218, 2, 16, 346274) The Government should have shown Jayaprakash the document or documents seized, and published his answer if he had any to give.
('81', 218, 2, 17, 346401) The way in which his poor wife has been dragged in is unfortunate.
('81', 218, 2, 18, 346468) She knew nothing of the attempt, for it was frustrated
('81', 218, 3, 19, 346523) 1 A communique issued by the Government on October 16 said : “Plans to consolidate the position of the Congress Socialist Party by winning over important members of the terrorist organizations, known as the Revolutionary Socialist Party and the Hindustan Republican Socialist Association and by isolating the Communist Party, were seized from Mr. Jayaprakash Narayan, security prisoner, Deoli Camp, when he attempted to pass them to his wife, Prabhavati Devi, at an interview.”
('81', 219, 0, 1, 347001) 220 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('81', 219, 1, 2, 347043) before anything could reach her.
('81', 219, 1, 3, 347076) I may inform the public that Prabhavati does not share Jayaprakash Narayan’s views.
('81', 219, 1, 4, 347160) She was put under my charge by her parents when she was not yet fifteen and while her husband Jayaprakash was still in America.
('81', 219, 1, 5, 347288) She has wholly accepted my view of Indian politics and is one of my most faithful co workers.
('81', 219, 1, 6, 347382) As husband and wife, Jayaprakash Narayan and Prabhavati Devi are an ideal couple.
('81', 219, 1, 7, 347464) Jayaprakash has never sought to impose his views on Prabhavati.
('81', 219, 1, 8, 347528) He has never prevented her from freely coming to me.
('81', 219, 1, 9, 347581) Indeed, he has encouraged her to come to me whenever she has been ill.
('81', 219, 1, 10, 347652) She has never been taken into the secrets of the Socialist Party.
('81', 219, 1, 11, 347718) The alleged communication has completely upset her, for she never thought that her husband would advocate the method attributed to him.
('81', 219, 1, 12, 347854) The suggestion made in some newspapers that the restrictions on prisoners should be tightened is wholly irrelevant to Jayaprakash Narayan’s attempt.
('81', 219, 1, 13, 348003) That it was frustrated is enough proof of the efficiency of the C. I. D. Even if there is laxity, it can be no warrant for giving them bad or insufficient food, or keeping them in places far away from their homes, making it difficult or expensive for relatives to visit detenus.
('81', 219, 1, 14, 348282) I have read Shri N. M. Joshi’s very careful and over moderate recommendations 1 about the Deoli Camp.
('81', 219, 1, 15, 348384) I have learnt enough about it to enable me to say, in the name of humanity, that the Camp should be disbanded and the prisoners should be sent nearer their homes.
('81', 219, 1, 16, 348547) It is wrong, from every point of view, to bring prisoners from their provinces and concentrate them in a place where there is no facility either of provisions or medical assistance or other amenities of life.

('81', 225, 11, 18, 358722) SEVAGRAM, October 22, 1941 As regards diet, I am quite convinced that the food cooked in the Ashram kitchen would, with slight adjustments, be suitable for the people in Sevagram also.
('81', 225, 11, 19, 358907) The food served at the Khadi Vidyalaya or to C class prisoners would not do.
('81', 225, 11, 20, 358984) The standard of food prepared in our kitchen here would be found suitable.
('81', 225, 11, 21, 359059) In this regard we have taken into consideration the opinions of doctors all over India and we consult them even now.
('81', 225, 11, 22, 359176) At the Ashram we can protect ourselves from a number of diseases.
('81', 225, 11, 23, 359242) Whatever illness persists is due to the fact that all of us are not frugal eaters.

('81', 226, 1, 2, 359549) Everyone must get two 1b.
('81', 226, 1, 3, 359575) of milk, two tolas of ghee and two and a half tolas of butter daily.

('81', 231, 0, 1, 371963) 232 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('81', 231, 1, 2, 372005) 410. AN ERROR The khadi movement, I find, has gone on for more than 21 years.
('81', 231, 1, 3, 372083) But while on the one hand we do not have a sufficient number of weavers, on the other the millions of idle weavers in India do not use our yarn for weaving.
('81', 231, 1, 4, 372240) Is it any error on our part which leads to this double failure?
('81', 231, 1, 5, 372304) I shall try to answer this question today.
('81', 231, 1, 6, 372347) I am of the opinion that this is but the result of our own folly.
('81', 231, 1, 7, 372413) If I were to find fault with anyone in this effort it could be only myself.
('81', 231, 1, 8, 372489) When I placed khadi on such a high pedestal I should have considered all aspects of the problem.
('81', 231, 1, 9, 372586) However, many vital things were first revealed to me in their generality and the finer details were only gradually worked out.
('81', 231, 1, 10, 372713) The fact that spinning involves carding was discovered only through experience.
('81', 231, 1, 11, 372793) The process of ginning cotton came to light only later.
('81', 231, 1, 12, 372849) I knew that the yarn would have to be woven but I had not imagined then that it would be a difficult process.
('81', 231, 1, 13, 372959) Even when I knew it I did not clearly see the solution as I see it now.
('81', 231, 1, 14, 373031) The solution is that khadi workers must learn the process of weaving even as a matter of atonement.
('81', 231, 1, 15, 373131) The best of our spinners have come from the same class.
('81', 231, 1, 16, 373187) That is how we could make good progress in spinning.
('81', 231, 1, 17, 373240) In the same manner we should have made weaving compulsory for the khadi workers.
('81', 231, 1, 18, 373321) When we learn this art we shall fully understand the weavers’ difficulties in using hand spun yarn.
('81', 231, 1, 19, 373421) Only then can we find a remedy for the difficulties and the professional weavers will follow us in using hand spun yarn.
('81', 231, 1, 20, 373542) Not that I had never thought of this.
('81', 231, 1, 21, 373580) The work of weaving hand spun yarn was first started long ago by the late Maganlal Gandhi and by Manilal Gandhi.
('81', 231, 1, 22, 373693) But I did not insist that everyone or certain people must weave, as I used to insist that they must spin.
('81', 231, 1, 23, 373799) As a result of this error the process of weaving has not been as widely taken up by khadi workers as it should have been.
('81', 231, 1, 24, 373921) I am of the opinion that one among every five, seven or ten spinners must become a good weaver.
('81', 231, 1, 25, 374017) Weaving cannot be done by one man.
('81', 231, 1, 26, 374052) One needs a companion for fixing the warp and for sizing.
('81', 231, 1, 27, 374110) One also needs the help of a boy or a girl to load the shuttle.
('81', 231, 1, 28, 374174) Any one can handle these processes as also the actual weaving on the loom.
('81', 231, 1, 29, 374249) But what I propose is that a certain proportion should become experts.
('81', 231, 1, 30, 374320) This will lead to great progress.
('81', 231, 1, 31, 374354) It is not necessary to tell me that this is already the practice at some centres.
('81', 231, 1, 32, 374436) My complaint is that I have not systematically insisted that one loom must operate where there are, say, five, seven or ten spinners.
('81', 231, 1, 33, 374570) Had I so insisted I would have got
('81', 232, 0, 1, 374605) VOL. 81 : 18 AUGUST, 1941 8 FEBRUARY, 1942 233
('81', 232, 1, 2, 374652) today not yarn but woven goods.
('81', 232, 1, 3, 374684) The large number of satyagrahis in the prisons would not have been content with merely plying the charkha but would have had a loom and woven their yarn.
('81', 232, 1, 4, 374838) Weaving includes tapes, webbing, towels and coarse khadi as well as the fine dhotis or saris from Andhra with elaborately woven patterns.
('81', 232, 1, 5, 374976) When the processes of weaving all these items are present in our minds we shall not waste a single stretch of yarn.
('81', 232, 1, 6, 375092) We shall classify the different varieties of yarn, and weave them into appropriate cloth.
('81', 232, 1, 7, 375182) This error has also led to a lot of waste.
('81', 232, 1, 8, 375225) We used to throw away broken yarn as so much waste.
('81', 232, 1, 9, 375277) I know that many of the basic schools have begun taking care to avoid such waste.
('81', 232, 1, 10, 375359) We have to spread this knowledge.
('81', 232, 1, 11, 375393) This is just the beginning of basic education.
('81', 232, 1, 12, 375440) In fact it is the primary function of basic education to give thought to these problems, to investigate them scientifically and to suggest reform accordingly.
('81', 232, 1, 13, 375599) The most unfortunate result of this error has been our failure to enlist every weaver for our movement.
('81', 232, 1, 14, 375703) Why can we not approach the weaver with hand spun yarn instead of mill made yarn?
('81', 232, 1, 15, 375785) If we acknowledge our error and atone for it, there would be such a great improvement in hand spun yarn that it could compete with mill made yarn.
('81', 232, 1, 16, 375932) Perhaps it may not be possible to spin by hand as fine yarn as the mills can produce.
('81', 232, 1, 17, 376018) However, there need not be this vast difference between the two and the weaver need not have scorn on his face, as he now has, at the sight of hand spun yarn.

('81', 243, 7, 13, 389653) 434. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('81', 243, 8, 14, 389681) SEVAGRAM, October 28, 1941 I have been chary of issuing statements for the guidance of satyagrahis.
('81', 243, 8, 15, 389781) The deciding reason has been to have them to be self guided where they are not guided by local leaders.
('81', 243, 8, 16, 389885) But this chariness can easily be overdone.
('81', 243, 8, 17, 389928) Time seems to have arrived for a brief review especially as several leaders who have been discharged have met me and there has been much speculation about the trend or the result of these talks.
('81', 243, 8, 18, 390123) The public should know that those who were not whole heartedly with the Bombay Resolution 2 have come out with their doubts confirmed.
('81', 243, 8, 19, 390258) Similarly those who never had any doubts have become firmer than ever before in their opinion.
('81', 243, 8, 20, 390353) As for me I never had any doubt as to the correctness of the Bombay Resolution and have none about the correctness of the steps hitherto taken in pursuance thereof.
('81', 243, 8, 21, 390518) If I had, I could not, would not, have led a fight involving not only the fate of the Congress but even of the nation as a whole.
('81', 243, 8, 22, 390648) There is one saving grace in non violent action.
('81', 243, 8, 23, 390697) Unlike violent action, it being good in itself can never do real harm.
('81', 243, 9, 24, 390768) 1 Vide “Statement to the Press”, 28 10 1941. 2 Vide “All India Congress Committee Resolution”, 22 9 1940.
('81', 244, 0, 1, 390874) VOL. 81 : 18 AUGUST, 1941 8 FEBRUARY, 1942 245
('81', 244, 1, 2, 390921) Complaints reach me (1) that there is marked deterioration in enthusiasm; (2) that fewer people are coming forward now than before; (3) that those who are discharged are not seeking impriso nment again; (4) that there is no discipline among many satyagrahi prisoners some of whom have no notion of non violence or truth; (5) that the treatment of C class prisoners is inhuman in that the food given is bad in quality and deficient in balance.
('81', 244, 1, 3, 391364) The result is that the majority of prisoners have suffered in health, making it impossible for many on discharge to seek imprisonment again without adequate rest and repair.
('81', 244, 1, 4, 391538) There are too complaints about want of newspapers, books and proper sanitation; (6) that the policy of non embarrassment is unintelligible, as the Rulers themselves do not appreciate it, and the fight therefore should be intensified without regard to embarrassment; (7) that there is no life left in the Congress—there are no meetings, there are no demonstrations, no other activity, and that there should be a change of policy and programme even resulting in the resumption of full parliamentary programme, including ministries, i.e., reversion to the Poona offer 1 with suitable modification.
('81', 244, 1, 5, 392133) (1 & 2) I shall consider the first two together.
('81', 244, 1, 6, 392182) Enthusiasm that is froth is of no use in non violent action.
('81', 244, 1, 7, 392243) Showy demonstrations and the like have a value in the initial stages.
('81', 244, 1, 8, 392313) Continuous feverish activity can only promote violence and therefore retard the steady march of non violent action, call it battle, if that word is preferred.
('81', 244, 1, 9, 392472) That fewer are coming forward is but natural.
('81', 244, 1, 10, 392518) For it must be recalled that civil disobedience is individual and restricted to representatives, be they even elected members of village or firka 2 committee.
('81', 244, 1, 11, 392677) The list of representatives being limited it must one day be exhausted.
('81', 244, 1, 12, 392749) I have no doubt that if I made a general call and relaxed the conditions of enrollment I should be overwhelmed by applications.
('81', 244, 1, 13, 392877) I have no machinery to examine such applications.
('81', 244, 1, 14, 392927) In reality it will be mass action which does not admit of individual examination and choice.
('81', 244, 1, 15, 393020) That call will not come before the close of the war.
('81', 244, 1, 16, 393073) There is neither warrant nor atmosphere for mass action.
('81', 244, 1, 17, 393130) That would be naked embarrassment and a betrayal of non violence.
('81', 244, 1, 18, 393196) What is more it can
('81', 244, 2, 19, 393216) 1 The reference is to the A.I.C.C. resolution passed at Poona on July 28, 1940; vide “Statement to the Press”, 15 6 1941.
('81', 244, 3, 20, 393338) 2 Group
('81', 245, 0, 1, 393346) 246 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('81', 245, 1, 2, 393388) never lead to independence.
('81', 245, 1, 3, 393416) Mass action at this stage without communal unity is an invitation to civil war.
('81', 245, 1, 4, 393496) If civil war is to be our lot, it will come, but if I know the Congress mind, it will never come at the wish or invitation of the Congress.
('81', 245, 1, 5, 393636) (3) This complaint is partially valid.
('81', 245, 1, 6, 393675) It is true that some of those who have been discharged are reluctant to go back.
('81', 245, 1, 7, 393756) This is a novel experience for India.
('81', 245, 1, 8, 393794) I had to do it in South Africa.
('81', 245, 1, 9, 393826) The struggle demanded it there as it now does here.
('81', 245, 1, 10, 393878) Self suffering has no limit.
('81', 245, 1, 11, 393907) In the former civil disobedience the occasion had not come to send the same resisters to jail again and again.
('81', 245, 1, 12, 394018) In the present one it is inevitable.
('81', 245, 1, 13, 394055) Any other course would reduce the struggle to a farce.
('81', 245, 1, 14, 394110) The alternative suggested is that substitutes should be found for those who would not go in again.
('81', 245, 1, 15, 394209) Surely that is not the way of suffering.
('81', 245, 1, 16, 394250) And how can we think of gaining independence without a full measure of suffering?
('81', 245, 1, 17, 394332) The greater the cause the richer the suffering.
('81', 245, 1, 18, 394380) Therefore in this struggle they only will count who will seek imprisonment again and again, come what will.
('81', 245, 1, 19, 394488) They may be very few.
('81', 245, 1, 20, 394510) That will not matter.
('81', 245, 1, 21, 394532) Of course those who are ill will naturally not be required to go till they are restored.
('81', 245, 1, 22, 394621) Some have interpreted literally my statement 1
('81', 245, 2, 23, 394668) that the discharged satyagrahis may take about a week before they go.
('81', 245, 2, 24, 394738) Each case has to be judged on merits.
('81', 245, 2, 25, 394776) Shri Vinoba went in twice within 72 hours of his discharge.
('81', 245, 2, 26, 394836) He had to come to me before reoffering civil disobedience.
('81', 245, 2, 27, 394895) Hence even that little delay.
('81', 245, 2, 28, 394925) Shri Pyarelal took nearly a month before going in for the third time.
('81', 245, 2, 29, 394995) There were unavoidable causes which need not occupy the reader’s time and attention.
('81', 245, 2, 30, 395080) I have mentioned two cases which I was personally regulating.
('81', 245, 2, 31, 395142) They exemplify the elasticity I refer to.
('81', 245, 2, 32, 395184) There is no shame or harm in unavoidable delay.
('81', 245, 2, 33, 395232) Hypocrisy and camouflage must be avoided at all cost.
('81', 245, 2, 34, 395286) In satyagraha there is no waste of men or time or labour, provided that Satya is adhered to in its entirety.
('81', 245, 2, 35, 395395) I can otherwise utilize the services, as true soldiers of truth, of men and women who will whole heartedly carry out instructions.
('81', 245, 2, 36, 395526) Thus those who cannot for some just reason court imprisonment should engage themselves in corporate constructive activity.
('81', 245, 2, 37, 395649) Difficulty arises because many Congressmen, though they profess or believe in C. D., have no
('81', 245, 3, 38, 395742) 1 Vide “Discussion with D. K. Gosavi”, 15 5 1941.
('81', 246, 0, 1, 395792) VOL. 81 : 18 AUGUST, 1941 8 FEBRUARY, 1942 247
('81', 246, 1, 2, 395839) faith in the constructive programme.
('81', 246, 1, 3, 395876) I must proclaim from the housetop for the thousandth time that constructive programme is an integral part of the national movement and therefore also of C. D. C. D. without the backing of the constructive programme is criminal and a waste of effort.
('81', 246, 1, 4, 396126) All cannot go to jail.
('81', 246, 1, 5, 396149) But all must work the constructive programme.
('81', 246, 1, 6, 396195) Even in armed conflict armies are power fully helped by the civil population.
('81', 246, 1, 7, 396273) Imagine the fate of the British forces, if their effort was not co ordinated with that of the civilians.
('81', 246, 1, 8, 396378) I was therefore delighted that there was a wide response from the prisoners and the other Congressmen this time in the matter of spinning during the spinning carnival 1. I dare to believe that if Congressmen were enthusiastic believers in communal unity and removal of untouchability and the like, there would be no communal discord and there would be no antagonism such as it is from Harijans.
('81', 246, 1, 9, 396773) We are the makers of our own destiny.
('81', 246, 1, 10, 396811) It has been somewhat justly said that if I am a good General, I must not grumble about my men.
('81', 246, 1, 11, 396906) For I must choose them from the material at my disposal.
('81', 246, 1, 12, 396963) I plead guilty.
('81', 246, 1, 13, 396979) But I have qualified my admission by the adverb ‘somewhat’, for I laid down the conditions from the very inception of the programme of non violence.
('81', 246, 1, 14, 397128) My terms were accepted.
('81', 246, 1, 15, 397152) If from experience it is found that the terms cannot be worked, I must either be dismissed or I must retire.
('81', 246, 1, 16, 397261) I retired 2 but to no purpose.
('81', 246, 1, 17, 397292) The bond between Congressmen and me seems to be unbreakable.
('81', 246, 1, 18, 397353) They may quarrel with my conditions but they will not leave me or let me go.
('81', 246, 1, 19, 397430) They know that however unskilled a servant I may be, I will neither desert them nor fail them in the hour of need.
('81', 246, 1, 20, 397545) And so they try, though often grumblingly, to fulfil my conditions.
('81', 246, 1, 21, 397613) I must then on the one hand adhere to my conditions so long as I have a living faith in them and, on the other, take what I can get from Congressmen, expecting that if I am true, they will some day fulfil all my conditions and find themselves in the enjoyment of full independence such as has never before been seen on earth.
('81', 246, 1, 22, 397939) (4) There are two sides to the complaint about indiscipline.
('81', 246, 1, 23, 398000) I must here confine myself to satyagrahi prisoners only.
('81', 246, 1, 24, 398057) I would naturally like the other political prisoners to attend to what I say.
('81', 246, 2, 25, 398135) 1 Ceremonial spinning during Gandhi Jayanti week 2 In October 1934
('81', 247, 0, 1, 398202) 248 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('81', 247, 1, 2, 398244) wrong to say that there is universal indiscipline among Congressmen or that all are unfit to be called satyagrahis.
('81', 247, 1, 3, 398360) Cases of grave indiscipline have been brought to my notice.
('81', 247, 1, 4, 398420) I know that violent men have crept into the organization under the guise of non violence.
('81', 247, 1, 5, 398510) But I know also cases of exemplary discipline.
('81', 247, 1, 6, 398557) Everybody knows that there are in the movement and among the prisoners faithful Congressmen.
('81', 247, 1, 7, 398650) I am conducting the struggle in their name and for their sake.
('81', 247, 1, 8, 398713) It is through them that we may expect to win.
('81', 247, 1, 9, 398759) This should mean no reflection on those who are weak but true.
('81', 247, 1, 10, 398822) Even a child of seven who performs its allotted task faithfully will be entitled to the same credit as those who may cheerfully mount the gallows, if thereto called.
('81', 247, 2, 11, 398988) What is happening now is a process of automatic selection.
('81', 247, 2, 12, 399047) Those who cannot stand the test will stay out without dishonour.
('81', 247, 2, 13, 399112) Hypocrites and smugglers will be cast out because they will not stand the real heat or they will be rejected when found out.
('81', 247, 3, 14, 399237) (5) C class prisoners’ is almost a baffling question.
('81', 247, 3, 15, 399291) I have said more than once that classification is bad in itself.
('81', 247, 3, 16, 399356) But the Congress has come to no decision on the question.
('81', 247, 3, 17, 399414) Meanwhile we must do the best we can.
('81', 247, 3, 18, 399452) There is no manner of doubt in my mind that the treatment of C class prisoners is unhuman.
('81', 247, 3, 19, 399543) I do not wish to blame either the Government or the prison officials.
('81', 247, 3, 20, 399613) I admit that theirs is a thankless task.
('81', 247, 3, 21, 399654) For ages almost they have been used to only one tradition.
('81', 247, 3, 22, 399713) Their mind refuses to grasp the distinction between criminals and political prisoners.
('81', 247, 3, 23, 399800) They would make no distinction between prisoners guilty of crimes and those who rebel against constituted authority.
('81', 247, 3, 24, 399917) For them the political are worse than the others.
('81', 247, 3, 25, 399967) But pressure of public opinion has compelled distinction.
('81', 247, 3, 26, 400025) The result is highly unsatisfactory.
('81', 247, 3, 27, 400062) The will on the part of the officials is lacking.
('81', 247, 3, 28, 400112) Satyagrahis who seek imprisonment cannot with any dignity quarrel with the treatment they get, except when their honour is attacked.
('81', 247, 3, 29, 400245) An irresponsible government, which the British Government in India is may, as it often does, defy public opinion.
('81', 247, 3, 30, 400359) Satyagrahis have still to court imprisonment.
('81', 247, 3, 31, 400405) It is one of the gateways to liberty.
('81', 247, 3, 32, 400443) They cannot stipulate as to the conditions of jail life.
('81', 247, 3, 33, 400500) But weak as public opinion is, it can express itself with effect on a matter of pure humanity.
('81', 247, 3, 34, 400595) I have suggested that medical men should
('81', 248, 0, 1, 400636) VOL. 81 : 18 AUGUST, 1941 8 FEBRUARY, 1942 249
('81', 248, 1, 2, 400683) give the lead in this matter.
('81', 248, 1, 3, 400713) I understand that a movement on their part is quite likely.
('81', 248, 1, 4, 400773) It is cruel to distinguish between the food of the different classes.
('81', 248, 1, 5, 400843) The needs in the majority of cases of the political prisoners are identical.
('81', 248, 1, 6, 400920) I suggest that the rations of all political prisoners should approach what is known as balanced diet with the permission to replenish it at the prisoner’s expense.
('81', 248, 1, 7, 401084) As to sanitation and other matters, a non official medical committee should make recommendations which should be given effect to at once.
('81', 248, 1, 8, 401222) There should be identity of treatment in all the provinces.
('81', 248, 1, 9, 401282) Having said this, I must warn satyagrahis against hunger strikes or the like.
('81', 248, 1, 10, 401360) It is their duty to conform to the jail regulations in so far as they do not come in conflict with known rules of honour, not self made ones by hyper sensitive temperaments.
('81', 248, 1, 11, 401534) These ought not to court imprisonment.
('81', 248, 1, 12, 401573) I suggest that it is a satyagrahi’s first code of honour that he will conscientiously carry out jail discipline with the reservation just mentioned.
('81', 248, 1, 13, 401722) Satyagraha is a process of silent conversion.
('81', 248, 1, 14, 401768) Indiscipline and nagging are wholly inconsistent with the ambition of conversion.
('81', 248, 1, 15, 401850) I am repeating these views of mine not without fear and trembling.
('81', 248, 1, 16, 401917) For I know that jail officials have often quoted them on wrong occasions against satyagrahi prisoners.
('81', 248, 1, 17, 402020) Of course in all I have said there is nothing against carrying out constitutional agitation for jail reforms even as to the so called criminals.
('81', 248, 1, 18, 402165) A satyagrahi is a universal reformer.
('81', 248, 1, 19, 402203) For him there is no distinction between criminals and non criminals.
('81', 248, 1, 20, 402272) He is out to render service to the whole of humanity to the extent of his ability and opportunity.
('81', 248, 1, 21, 402371) There is the question of newspapers and books.
('81', 248, 1, 22, 402418) These are as important as food.
('81', 248, 1, 23, 402450) Some would do without food but not without newspapers and literature.
('81', 248, 1, 24, 402520) I hold that deprivation of this amenity is additional punishment for a political prisoner.
('81', 248, 1, 25, 402611) (6) Although I have dealt with the question of non embarra ssment in my previous statements, I see that it still continues to agitate many Congressmen.
('81', 248, 1, 26, 402763) For one thing, it is part of the Bombay Resolution and effect should be given to it.
('81', 248, 1, 27, 402848) It is inherent in non violence.
('81', 248, 1, 28, 402880) But it is also expedient.
('81', 248, 1, 29, 402906) By causing embarrassment at this stage, the authorities must resent it bitterly and are likely to act madly.
('81', 248, 1, 30, 403015) Of course it would be different if we had resorted to armed rebellion.
('81', 249, 0, 1, 403086) 250 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('81', 249, 1, 2, 403128) Then the saying ‘their difficulty becomes our opportunity’ would apply.
('81', 249, 1, 3, 403200) It is obvious that exactly the opposite rule should apply when an opposite method is adopted.
('81', 249, 1, 4, 403294) It is worse than suicide to resort to violence, i.e., embarrassment under cover of non violence.
('81', 249, 1, 5, 403391) We may not be “temperate and furious” at the same time.
('81', 249, 1, 6, 403447) ‘But then to be logical you must give up C. D. altogether’, says the critic.
('81', 249, 1, 7, 403524) To give up C. D. would be folly.
('81', 249, 1, 8, 403557) C. D. is itself completely non violent action.
('81', 249, 1, 9, 403604) It is a duty in the face of violence without parallel.
('81', 249, 1, 10, 403659) C. D. in the present case means assertion of the right to speak against participation in this war or all war.
('81', 249, 1, 11, 403769) If we cannot do even this much when the occasion demands it, we might as well give up non violence.
('81', 249, 1, 12, 403869) C. D. is the assertion of a right which law should give but it denies.
('81', 249, 1, 13, 403940) If performance of a duty causes embarrassment, it cannot be helped.
('81', 249, 1, 14, 404008) It is my duty to give up drink.
('81', 249, 1, 15, 404040) It would cause some loss to the tavern keeper.
('81', 249, 1, 16, 404087) I am helpless.
('81', 249, 1, 17, 404102) The authority can easily avoid embarrassment by recognizing the elementary right of non violent free speech.
('81', 249, 1, 18, 404211) Consideration whether the policy of self imposed restraint creates an immediate impression on the authority is irrelevant.
('81', 249, 1, 19, 404334) Belief that it must ultimately is inherent in belief is non violence itself.
('81', 249, 1, 20, 404411) We may not bear ill will against the bitterest opponent.
('81', 249, 1, 21, 404468) (7) I do not share the belief that there is no life left in the Congress.
('81', 249, 1, 22, 404542) “Still waters run deep.” Congressmen are too much attached to the Congress to let the institution die of inanity.
('81', 249, 1, 23, 404656) There seems to be no life because we have no spectacular show in the shape of parliamentary programme or mass C. D. Things are going according to plan.
('81', 249, 1, 24, 404808) C. D. is restricted to select individuals.
('81', 249, 1, 25, 404851) It will be further restricted to those who reoffer C.D. as often as necessary.
('81', 249, 1, 26, 404930) It does not matter if the number is reduced to ten or two.
('81', 249, 1, 27, 404989) The two will represent the whole Congress.
('81', 249, 1, 28, 405032) Does not one ambassador represent his people?
('81', 249, 1, 29, 405078) One can be multiplied infinitely.
('81', 249, 1, 30, 405112) Parliamentary activity has been almost stopped also according to plan.
('81', 249, 1, 31, 405183) It may be, in my opinion should be, stopped completely.
('81', 249, 1, 32, 405239) But I do not wish to rush things.
('81', 249, 1, 33, 405273) Members of local boards have in many cases been withdrawn according to plan.
('81', 249, 1, 34, 405350) Then what are the Congressmen to do if they cannot or will not be allowed to offer C. D. and there is no parliamentary programme?
('81', 249, 1, 35, 405480) The answer is simple.
('81', 249, 1, 36, 405502) There are only two things for Congressmen to
('81', 250, 0, 1, 405547) VOL. 81 : 18 AUGUST, 1941 8 FEBRUARY, 1942 251
('81', 250, 1, 2, 405594) All to carry on the thirteenfold constructive programme and some select few to offer C.D. in addition.
('81', 250, 1, 3, 405697) C.D. is a mighty weapon to be wielded effectively by only a few in the first instance.
('81', 250, 1, 4, 405784) Constructive programme is to be worked by all Congressmen and even non Congressmen if they will.
('81', 250, 1, 5, 405881) How can people shut their eyes to its paramount importance?
('81', 250, 1, 6, 405941) Even parliamentary programme without it is a mere farce.
('81', 250, 1, 7, 405998) We have had it till 1920. I do not deny its usefulness even as a farce is useful.
('81', 250, 1, 8, 406080) But there is no such thing as a farce without the backing of a play.
('81', 250, 1, 9, 406149) In 1920 the nation came into its own.
('81', 250, 1, 10, 406187) Constructive programme was described in so many words to be a preparation for C. D. Parliamentary programme was given up in toto.
('81', 250, 1, 11, 406317) The nation lost nothing by it.
('81', 250, 1, 12, 406348) Parliamentary programme will have its definite place when we have a parliament of our own.

('81', 250, 1, 15, 406589) If we do not find ourselves free at the end of the war, resumption will be a certainty.
('81', 250, 1, 16, 406677) But that is idle speculation.
('81', 250, 1, 17, 406707) If we do our present duty, whatever the circumstances that face us at the end of the war we shall be found ready.
('81', 250, 1, 18, 406821) Let me glance at the constructive programme.
('81', 250, 1, 19, 406866) There is communal unity.
('81', 250, 1, 20, 406891) It is worth much more than the whole parliamentary programme.
('81', 250, 1, 21, 406953) Without it, the latter is useless.
('81', 250, 1, 22, 406988) It becomes a field for interminable wrangling.
('81', 250, 1, 23, 407035) Complete heart unity takes us almost straightway to independence.
('81', 250, 1, 24, 407101) Let me not be told that there will be no unity at all or not in our lifetime.
('81', 250, 1, 25, 407179) I must refuse to believe the negation so long as there are some Congressmen working for unity.
('81', 250, 1, 26, 407274) If the Congress cannot, I know that no other institution can.
('81', 250, 1, 27, 407336) For every Congressman whatever his faith must equally represent in his own person every Indian, no matter what his faith is.
('81', 250, 1, 28, 407461) In that sense he belongs to all religions.
('81', 250, 1, 29, 407504) Then take untouchability.
('81', 250, 1, 30, 407530) I repeat that if untouchability lives, Hinduism and with it India dies.
('81', 250, 1, 31, 407602) Is that not a programme worth living for, dying for?
('81', 250, 1, 32, 407655) And the spinning wheel whose every turn brings India nearer her destiny?
('81', 250, 1, 33, 407728) Surely it can fully occupy every day of every Congressman.
('81', 250, 1, 34, 407787) And the wheel being the centre of our solar system it includes all the planets in the shape of village industries.
('81', 250, 1, 35, 407902) The wheel brings us at once to the emancipation of India’s
('81', 251, 0, 1, 407961) 252 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('81', 251, 1, 2, 408003) manhood, kisans, labourers and all those who are weary and heavy laden.
('81', 251, 1, 3, 408075) If this all inclusive and mighty programme is not understood and appreciated by Congressmen they do not know the A B C of non violence nor do they know the elements of C.D. This programme gives ample scope for public meetings, demonstrations, exhibitions and the like.
('81', 251, 1, 4, 408344) No official Congress Committees need function for co ordinating these activities.

('81', 251, 1, 6, 408514) Congress will now see why I contemplate no change in the programme as it is going and why I am full of hope for the future of the country.

('81', 257, 7, 15, 415642) 449. INTERVIEW TO THE PRESS
('81', 257, 8, 16, 415670) WARDHAGANJ, October 30, 1941
('81', 257, 9, 17, 415699) Asked for his reaction to the hunger strike by detenus 1 in Deoli Camp Jail and
('81', 257, 10, 18, 415779) the Government communique thereon, Mahatma Gandhi said : The communique was unfortunate.
('81', 257, 10, 19, 415868) I am generally averse to hunger strikes by prisoners but I cannot help recognizing that at times they have no other honourable recourse for the redress of grievances.
('81', 257, 10, 20, 416035) It is cruel for the Government to say that they will not consider grievances unless the strike is given up.
('81', 257, 10, 21, 416143) It is tantamount to saying that the sufferers should not suffer for the redress of wrongs done to them.
('81', 257, 10, 22, 416247) I should have thought a responsive Government would all the more readily listen to appeals of the wronged when they are accompanied by self inflicted suffering.
('81', 257, 10, 23, 416408) If the demands are just, and they seem to be just according to Sri N. M. Joshi’s report, justice should be expedited in order to alleviate avoidable suffering The Hindu, 1 11 1941
('81', 257, 11, 24, 416588) 1 Two hundred and four detenus were on hunger strike.

('81', 259, 10, 22, 418785) 454. WHAT JESUS MEANS TO ME 1
('81', 259, 11, 23, 418815) Although I have devoted a large part of my life to the study of religion and to discussion with religious leaders of all faiths, I know very well that I cannot but seem presumptuous in writing about Jesus Christ and trying to explain what He means to me.
('81', 259, 11, 24, 419070) I do so only because my Christian friends have told me on more than a few occasions that for the very reason that I am not a Christian and that (I
('81', 259, 12, 25, 419217) 1 The source reproduced this from Inner Culture.
('81', 259, 12, 26, 419266) The date of the writing, however, is not available.
('81', 260, 0, 1, 419318) VOL. 81 : 18 AUGUST, 1941 8 FEBRUARY, 1942 261
('81', 260, 1, 2, 419365) shall quote their words exactly) “I do not accept Christ in the bottom of my heart as the only Son of God”, it is impossible for me to understand the profound significance of His teachings, or to know and interpret the greatest source of spiritual strength that man has ever known.
('81', 260, 1, 3, 419647) Although this may or may not be true in my case, I have reasons to believe that it is an erroneous point of view.
('81', 260, 1, 4, 419761) I believe that such an estimate is incompatible with the message that Jesus Christ gave to the world.
('81', 260, 1, 5, 419863) For he was, certainly, the highest example of one who wished to give everything asking nothing in return, and not caring what creed might happen to be professed by the recipient.
('81', 260, 1, 6, 420042) I am sure that if He were living here now among men, He would bless the lives of many who perhaps have never even heard His name, if only their lives embodied the virtues of which He was a living example on earth; the virtues of loving one’s neighbour as oneself and of doing good and charitable works among one’s fellow men.
('81', 260, 1, 7, 420368) What, then, does Jesus mean to me?
('81', 260, 1, 8, 420403) To me He was one of the greatest teachers humanity has ever had.
('81', 260, 1, 9, 420468) To His believers He was God’s only begotten Son.
('81', 260, 1, 10, 420517) Could the fact that I do or do not accept this belief make Jesus have any more or less influence in my life?
('81', 260, 1, 11, 420626) Is all the grandeur of His teaching and of His doctrine to be forbidden to me?
('81', 260, 1, 12, 420705) I cannot believe so.
('81', 260, 1, 13, 420726) To me it implies a spiritual birth.
('81', 260, 1, 14, 420762) My interpretation, in other words, is that in Jesus’ own life is the key of His nearness to God; that He expressed, as no other could, the spirit and will of God.
('81', 260, 1, 15, 420925) It is in this sense that I see Him and recognize Him as the Son of God.
('81', 260, 1, 16, 420997) But I do believe that something of this spirit, that Jesus exemplified in the highest measure in its most profound human sense, does exist.
('81', 260, 1, 17, 421137) I must believe this; if I do not believe it I should be a scep tic; and to be a sceptic is to live a life that is empty and lacks moral content.
('81', 260, 1, 18, 421282) Or, what is the same thing, to condemn the entire human race to a negative end.
('81', 260, 1, 19, 421362) It is true that there certainly is reason for scepticism when one observes the bloody butchery that European aggressors have un loosed, and when one thinks about the misery and suffering prevalent in every corner of the world, as well as the pestilence and famine that always follow, terribly and inevitably, upon war.
('81', 260, 1, 20, 421681) In the face of this, how can one speak seriously of the divine spirit incarnate in man?
('81', 260, 1, 21, 421769) Because these acts of terror and murder offend the conscience of man; because man knows that they represent evil; because in the inner depths of his heart and of his mind, he deplores them.
('81', 260, 1, 22, 421959) And because, moreover, when he does not go astray,
('81', 261, 0, 1, 422010) 262 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('81', 261, 1, 2, 422052) misled by false teachings or corrupted by false leaders, man has within his breast an impulse for good and a compassion that is the spark of divinity, and which some day, I believe, will burst forth into the full flower that is the hope of all mankind.
('81', 261, 1, 3, 422305) An example of this flowering may be found in the figure and in the life of Jesus.
('81', 261, 1, 4, 422387) I refuse to believe that there now exists or has ever existed a person that has not made use of His example to lessen his sins, even though he may have done so without realizing it.
('81', 261, 1, 5, 422569) The lives of all have, in some greater or lesser degree, been changed by His presence, His actions, and the words spoken by His divine voice.
('81', 261, 1, 6, 422711) I believe that it is impossible to estimate the merits of the various religions of the world, and moreover I believe that it is unnecessary and harmful even to attempt it.
('81', 261, 1, 7, 422883) But each one of them, in my judg ment, embodies a common motivating force : the desire to uplift man’s life and give it purpose.
('81', 261, 1, 8, 423012) And because the life of Jesus has the significance and the transcendency to which I have alluded, I believe that He belongs not solely to Christianity, but to the entire world; to all races and people, it matters little under what flag, name or doctrine they may work, profess a faith, or worship a god inherited from their ancestors.
('81', 261, 1, 9, 423347) Modern Review, October 1941

('81', 278, 4, 11, 447185) SEVAGRAM, November 9, 1941
('81', 278, 5, 12, 447212) MY DEAR SATYAMURTI, Your letter.
('81', 278, 5, 13, 447245) You are off the track.
('81', 278, 5, 14, 447268) You need no permission even as those you mention did not.
('81', 278, 5, 15, 447326) 1 The Congress Constitution recognized the right of free speech by Congressmen.
('81', 278, 5, 16, 447406) I have given you my personal view of the working of non violence.
('81', 278, 5, 17, 447472) 2 You are in no way bound to accept it.
('81', 278, 5, 18, 447512) No one wants you or expects you to gag yourself even for one day.
('81', 278, 5, 19, 447578) You are free save for the restraint you put upon yourself by reason of ill health or otherwise.

('81', 278, 5, 21, 447750) Therefore please feel free to express yourself in any manner you like and whenever you like.
