('81', 284, 6, 20, 455104) 508. STATEMENT ON INDO CEYLONESE PACT WARDHA, November 11, 1941 The proposed Indo Ceylonese Pact 1 is not open to the fatal objections that have been universally raised against the Indo Burman thing, 2 which was sprung upon an unsuspecting public as an almost settled fact.
('81', 284, 6, 21, 455378) What has come from Ceylon is a proposal for examination by the Government and the public.
('81', 284, 6, 22, 455468) I have studied the relevant papers as much as possible.
('81', 284, 6, 23, 455524) On merits, the Ceylon proposal is open to objection in the same manner as the Burman.
('81', 284, 6, 24, 455610) I suggest to Ceylon Ministers that there is no reason whatsoever for hurry.
('81', 284, 6, 25, 455686) Adjustment can easily be made about the supply of labour, but wholesale legislation may be left over till after the war.
('81', 284, 6, 26, 455807) The war is a terrible tragedy, the like of which is unknown to history.
('81', 284, 6, 27, 455879) But the tragedy will be deeper still, if at the end we find
('81', 284, 7, 28, 455939) 1 The status and rights of Indians in Geylon, which were threatened by the proposed Immigration Ordinance of Ceylon Government, were sought to be safe guarded and in some respects improved in the joint report, published in New Delhi on October 16, by the Indian and Ceylonese delegations to the exploratory conference held in September in Ceylon.
('81', 284, 7, 29, 456286) 2 For Gandhiji’s statement on Indo Burman Agreement, vide “Statement to the Press”, 24 8 1941.
('81', 285, 0, 1, 456381) 286 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('81', 285, 1, 2, 456423) ourselves living the old way without radical changes in every walk of life.
('81', 285, 1, 3, 456499) Let me recall here the goodwill mission that was sent by the Congress in July 1939 in the person of Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru.
('81', 285, 1, 4, 456624) It had created a deep impression upon the Singhalese and their Minis ters.
('81', 285, 1, 5, 456699) It was hoped that the good seed sown by our ambassador would fructify.
('81', 285, 1, 6, 456770) When the Ceylon deputation came to India in November last, it was arranged that they would meet him in Allahabad.
('81', 285, 1, 7, 456884) But he was arrested before they could meet.
('81', 285, 1, 8, 456928) Jawaharlal had prepared a note for them.
('81', 285, 1, 9, 456969) It will be published, if I find it necessary to do so.
('81', 285, 1, 10, 457024) My object in recalling the mission and the attempt made thereafter is to point out the way to lasting peace and brotherliness between Ceylon and India.
('81', 285, 1, 11, 457176) It is unthinkable that Burma, Ceylon and India should distrust one another or regard the presence of their nationals among their neighbours as antagonistic to one another.
('81', 285, 1, 12, 457348) Any harmful migration from one country to the other may surely be regulated by voluntary adjustment without much legal inter ference.
('81', 285, 1, 13, 457482) I feel somehow that no harm has accrued to Ceylon by the settlement of Indians there.
('81', 285, 1, 14, 457568) As elsewhere, Indian merchants and pro fessionals had followed in the wake of labour imported wholly for the benefit of Ceylon.
('81', 285, 1, 15, 457696) Sir Edward Jackson’s report, I understand, clearly shows that Indian emigration to Ceylon has done no harm to the indigenous population.
('81', 285, 1, 16, 457833) But, if my plea for patient waiting falls on deaf ears, I suggest much the same thing that I have suggested for Burma.
('81', 285, 1, 17, 457952) I should have no difficulty in persuading experienced legislators that in legislation affecting men in the street and addressed to the masses the simplest and shortest method is best.
('81', 285, 1, 18, 458136) I, therefore, suggest that the whole of the Indian population found in Ceylon on a given date (kept secret) should be registered and clothed with full rights of citizenship.
('81', 285, 1, 19, 458310) Those who may be outside Ceylon but who can unquestionably be proved to be bona fide residents of Ceylon should also be registered on application.
('81', 285, 1, 20, 458457) This procedure obviates the intricacies which permeate the proposal under examination.
('81', 285, 1, 21, 458544) The term ‘domicile’ should find no place in such legislation.
('81', 285, 1, 22, 458606) The English law of domicile is the worst possible.
('81', 285, 1, 23, 458657) Judges have been known to have been confused over the interpretation of the term.
('81', 285, 1, 24, 458739) Human liberty is a precious thing, which must not be trifled with by legal subtleties and interminable wranglings in courts of law.
('81', 285, 1, 25, 458871) The wrangling attains no dignity, because it takes place in a law court.
('81', 285, 1, 26, 458944) Men should know definitely where they stand in given circumstances.
('81', 286, 0, 1, 459012) VOL. 81 : 18 AUGUST, 1941 8 FEBRUARY, 1942 287
('81', 286, 1, 2, 459059) So far as labour is concerned, I have no doubt that Ceylon should have the sole right to import as much as it likes under contracts easily to be understood and mutually agreed to between the two Governments.
('81', 286, 1, 3, 459267) The suggested quota system should have no place in an honourable understanding.
('81', 286, 1, 4, 459347) The Bombay Chronicle, 12 11 1941

('81', 287, 6, 15, 460428) 511. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS WARDHAGANJ, November 12, 1941 I observe that there is a move to press the Government to release satyagrahi prisoners.
('81', 287, 6, 16, 460574) It is, perhaps, appropriate to mention that so far as I know there will be on the part of the Congress neither appreciation of nor response to any such gesture by the Government.
('81', 287, 6, 17, 460753) Those who may be discharged will have to be invited to re offer civil disobedience if they are physically fit.
('81', 287, 6, 18, 460864) Moreover, there will be great resentment if distinction is made between satyagrahis and those who are detained without trial.
('81', 287, 6, 19, 460990) The Government should not be judges of what is reasonable.
('81', 287, 6, 20, 461049) What the public demand is this : Let the Government keep the prisoners, but give decent treatment to the prisoners whether they hunger strike or not.
('81', 287, 6, 21, 461199) They need not take notice of such strikes when there is no reasonable cause for that.
('81', 287, 6, 22, 461285) The Deoli prisoners’ demands as far as they are known are just.
('81', 287, 6, 23, 461349) Let them end the terrible suspense by granting the demands and ending the hunger strike.
('81', 287, 6, 24, 461438) Let them also examine the recently published weighty manifesto by representative and prominent medical men from all India on the
('81', 287, 7, 25, 461567) 1 Gosibehn Captain, grand daughter of Dadabhai Naoroji
('81', 288, 0, 1, 461622) VOL. 81 : 18 AUGUST, 1941 8 FEBRUARY, 1942 289
('81', 288, 1, 2, 461669) dietary of C class prisoners and make the necessary changes and redress such other disabilities which have no just basis.
('81', 288, 1, 3, 461791) I, therefore, suggest to those who are urging the Government to discharge satyagrahi prisoners that they will do well if they will concentrate on the relief herein suggested.
('81', 288, 1, 4, 461966) 1 It can be granted quickly without any political or other embarrassment.
('81', 288, 1, 5, 462040) The Bombay Chronicle, 13 11 1941

('81', 292, 1, 2, 467491) So far as I can see, there is no political motive behind this hunger strike.

('81', 301, 1, 2, 480584) which deserves serious consideration.
('81', 301, 1, 3, 480622) I am, therefore, reproducing it below for the benefit of khadi lovers.
('81', 301, 2, 4, 480693) This scheme seeks to realine the dream of paying the spinners and ultimately all labourers, i.e., craftsmen, eight annas for an eight hour day.
('81', 301, 2, 5, 480837) It does not attempt to give everyone everything here and now.
('81', 301, 2, 6, 480899) But the attempt is to show that all this can be achieved within ten years.
('81', 301, 2, 7, 480974) Bhai Dhirendra does not express a definite opinion on the scheme but seeks the opinion and comments of other experts.
('81', 301, 2, 8, 481092) Maybe he does not have in the prison all the necessary literature on the subject.
('81', 301, 2, 9, 481174) About the scheme at the moment I can only say that all khadi workers should examine it and experiment in this direction.
('81', 301, 2, 10, 481295) Small experiments need almost no capital.
('81', 301, 2, 11, 481337) For exapmle, training ten or twenty spinners and a few teachers and keeping a record of the results should not involve much expenditure.
('81', 301, 2, 12, 481474) The chief merit of the scheme lies in its being almost self supporting.
('81', 301, 2, 13, 481546) It consists of two parts.
('81', 301, 2, 14, 481572) It does lay a little burden on the institution in the form of enhanced wages.
('81', 301, 2, 15, 481650) But the other half deals with payment to the spinners after training them for higher produc tion.
('81', 301, 2, 16, 481748) Another merit of the scheme is the attempt at all round reform in the spinners’ lives.
('81', 301, 2, 17, 481835) I attach importance to the scheme from this point of view.
('81', 301, 2, 18, 481894) This scheme is not the handiwork of an ignorant khadi lover but has been thought out by a responsible and practical worker.
('81', 301, 2, 19, 482018) Dhirendra Babu is not merely the author of this scheme.
('81', 301, 2, 20, 482074) He is himself going to implement it.
('81', 301, 2, 21, 482111) Every experimenter in the field should remember that the scheme takes into consideration all the processes from cotton growing to weaving.

('81', 305, 9, 24, 487456) 551. LETTER TO AMARNATH JHA
('81', 305, 10, 25, 487484) SEVAGRAM, WARDHA, November 20, 1941
('81', 305, 11, 26, 487520) BHAI AMARNATHJI, I venture to write to you without earlier acquaintance.
('81', 305, 11, 27, 487593) Your election as President of the Hindi Sahitya Sammelan made me glad as well as sad.
('81', 305, 11, 28, 487679) Who would not be glad at the election of a scholar like you?
('81', 305, 11, 29, 487740) But I must confess that I was sad, too; because I had, in the interest of work, wanted Rajendra Babu to be the President this year.
('81', 305, 11, 30, 487872) That is why Seth Jamnalal Bajaj proposed the name of Rajendra Babu.
('81', 305, 11, 31, 487940) You are of course aware that I have been closely associated with the Sammelan for many years.
('81', 305, 11, 32, 488034) I had a hand in framing the policy of the Sammelan towards propagation of Hindi.
('81', 305, 11, 33, 488115) It has developed some
('81', 306, 0, 1, 488137) VOL. 81 : 18 AUGUST, 1941 8 FEBRUARY, 1942 307
('81', 306, 1, 2, 488184) political overones too.
('81', 306, 1, 3, 488208) I shall not be able to attend the Sammelan.
('81', 306, 1, 4, 488252) Hence myself and a few friends thought that the election of Rajendra Babu would safeguard the interests of the Sammelan.
('81', 306, 1, 5, 488373) But this did not happen.
('81', 306, 1, 6, 488398) Now all my hopes rest on you.
('81', 306, 1, 7, 488428) I hope to secure your help in what I had expected from Rajendra Babu.
('81', 306, 1, 8, 488498) It will be common ground between you and me that all of us should endeavour to do our best, keeping in view the accommodating attitude of Tandonji 1 who is the soul of the Sammelan, and all the other things we know he stands for.
('81', 306, 1, 9, 488728) I do not know whether or no you approve of the policy adopted at Indore 2 and Nagpur 3. Some attempts were made at Poona to change that policy.
('81', 306, 1, 10, 488872) The attempts did succeed to some extent.
('81', 306, 1, 11, 488913) I do not how ever regard these changes as intolerable.
('81', 306, 1, 12, 488968) But further steps in that direction will become unbearable for persons like me.
('81', 306, 1, 13, 489048) My efforts would be to move a step further than at Nagpur.
('81', 306, 1, 14, 489107) I am convinced this would secure the progress of Hindi and the welfare of the nation.
('81', 306, 1, 15, 489193) Hindi Urdu controversy should not have been started nor should it be continued.
('81', 306, 1, 16, 489273) There have been sharp differences about the Wardha office.
('81', 306, 1, 17, 489332) That office must be subordinate to the Sammelan but I think it should have as much autonomy as the Madras office.
('81', 306, 1, 18, 489446) If it is agreed that the Wardha office has well served the cause of Hindi, it should, I think, enjoy greater autonomy than it has today.
('81', 306, 1, 19, 489583) Rajendra Babu’s presence at the Sammelan is uncertain.
('81', 306, 1, 20, 489638) He cannot stand the December weather of the Punjab.
('81', 306, 1, 21, 489690) Nor can Seth Jamnalalji go.
('81', 306, 1, 22, 489718) Kakasaheb Kalelkar and Acharya Shriman Narayan may go.
('81', 306, 1, 23, 489773) Please lend your ear to them.
('81', 306, 1, 24, 489803) I wish there should be no conflicts at the Sammelan nor any meaningless controversy.
('81', 306, 1, 25, 489888) If there are differences on principles, let them be expressed in a friendly spirit.
('81', 306, 1, 26, 489972) Therefore I would request you, if you can spare the time, to come here for a day so that all of us can meet and talk things over.

('81', 315, 6, 24, 502143) 570. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS WARDHAGANJ, November 27, 1941 The discontinuance of the hunger strike by the Deoli detenus relieves the terrible tension under which the public was labouring.
('81', 315, 6, 25, 502330) It was not possible to contemplate with unconcern the starvation, even self inflicted, of patriots, whether one agreed with their method or not.
('81', 316, 0, 1, 502475) VOL. 81 : 18 AUGUST, 1941 8 FEBRUARY, 1942 317
('81', 316, 1, 2, 502522) Let us hope that repatriation will be hastened and their treatment will not be worsened for their removal to their respective provinces.
('81', 316, 1, 3, 502659) I have read the Government communique describing the bewitching life in Deoli.
('81', 316, 1, 4, 502738) I recall a similar description of life in the Andamans.
('81', 316, 1, 5, 502794) It read like a fairy tale and yet most of the inmates preferred to return home.
('81', 316, 1, 6, 502874) These descriptions, however truthful they may be in the estimation of the writers not themsleves detenus, do not answer the reality as the detenus see it.
('81', 316, 1, 7, 503029) The object of the communique, on the face of it, is to show that the condition in Deoli was superior to what it was in the respective provinces.
('81', 316, 1, 8, 503174) If such was the case, it shows how correct and proper was the demand of the hunger strikers that their condition on repatriation should be no worse than in Deoli.
('81', 316, 1, 9, 503337) I should translate the demand thus : (1) Repatriation should not be to a remote godforsaken place in the detenu’s province.
('81', 316, 1, 10, 503461) The object of repatriation would be wholly frustrated if the detenus are transferred to a place far away from their homes.
('81', 316, 1, 11, 503584) (2) The conveniences and food should be as near to Deoli’s latest standard as possible.
('81', 316, 1, 12, 503672) That is so far as the prisoners’ demands are concerned.
('81', 316, 1, 13, 503728) But something more is needed.
('81', 316, 1, 14, 503758) Seeing that the detenus have not been tried, the burden is on the Government to give them as decent a treatment as possible.
('81', 316, 1, 15, 503883) War economy has no place in this connection, for detention is itself a war measure and could not be justified on any other ground.
('81', 316, 1, 16, 504014) Therefore, they are entitled to family allowance and travelling expenses for their families when necessary.
('81', 316, 1, 17, 504122) It should be remembered that most of the detenus are poor people.
('81', 316, 1, 18, 504188) So much as to Deoli.
('81', 316, 1, 19, 504209) But I feel that the question of food, sanitation and classification is and should be treated as an all India question.
('81', 316, 1, 20, 504328) I confine myself just now only to political prisoners, whether detenus detained on suspicion or satyagrahis who have courted imprisonment.
('81', 316, 1, 21, 504467) If I had the authority, I would treat all prisoners alike, making a distinction only on the ground of health and habit.
('81', 316, 1, 22, 504587) But I must not complicate the main issue by raising others [that] do not demand immediate solution.
('81', 316, 1, 23, 504687) I think that classifications should be scrapped.
('81', 316, 1, 24, 504736) At best they are arbitrary.
('81', 316, 1, 25, 504764) The scale prescribed in the very weighty and reasoned manifesto recently issued by eminent medical men representing the whole of India should be accepted forthwith as the minimum scale for all India, with such variations as staples grown in various provinces may demand.
('81', 316, 1, 26, 505035) All political prisoners should have the right to supplement their food and other requirements from their own pockets.
('81', 317, 0, 1, 505153) 318 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('81', 317, 1, 2, 505195) All should be supplied with a selection of newspapers and magazines of known standing without any censoring.
('81', 317, 1, 3, 505304) There should be no restrictions as to choice of books.
('81', 317, 1, 4, 505359) What is not generally prohibited in India should be allowed to prisoners.
('81', 317, 1, 5, 505433) They should be allowed to write letters and receive visitors on the same scale as in B class.
('81', 317, 1, 6, 505527) It should be common cause that no recognition should be given to hunger strikes for wringing illegitimate concessions nor need they be penalized by refusal to consider legitimate demands on merits.
('81', 317, 1, 7, 505725) For a prisoner under stress, hunger strike is the last non violent remedy.
('81', 317, 1, 8, 505800) He seeks to end imposed suffering by self imposed suffering.
('81', 317, 1, 9, 505861) He thereby hopes to melt the heart of authority or at least enlist the sympathy of the public.
('81', 317, 1, 10, 505956) Experience shows that the method is not to be despised.
('81', 317, 1, 11, 506012) It has succeeded in several cases.
('81', 317, 1, 12, 506047) But it is not easy to know always whether the cause for which a strike is undertaken is valid.
('81', 317, 1, 13, 506142) We know, too, that Governments do not always come to a right decision in such cases.
('81', 317, 1, 14, 506227) I have before me the case of a prisoner, who has given up his strike at my instance.
('81', 317, 1, 15, 506312) The cause, as transpires in the record of the case before me, seems to have been more than valid.
('81', 317, 1, 16, 506410) The vegetables served contained a dead scorpion.
('81', 317, 1, 17, 506459) The men who had resorted to hunger strike are now being tried for breach of jail regulations in that they refused the food served.
('81', 317, 1, 18, 506590) There is the Chunar hunger strike now going on for a fortnight.
('81', 317, 1, 19, 506654) It is in respect of the treatment of C class prisoners.
('81', 317, 1, 20, 506710) I have wired pleading for its suspension.
('81', 317, 2, 21, 506752) I think that hunger strikes should not be regarded as a crime, but whenever such a strike takes place it should be referred to a judicial tribunal with the right to the prisoner to be represented by a lawyer of his choice.
('81', 317, 2, 22, 506975) If the cause is found to be valid, the grievance should be removed.
('81', 317, 2, 23, 507043) If the hunger strike is persisted in, although the finding is against the prisoner, the fast should be ignored.
('81', 317, 2, 24, 507155) If the procedure recommended by me is adopted the probability is that strikes will automatically decrease.
('81', 317, 2, 25, 507262) Where the cause is valid, the authorities will grant redress on a mere notice of hunger strike and where the strike is found to be unjustified there will be no public sympathy.
('81', 317, 2, 26, 507439) It follows that there would be no forcible feeding if the procedure I am recommending is adopted.
('81', 317, 2, 27, 507537) In rare and obstinate cases a life may have to be lost.
('81', 317, 2, 28, 507593) It is impossible always to prevent suicide, even by fasting.
('81', 317, 2, 29, 507654) Fasting has come to stay as a remedy for redress of grievances.
('81', 317, 2, 30, 507718) It has its uses.
('81', 317, 2, 31, 507735) An honest fast draws attention to a felt grievance and
('81', 317, 3, 32, 507790) 1 The telegram is not available.
('81', 318, 0, 1, 507823) VOL. 81 : 18 AUGUST, 1941 8 FEBRUARY, 1942 319
('81', 318, 1, 2, 507870) compels redress.
('81', 318, 1, 3, 507887) What I have suggested is regularization of the huma nitarian instinct and the rescuing of a useful institution from ridicule or contempt.

('81', 332, 1, 2, 530426) 599. LETTER TO SAMPURANANAND
('81', 332, 2, 3, 530455) December 4, 1941
('81', 332, 3, 4, 530472) BHAI SAMPURNANAND, I just got your letter.
('81', 332, 3, 5, 530515) Even before your letter arrived I had, in the course of a letter to a friend, stated that you were fully entitled to offer criticism.
('81', 332, 3, 6, 530649) It has had no adverse effect on me, although I main tain that there is absolutely no ground whatsoever for your criticism.
('81', 332, 3, 7, 530772) At the back of [the struggle for] freedom of speech there is [the claim for] independence as it was at the back of the Salt [Satyagraha].
('81', 332, 3, 8, 530910) But then this is a controversial subject.
('81', 332, 3, 9, 530952) Time will reveal everything.
('81', 332, 3, 10, 530981) That leaves the question of Hindi.
('81', 332, 3, 11, 531016) This controversy is meaning less and stems from ignorance.
('81', 332, 3, 12, 531075) No one in the Congress is antagonistic towards Hindi.
('81', 332, 3, 13, 531129) And no one will suspect me of such antagonism.
('81', 332, 3, 14, 531176) But I may differ in my policy [regarding Hindi].
('81', 332, 3, 15, 531225) And if this happens to be the case, what would be my position in the Sammelan 1?
('81', 332, 3, 16, 531306) I have been dragged into the Sammelan and I can quit this moment.
('81', 332, 3, 17, 531372) I regard Urdu and the Persian script as included in Hindi.
('81', 332, 3, 18, 531431) I have been maintaining this view since the Indore [session].
('81', 332, 3, 19, 531493) The man responsible for giving to the national language the name Hindustani [and getting it] accepted by the Congress is Tandonji.
('81', 332, 3, 20, 531624) Now what can be done?
('81', 332, 3, 21, 531646) I think the resolution was all right.
('81', 332, 3, 22, 531684) And if it was so we should regard Hindustani as a synonym for Hindi.
('81', 332, 3, 23, 531753) Now tell me if there is anything wrong in it.
('81', 332, 3, 24, 531799) Rajendra Babu is not in a condition to go to Kashi.
('81', 332, 3, 25, 531851) And he is certainly not going to Abohar.
('81', 332, 3, 26, 531892) Kakasaheb and Shrimanji are on their way to meet Dr. Amarnathji.
('81', 332, 3, 27, 531957) 2 Maybe, now Tandonji himself will come out.
('81', 332, 3, 28, 532002) Whatever he says will be done.
('81', 332, 4, 29, 532033) Yours, M. K. GANDHI

('81', 333, 0, 1, 532228) 334 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('81', 333, 1, 2, 532270) 600. INTERVIEW TO THE PRESS
('81', 333, 2, 3, 532298) WARDHAGANJ, December 4, 1941
('81', 333, 3, 4, 532327) In the course of an interview, this afternoon, on the Government of India’s communique 1 regarding the release of political prisoners, Mahatma Gandhi said : As I have said before the event, 2 I must repeat after the event, that, so far as I am concerned, it cannot evoke a single responsive or appreciative chord in me.
('81', 333, 3, 5, 532647) From my student days onward, I have been, and still claim to be, a friend of the British people.
('81', 333, 3, 6, 532744) But my friendship cannot blind me to the fact that British representatives hold India as a bondslave.
('81', 333, 3, 7, 532846) All the freedom that India enjoys is the freedom of a slave and not the freedom of an equal, which is otherwise known as Complete Indepen dence.
('81', 333, 3, 8, 532991) Mr. Amery’s pronouncements do not soothe the festering sore, but are like sprinkling chillies on it.
('81', 333, 3, 9, 533092) It is in that setting that I am called upon to examine this release.
('81', 333, 3, 10, 533161) If the Government of India are confident of the determination of all responsible opinion in India to support the war effort, the logi cal conclusion would be to keep the civil disobedience prisoners in their custody, because they produce a jarring note.
('81', 333, 3, 11, 533415) The only meaning I can attach to the release, therefore, is that they expect that the prisoners will have changed their opinions in their self invited solitude.
('81', 333, 3, 12, 533576) I am hoping that the Government will be soon disillusioned.
('81', 333, 3, 13, 533636) Civil disobedience was not taken up without the most careful consideration.
('81', 333, 3, 14, 533712) It was certainly not taken up out of any vindictiveness.
('81', 333, 3, 15, 533769) It was taken up, and I hope will be continued, in order to make good the claim of the Congress to let the British people and the world know that there is, at the very least, a large body of public opinion represented by the Congress which is utterly opposed to participation in the war, not because it wishes any disaster to the British arms or
('81', 333, 4, 16, 534114) 1 Issued on December 3, 1941, which stated : “The Government of India, confident in the determination of all responsible opinion in India to support the war effort until victory is secured, have reached the conclusion that those civil disobedience prisoners whose offences have been formal or symbolic in character, can be set free.
('81', 333, 4, 17, 534447) Effect will be given to this course as soon as possible.
('81', 333, 4, 18, 534504) There are provinces in which local conditions may mean delay; but before the end of the year the Government of India hope that throughout India practically all such persons will have been set free.
('81', 333, 4, 19, 534702) With them there will be released also Maulana Abul Kalam Azad and Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru.” 2 Vide “Statement to the Press”, 12 11 1941.
('81', 334, 0, 1, 534839) VOL. 81 : 18 AUGUST, 1941 8 FEBRUARY, 1942 335
('81', 334, 1, 2, 534886) victory to the Nazi or Fascist arms, but because it sees no deliverance from blood guiltiness either for the victor or for the vanquished, and certainly no deliverance for India out of this war.
('81', 334, 1, 3, 535081) The Congress, which seeks and claims to represent the dumb millions, has, for the past twenty years, accepted non violence as its unbroken policy to achieve India’s independence.
('81', 334, 1, 4, 535260) To stop civil disobedience, symbolic though it may be for the time being, will be to deny its policy at a crucial moment.
('81', 334, 1, 5, 535382) The Government claim that, in spite of the Congress efforts, they are able to get all the men and money from India.
('81', 334, 1, 6, 535498) Therefore the Congress opposition, in their estimate, can only be a moral effort and a moral demonstration.
('81', 334, 1, 7, 535606) I, for one, am entirely satisfied with it, because I am convinced that from that moral demonstration will arise, when the moment comes, a demonstration which will result in the attainment of India’s independence, not the ascendance of this party or that.
('81', 334, 1, 8, 535861) The Congress struggle covers every single unit in India.
('81', 334, 1, 9, 535918) Now that the Congress President 1 is expected to be out, it will be for him to consider whether and when to call the Congress Working Committee or the A. I. C. C. These two bodies will determine the future policy of the Congress.
('81', 334, 1, 10, 536148) I am but a humble instrument of service in conducting the civil disobedience.
('81', 334, 1, 11, 536226) I would, however, say one word about the detenus and other prisoners.
('81', 334, 1, 12, 536296) It sounds strange that those who have sought imprisonment are to be discharged and not those who are either detained without trial or imprisoned because they hold the freedom of their country dearer than their personal liberty.
('81', 334, 1, 13, 536524) There is surely something utterly wrong somewhere.
('81', 334, 1, 14, 536575) Therefore I cannot rejoice over the Government of India’s decision.
('81', 334, 1, 15, 536643) The Hindu, 6 12 1941 601. LETTER TO JAWAHARLAL NEHRU December 5, 1941

('81', 338, 9, 18, 541604) 607. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS WARDHAGANJ, December 7, 1941 The jail delivery that is going on apace of satyagrahis must be taken as a challenge to convene a meeting of the A. I. C. C. which, the Government of India have been evidently induced to expect, will reverse the Bombay decision, whose working is reflected in my conduct of the satyagraha campaign.
('81', 338, 9, 19, 541959) I have, therefore, advised the Maulana Saheb to convene a meeting of the Working Committee and the A.I.C.C. at an early date, but until that decision is reversed civil disobedience has to go on.
('81', 338, 9, 20, 542154) I must admit, however, that the conduct of the campaign has been rendered difficult by the Government action in discharging civil disobedience prisoners, but if we are to reach our goal, we have to cut our way through every difficulty.
('81', 338, 9, 21, 542390) This one is nothing compared to what we are likely to have to face before we come into our own.
('81', 338, 9, 22, 542486) If the A. I. C. C. meeting is to come, as it must, pending the meeting members of the Working Committee and the A. I. C. C. must
('81', 339, 0, 1, 542615) 340 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('81', 339, 1, 2, 542657) not offer civil disobedience, nor should those who are interested in reversing the Bombay decision.
('81', 339, 1, 3, 542757) Apart from these, civil disobedience should continue without interruption.
('81', 339, 1, 4, 542832) Of course it will stand suspended on Xmas Day, Boxing Day and New Year’s Day.
('81', 339, 1, 5, 542910) The question naturally arises whether civil disobedience is to be offered in the usual manner by reciting the prescribed formula 1 or in some other manner.
('81', 339, 1, 6, 543066) I like the formula method.
('81', 339, 1, 7, 543093) It gives directness and symmetry to the movement.
('81', 339, 1, 8, 543143) There is great power in the reciting of the same formula in the same manner.
('81', 339, 1, 9, 543220) It rivets the attention of the masses and men on identical theme.
('81', 339, 1, 10, 543286) The formula is not a mean thing.
('81', 339, 1, 11, 543319) It is a protest of the nation against war as an arbitrator.
('81', 339, 1, 12, 543379) It is a message of peace on earth and goodwill towards mankind.
('81', 339, 1, 13, 543443) What is individual formula today will become, in due time, that of the masses, but the authorities having discharged symbolical satyagrahis may refuse to rearrest them for reciting slogans.
('81', 339, 1, 14, 543633) There are then two ways open to us: If they do not rearrest, there need be no dismay and demoralization, the jail is not our objective.
('81', 339, 1, 15, 543769) Freedom of speech is the immediate objective.
('81', 339, 1, 16, 543815) If recitation is not objected to, we have advanced somewhat towards our objective and it will be foolish to court imprisonment for the sake of it.
('81', 339, 1, 17, 543962) Dismay and demoralization arise because Congressmen in general have not realized the inevitable connection between construc tive programme and civil disobedience.
('81', 339, 1, 18, 544125) Civil disobedience without the backing of constructive programme can never lead us to indepen dence.
('81', 339, 1, 19, 544226) Shorn of it, civil disobedience becomes method of violence bound to prove ineffective in the end.
('81', 339, 1, 20, 544324) Moreover, civil disobedience, even when it is mass, will only be offered by those who are bodily fit, whereas constructive programme is for all and will never be suspended.
('81', 339, 1, 21, 544497) If the whole nation took it up in earnest it is enough to give us complete independence.
('81', 339, 1, 22, 544586) The prosecu tion of the constructive programme means constructing the structure of swaraj.
('81', 339, 1, 23, 544677) The whole theme of corporate non violence, as I have conceived it, falls to pieces if there is no living faith in the constructive programme.
('81', 339, 1, 24, 544819) To my mind, swaraj based on non violence is a fulfilment of the
('81', 339, 2, 25, 544883) 1 Namely, “It is wrong to help the British war effort with men or money.
('81', 339, 2, 26, 544956) The only worthy effort is to resist all war with non violent resistance”, Vide “Instructions to Satyagrahis”, 8 11 1940.
('81', 340, 0, 1, 545077) VOL. 81 : 18 AUGUST, 1941 8 FEBRUARY, 1942 341
('81', 340, 1, 2, 545124) constructive programme; hence, whether the authorities jail us or not, we must pursue the constructive programme.
('81', 340, 1, 3, 545238) I have been asked whether discharged satyagrahis should hold or attend meetings and deliver speeches.
('81', 340, 1, 4, 545340) They should do so.
('81', 340, 1, 5, 545359) I do not want or expect them to re offer civil disobedience immediately.
('81', 340, 1, 6, 545432) That would be indecent haste, but ordinary civil disobedience may go on.
('81', 340, 1, 7, 545505) For the discharged ones let there be breathing time.
('81', 340, 1, 8, 545558) Let them address meetings in their constituencies and study things.
('81', 340, 1, 9, 545626) At the meetings they will expound their views on the general situation and not hesitate to interpret anti war Congress policy.
('81', 340, 1, 10, 545753) Symbolic satyagraha has a definite meaning but it is open to the authorities to arrest Congressmen for their speeches even if they do not intend thereby to offer C. D. That was how they had arrested the Maulana Sahib and Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, not to mention lesser lights.
('81', 340, 1, 11, 546029) Let it be known that I have no authority to suspend C. D. on extraneous grounds.
('81', 340, 1, 12, 546110) That is for the Congress to do.
('81', 340, 1, 13, 546142) For me personally there is no choice.
('81', 340, 1, 14, 546180) As a man sworn to peace, at this critical moment to suspend my anti war activity would be to deny myself.
('81', 340, 1, 15, 546286) Therefore, for those who think like me, whether we are misunderstood or worse befalls, we must express our faith through our action hoping thereby that ultimately our way will be accepted by all warring powers as the only escape from a blood bath which is reducing man to his lowest depth.

('81', 341, 8, 20, 547611) 610. ASHRAM NOTE
('81', 341, 9, 21, 547628) December 8, 1941 The rules deducible from the eleven observances 2 and essential for a well regulated Ashram life are as follows : All members—whether permanent or otherwise—will turn every minute of their time to good account.
('81', 341, 9, 22, 547856) They will take part in every corporate activity of the Ashram.
('81', 341, 9, 23, 547919) When free from Ashram work they will spin or carry out some other process connected with cotton.
('81', 341, 9, 24, 548016) They will prosecute their private studies from 8 to 9 p.m.
('81', 341, 9, 25, 548075) or during daytime, when they have no Ashram work to do and have done at least one hour’s spinning.
('81', 341, 9, 26, 548174) They may not spin when they are ill or otherwise unable to spin owing to circumstances beyond their control.
('81', 341, 10, 27, 548283) 1 Vide “Letter to K. M. Munshi”, 5 12 1941. 2 Ahimsa, truth, non stealing, brahmacharya, non possession, body labour, control of the palate, freedom from fear, equal regard for all religions, swadeshi and looking upon all human beings as touchables
('81', 342, 0, 1, 548532) VOL. 81 : 18 AUGUST, 1941 8 FEBRUARY, 1942 343
('81', 342, 1, 2, 548579) No one should talk idly or in a loud voice.
('81', 342, 1, 3, 548623) The Ashram must bear the impress of perfect peace as well as of truth.
('81', 342, 1, 4, 548694) Our relations with one another must be marked by affection and restraint, and with guests and visitors by courtesy.
('81', 342, 1, 5, 548810) Whether a visitor is dressed in rags or in gorgeous robes, we should treat him with the same respect.
('81', 342, 1, 6, 548912) We must not make any distinction between the rich and the poor, the high and the lowly.
('81', 342, 1, 7, 549000) This does not mean that we may expect a delicately nurtured guest to live as simply as ourselves.
('81', 342, 1, 8, 549098) That is to say, in waiting upon guests, we must always take into consideration their habitual mode of life.
('81', 342, 1, 9, 549206) This is true courtesy.
('81', 342, 1, 10, 549229) If an unknown visitor arrives at the Ashram, we must ask him the purpose of his visit, and if necessary take him to the manager.
('81', 342, 1, 11, 549358) This is the duty of every inmate of the Ashram, because we cannot know whom such a visitor is likely to meet first.
('81', 342, 1, 12, 549474) Our every word and every act should be well considered.
('81', 342, 1, 13, 549530) What ever we do we should do with a will and in complete identification with the work of the moment.
('81', 342, 1, 14, 549631) Food must be taken like medicine, under proper restraint, only for sustaining the body and keeping it a fit instrument for service.
('81', 342, 1, 15, 549763) We must therefore take food in moderation or even abstemiously.
('81', 342, 1, 16, 549827) We must be content with what food we get.
('81', 342, 1, 17, 549869) If the food is insufficiently or badly cooked, we must not talk about it at meals, but courteously speak about it later to the manager of the kitchen.
('81', 342, 1, 18, 550020) Bad or imperfectly cooked food should not be eaten.
('81', 342, 1, 19, 550072) We must not champ while eating.
('81', 342, 1, 20, 550104) We must eat our food slowly, decorously and tidily in a spirit of thankfulness to God.
('81', 342, 1, 21, 550191) Everyone must wash his own dish thoroughly and keep it in its place.
('81', 342, 1, 22, 550260) Guests and visitors are requested to bring their own plate, drink ing pot, bowls and spoon, as well as lantern, bedding and mos quito net.
('81', 342, 1, 23, 550399) They must not have more clothes than necessary.
('81', 342, 1, 24, 550447) Their clothes should be made of khadi.
('81', 342, 1, 25, 550486) Other things must be as far as possible village made or at least swadeshi.
('81', 342, 1, 26, 550561) Everything must be kept in its proper place.
('81', 342, 1, 27, 550606) All refuse must be put into the dust bin.
('81', 342, 1, 28, 550648) Water must not be wasted.
('81', 342, 1, 29, 550674) Boiled water is used for drinking pur poses.
('81', 342, 1, 30, 550719) Pots and pans are finally washed with boiled water.
('81', 342, 1, 31, 550771) Unboiled water of the Ashram wells is not safe to drink.
('81', 342, 1, 32, 550828) It is necessary to learn the distinction between boiling water and hot water.
('81', 342, 1, 33, 550906) Boiling water is that in which pulses are cooked; and which gives out lots of steam.
('81', 342, 1, 34, 550991) No one can drink boiling water.
('81', 343, 0, 1, 551023) 344 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('81', 343, 1, 2, 551065) We should not spit or clean the nose on the road, but only in an out of the way place where no one is likely to walk.
('81', 343, 1, 3, 551183) The call of nature must be attended to only at the appointed place.
('81', 343, 1, 4, 551251) It is necessary to clean oneself after answering either call of nature.
('81', 343, 1, 5, 551323) The water jug used in the toilet is, as it should always be, set apart.
('81', 343, 1, 6, 551395) After a visit to the latrine, we must wash our hands with pure earth and pure water, and wipe them with a clean napkin.
('81', 343, 1, 7, 551515) The night soil must be fully covered with dry earth so as not to attract flies and in such a way that nothing but dry earth is visible.
('81', 343, 1, 8, 551651) One must sit carefully on the latrine seat, so that the seat does not get dirty and the stool drops into the receptacle.
('81', 343, 1, 9, 551772) A lantern must be carried if it is dark.
('81', 343, 1, 10, 551813) Everything which can attract flies should be properly covered.
('81', 343, 1, 11, 551876) Teeth must be cleaned with care at the proper place.
('81', 343, 1, 12, 551929) The end of the twig must be well chewed into a soft brush, and the teeth and the gums must be brushed with it inside and out.
('81', 343, 1, 13, 552055) The saliva discharged during brushing must be spat out.
('81', 343, 1, 14, 552111) It must not be swallowed.
('81', 343, 1, 15, 552137) After the teeth are well brushed the twig must be split into two to clean the tongue with.
('81', 343, 1, 16, 552228) Then the mouth should be carefully washed.
('81', 343, 1, 17, 552271) The nose also should be cleaned by drawing in water.
('81', 343, 1, 18, 552324) The split twigs should be washed well, and collected in a pot.
('81', 343, 1, 19, 552387) When they dry up they should be used for starting a fire, the idea being that nothing which can be used should be thrown away.
('81', 343, 1, 20, 552514) Waste paper, which cannot be used for writing on the other side, should be burned.
('81', 343, 1, 21, 552597) Nothing else should be mixed with it.
('81', 343, 1, 22, 552635) The refuse from leafy vegetables must be kept separate and converted into manure.
('81', 343, 1, 23, 552717) Broken glass should be thrown into a pit at a safe distance from houses.
('81', 343, 1, 24, 552790) If anyone visits the Ashram or comes as a guest he should be received with love.
('81', 343, 1, 25, 552871) He should not feel an outsider.
('81', 343, 1, 26, 552903) In the Ashram everything should be in its proper place and every nook and corner should be clean.
('81', 343, 1, 27, 553001) No dust should be allowed to collect on the doors, nor should they be sticky.
('81', 343, 1, 28, 553079) Everyone should do with great care the work allotted to him.
('81', 343, 1, 29, 553140) No one should absent himself from a collective task.
('81', 343, 1, 30, 553193) There should be the most scrupulous care in cleaning the utensils.
('81', 343, 1, 31, 553260) The latrines should always be kept dry.
('81', 343, 1, 32, 553300) The night soil must always be covered with dry earth.
('81', 343, 1, 33, 553354) Much water stagnates near the water room; this is not good.
('81', 343, 1, 34, 553414) Food should always be kept covered, so that it does not attract flies.
('81', 344, 0, 1, 553485) VOL. 81 : 18 AUGUST, 1941 8 FEBRUARY, 1942 345
('81', 344, 1, 2, 553532) In the matter of food everyone should remember our vow about control of the palate, and eat all the things as medicine.
('81', 344, 1, 3, 553652) We should not be perturbed if occasionally we miss an item.
('81', 344, 1, 4, 553712) Whatever we get should be accepted as God’s grace.

('81', 345, 8, 21, 555882) 615. INTERVIEW TO EVELYN WRENCH 4
('81', 345, 9, 22, 555916) [Before December 9, 1941]
('81', 345, 10, 23, 555942) Sir E. I recently had an hour and a half talk with Mr. Jinnah and heard his point of view.
('81', 345, 10, 24, 556033) I do not know what following he has, but he reiterated again and again : “Never will Muslims be subservient to Hindu authority.
('81', 345, 10, 25, 556161) You English and Germans are much closer to each other than Hindus and Muslims.” I would like to know what you have to say in regard to this.
('81', 345, 11, 26, 556302) 1 Ratilal, addressee’s brother, and Dr. Pranjivandas Mehta, addressee’s father 2 ibid
('81', 345, 12, 27, 556388) 3 Prabhashankar Parekh, Ratilal’s father in law 4 According to Evelyn Wrench, Editor of The Spectator, the interview took place just before Christmas, 1941, in Gandhiji’s Ashram, Sevagram, Wardha.
('81', 345, 12, 28, 556585) The period, however, has been inferred from the fact that Gandhiji was at Wardha in December 1941 up to the 9th, when he left for Bardoli.
('81', 346, 0, 1, 556724) VOL. 81 : 18 AUGUST, 1941 8 FEBRUARY, 1942 347
('81', 346, 1, 2, 556771) GANDHIJI.
('81', 346, 1, 3, 556781) I deny absolutely what Jinnah sahib says.
('81', 346, 1, 4, 556823) The Muslim is as much an Indian as I am and of the same blood.
('81', 346, 1, 5, 556886) There is no fundamental cleavage between Hindus and Musalmans.
('81', 346, 1, 6, 556949) We have lived in the same land as brothers for generations and what has been possible all these years will certainly be possible in the future.
('81', 346, 1, 7, 557093) With due respect to Jinnasahib, he resorts unconsciously to an untruth when he says what you have just quoted, and speaks as a disappointed man does in order to maintain his view at any cost.
('81', 346, 1, 8, 557285) In any case, the fear of subservience is quite imaginary.
('81', 346, 1, 9, 557343) No one can dominate a population of 80,000,000. Can such a number be termed a minority?
('81', 346, 1, 10, 557431) I personally would resist the subservience even of the Parsis, who are a mere handful, i.e., 1,00,000 , because I believe in equality for all and has throughout been the Congress creed.
('81', 346, 1, 11, 557617) But I admit that Jinnah sahib’s fear though in fact imaginary is a real thing in his estimation, and therefore he has my sympathy.
('81', 346, 2, 12, 557748) Sir E. What about the possibility of a free and equal India becoming a partner in the British Commonwealth in the sense that Canada and Australia are partners?
('81', 346, 3, 13, 557908) G. Bitter experience has shown that India cannot be that in the sense that Canada and Australia are.
('81', 346, 3, 14, 558009) At the moment the British Common wealth is a Commonwealth of White nations.
('81', 346, 3, 15, 558085) But I go a step further than you.
('81', 346, 3, 16, 558119) Why only a British Commonwealth?
('81', 346, 3, 17, 558152) Whoever is victor, there should be, after the war, a commonwealth of all nations.
('81', 346, 3, 18, 558234) The British Commonwealth must give a place to this and no one must be excluded.
('81', 346, 3, 19, 558314) Germany, Italy, Russia, all must come in, not only those who are today Allies of Britain.
('81', 346, 3, 20, 558404) India will gladly be a member of such a common wealth.
('81', 346, 4, 21, 558459) Sir E. You are indulging in undue optimism.
('81', 346, 4, 22, 558503) I worked seven years for the All Peoples Association in Europe and my experiences there during the last two decades do not lead to hope that the real internationalism is round the corner.
('81', 346, 4, 23, 558691) Anyhow, your and my goal of universal brotherhood is common.
('81', 346, 4, 24, 558752) Is it thus wise to destroy or abolish what has stood for a Commonwealth of at least some nations when the world is not ready for the ultimate ideal?

('81', 353, 7, 12, 573558) 621. “CONSTRUCTIVE PROGRAMME : ITS MEANING AND PLACE” 1
('81', 353, 8, 13, 573614) [December 13, 1941] 2 INTRODUCTORY The constructive programme may otherwise and more fittingly be called construction of poorna swaraj or complete independence by truthful and non violent means.
('81', 353, 8, 14, 573809) Effort for construction of independence so called through violent and, therefore, necessarily untruthful means we know only too painfully.
('81', 353, 8, 15, 573948) Look at the daily destruction of property, life and truth in the present war.
('81', 353, 8, 16, 574026) Complete independence through truth and non violence means the independence of every unit, be it the humblest of the nation, with 
('81', 353, 9, 17, 574157) 1According to Mahatma, Vol. VI, Gandhiji wrote this on the train from Wardha to Bardoli.
('81', 353, 9, 18, 574246) Gandhiji left Sevagram on December 9, 1941, and reached Bardoli on December 10, 1941. However, in his letter to Mirabehn dated December 13, 1941, Gandhiji says, “I was immersed in writing work which is just finished.” Apparently he commenced writing this on the train and finished it later at Bardoli.
('81', 353, 9, 19, 574548) The version reproduced here was “thoroughly revised” and date lined “Poona, 13 11 1945”.
('81', 353, 9, 20, 574637) The Foreword and the two Appendices appear in their chronological places under the dates November 13, 1945, January 16, 1946, and January 27, 1948. 2 ibid
('81', 354, 0, 1, 574792) VOL. 81 : 18 AUGUST, 1941 8 FEBRUARY, 1942 355
('81', 354, 1, 2, 574839) out distinction of race, colour or creed.
('81', 354, 1, 3, 574881) This independence is never exclusive.
('81', 354, 1, 4, 574919) It is, therefore, wholly compatible with interdepen dence within or without.
('81', 354, 1, 5, 574996) Practice will always fall short of the theory, even as the drawn line falls short of the theoretical line of Euclid.
('81', 354, 1, 6, 575113) Therefore, complete independence will be complete only to the extent of our approach in practice to truth and non violence.
('81', 354, 1, 7, 575237) Let the reader mentally plan out the whole of the constructive programme, and he will agree with me that, if it could be successfully worked out, the end of it would be the independence we want.
('81', 354, 1, 8, 575432) Has not Mr. Amery said that an agreement between the major parties, trans lated in my language, any agreement after communal unity which is only one item in the constructive programme, will be respected?
('81', 354, 1, 9, 575636) We need not question his sincerity, for if such unity is honestly, i.e., non violently, attained, it will in itself contain the power to compel acceptance of the agreed demand.
('81', 354, 1, 10, 575813) On the other hand there is no such thing as an imaginary or even perfect definition of independence through violence.
('81', 354, 1, 11, 575931) For it pre supposes only ascendancy of that party of the nation which makes the most effective use of violence.
('81', 354, 1, 12, 576043) In it perfect equality, economic or otherwise, is inconceivable.
('81', 354, 1, 13, 576108) But for my purpose, which is to convince the reader of the necessity of following out the constructive programme in the non violent effort, the acceptance of my argument about the ineffective ness of violence for the attainment of independence is not required.
('81', 354, 1, 14, 576369) The reader is welcome to the belief that independence of this hum blest unit is possible under a scheme of violence, if this effort enables him also to admit that it is a certainty through the complete execution of the programme by the nation.
('81', 354, 1, 15, 576613) Let us now examine the items :
('81', 354, 2, 16, 576644) 1. COMMUNAL UNITY
('81', 354, 3, 17, 576662) Everybody is agreed about the necessity of this unity.
('81', 354, 3, 18, 576717) But everybody does not know that unity does not mean political unity, which may be imposed.
('81', 354, 3, 19, 576809) It means an unbreakable heart unity.
('81', 354, 3, 20, 576846) The first thing essential for achieving such unity is for every Congressman, whatever his religion may be, to represent in his own person Hindu, Muslim, Christian, Zoroastrian, Jew, etc., shortly, every Hindu and non Hindu.
('81', 354, 3, 21, 577070) He has to feel his identity with every one of the millions of the inhabitants of Hindustan.
('81', 354, 3, 22, 577162) In order to realize this, every Con gressman will cultivate personal friendship with persons represent ing faiths other than his own.
('81', 354, 3, 23, 577296) He should have the same regard for the other faiths as he has for his own.
('81', 355, 0, 1, 577371) 356 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('81', 355, 1, 2, 577413) In such a happy state of things there would be no disgraceful cry at the stations such as “Hindu water” and “Muslim water” or “ Hindu tea” and “ Muslim tea”.
('81', 355, 1, 3, 577571) There would be no separate rooms or pots for Hindus and non Hindus in schools and colleges, no communal schools, colleges and hospitals.

('81', 371, 1, 14, 621275) For working out the programme I have sketched for them, the students must find time.

('81', 371, 1, 16, 621417) By strict economy, they can save many hours.
('81', 371, 1, 17, 621462) But I do not want to put an undue strain upon any student.
('81', 371, 1, 18, 621521) I would, therefore, advise patriotic students to lose one year, not at a stretch but spread it over their whole study.
('81', 371, 1, 19, 621640) They will find that one year so given will not be a waste of time.
('81', 371, 1, 20, 621707) The effort will add to their equipment, mental, moral and physical, and they will have made even during their studies a substantial contribution to the freedom movement.
('81', 372, 0, 1, 621877) VOL. 81 : 18 AUGUST, 1941 8 FEBRUARY, 1942 373
('81', 372, 1, 2, 621924) PLACE OF CIVIL DISOBEDIENCE
('81', 372, 2, 3, 621952) I have said in these pages that civil disobedience is not absolutely necessary to win freedom through purely non violent effort, if the co operation of the whole nation is secured in the constructive programme.
('81', 372, 2, 4, 622163) But such good luck rarely favours nations or individuals.
('81', 372, 2, 5, 622221) Therefore, it is necessary to know the place of civil disobedience in a nationwide non violent effort.
('81', 372, 2, 6, 622324) It has three definite functions : 1. It can be effectively offered for the redress of a local wrong.
('81', 372, 2, 7, 622425) 2. It can be offered without regard to effect, though aimed at a particular wrong or evil, by way of self immolation in order to rouse local consciousness or conscience.
('81', 372, 2, 8, 622595) Such was the case in Champaran when I offered civil disobedience without any regard to the effect and well knowing that even the people might remain apathetic.
('81', 372, 2, 9, 622755) That it proved otherwise may be taken, according to taste, as God’s grace or a stroke of good luck.
('81', 372, 2, 10, 622855) 3. In the place of full response to constructive effort, it can be offered as it was in 1941 1. Though it was a contribution to and part of the battle for freedom, it was purposely centred round a particular issue, i.e., free speech.
('81', 372, 2, 11, 623089) Civil disobedience can never be directed for a general cause such as for independence.
('81', 372, 2, 12, 623176) The issue must be definite and capable of being clearly understood and within the power of the opponent to yield.
('81', 372, 2, 13, 623290) This method properly applied must lead to the final goal.
('81', 372, 2, 14, 623348) I have not examined here the full scope and possibilities of civil disobedience.
('81', 372, 2, 15, 623429) I have touched enough of it to enable the reader to understand the connection between the constructive programme and civil disobedience.
('81', 372, 2, 16, 623566) In the first two cases, no elaborate constructive programme was or could be necessary.
('81', 372, 2, 17, 623653) But when civil disobedience is itself devised for the attainment of independence, previous preparation is necessary, and it has to be backed by the visible and conscious effort of those who are engaged in the battle.
('81', 372, 2, 18, 623870) Civil disobedience is thus a stimulation for the fighters and a challenge to the opponent.
('81', 372, 2, 19, 623961) It should be clear to the reader that civil disobedience in terms of independence without the co operation of the millions by way of constructive effort is mere bravado and worse than useless.
('81', 372, 3, 20, 624154) CONCLUSION
('81', 372, 4, 21, 624165) This is not a thesis written on behalf of the Congress or at the instance of the Central Office.
('81', 372, 4, 22, 624262) It is the outcome of conversations I had
('81', 372, 5, 23, 624303) 1 The first edition here has : “as it is being offered at present.”
('81', 373, 0, 1, 624371) 374 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('81', 373, 1, 2, 624413) with some co workers in Sevagram.
('81', 373, 1, 3, 624447) They had felt the want of some thing from my pen showing the connection between the constructive programme and civil disobedience and how the former might be worked.
('81', 373, 1, 4, 624613) I have endeavoured to supply the want in this pamphlet.
('81', 373, 1, 5, 624669) It does not purport to be exhaustive, but it is sufficiently indicative of the way the programme should be worked.
('81', 373, 1, 6, 624784) Let not the reader make the mistake of laughing at any of the items as being part of the movement for independence.
('81', 373, 1, 7, 624900) Many people do many things, big and small, without connecting them with non violence or independence.
('81', 373, 1, 8, 625002) They have then their limited value as expected.
('81', 373, 1, 9, 625050) The same man appearing as a civilian may be of no consequence, but appearing in his capacity as General he is a big personage, holding the lives of millions at his mercy.
('81', 373, 1, 10, 625221) Similarly, the charkha in the hands of a poor widow brings a paltry pice to her, in the hands of a Jawaharlal it is an instrument of India’s freedom.
('81', 373, 1, 11, 625371) It is the office which gives the charkha its dignity.
('81', 373, 1, 12, 625425) It is the office assigned to the constructive programme which gives it an irresistible prestige and power.
('81', 373, 1, 13, 625532) Such at least is my view.
('81', 373, 1, 14, 625558) It may be that of a mad man.
('81', 373, 1, 15, 625587) If it makes no appeal to the Congressman, I must be rejected.
('81', 373, 1, 16, 625649) For my handling of civil disobedience without the constructive programme will be like a paralysed hand attempting to lift a spoon.
('81', 373, 2, 17, 625780) Constructive Programme : Its Meaning and Place
('81', 373, 3, 18, 625827) 622. THE PLACE OF SILK
('81', 373, 4, 19, 625850) Shri Jajuji writes : 1
('81', 373, 5, 20, 625873) All these are good points.
('81', 373, 5, 21, 625900) They have also been pretty well discussed.
('81', 373, 5, 22, 625943) But some questions are raised again and again and need to be discussed again and again.
('81', 373, 5, 23, 626031) I shall answer the questions in the order in which they have been asked.
('81', 373, 5, 24, 626104) (1) The question of violence and non violence does arise, for there is violent silk and non violent silk.
('81', 373, 5, 25, 626210) The best thing of course is for people who like to consider everything from the point of view of
('81', 373, 6, 26, 626307) 1 The letter is not translated here.
('81', 373, 6, 27, 626344) Shrikrishnadas Jaju, Secretary, All India Spinners’ Association, had formulated the following views and sought Gandhiji’s opinion on them : (1) Bearing in mind that sericulture involves violence, the worker should give it at best secondary importance; (2) silk competes with fine khadi; (3) it tends to make people luxury loving; and (4) it calls for a much larger capital outlay.
('81', 374, 0, 1, 626725) VOL. 81 : 18 AUGUST, 1941 8 FEBRUARY, 1942 375
('81', 374, 1, 2, 626772) non violence to give up silk altogether.
('81', 374, 1, 3, 626813) But from the point of view of khadi we should not raise this question.
('81', 374, 1, 4, 626884) We should stock both kinds of silk in our bhandars, though we should give encouragement only to non violent silk.
('81', 374, 1, 5, 626998) (2) We should never allow silk to reach a point where it can compete with khadi.
('81', 374, 1, 6, 627079) The idea behind giving a place to silk was that it should supplement khadi.
('81', 374, 1, 7, 627155) It has also been the view that hand spun silk is always to be preferred to foreign silk and silk manufactured in Indian mills.
('81', 374, 1, 8, 627282) But silk must never be given the place of cotton cloth.
('81', 374, 1, 9, 627338) That is why a limit has been put upon the quantity of silk to be stocked in khadi bhandars.
('81', 374, 1, 10, 627430) (3) This is not an important point.
('81', 374, 1, 11, 627466) In a way even Andhra khadi, coloured khadi and khadi with woven designs make us luxury loving.
('81', 374, 1, 12, 627561) Khadi is as much for the fastidious as it is for the poor.
('81', 374, 1, 13, 627620) From the very beginning it has been our endeavour to introduce into khadi as much beauty and decoration as we can.
('81', 374, 1, 14, 627735) We display this at every khadi exhibition.
('81', 374, 1, 15, 627778) We have been showing progress in the appearance of khadi every year.
('81', 374, 1, 16, 627847) This was and still is the correct [attitude].
('81', 374, 1, 17, 627893) Khadi mindedness does not mean that art and design should have no place in khadi, and that it is to be only the attire of the poor.
('81', 374, 1, 18, 628025) Therefore the restraint we should place on ourselves here is that we should put what art and design we can into khadi and be satisfied.
('81', 374, 1, 19, 628161) From this point of view silk is to be and should be discarded.
('81', 374, 1, 20, 628224) From this point of view too we compare the fine Andhra khadi with silk.
('81', 374, 1, 21, 628296) Then the silk lovers say they find silk cheaper than the Andhra khadi.
('81', 374, 1, 22, 628367) I answer that we cannot advance the work of khadi in this way.
('81', 374, 1, 23, 628430) Khadi, though it may be costly, comes out cheap in the end.
('81', 374, 1, 24, 628490) (4) If silk making calls for twice as large a capital outlay, we have a very strong reason for giving it up.
('81', 374, 1, 25, 628599) But having regard to human nature we do not or cannot wholly renounce silk.
('81', 374, 1, 26, 628675) In our definition of khadi we have given a place to hand spun silk and hand spun wool.
('81', 374, 1, 27, 628762) But we cannot encourage woollens and silk with a view to increasing profits.
('81', 374, 1, 28, 628839) There will have to be some restraint in regard to these.
('81', 374, 1, 29, 628896) Service of the millions is possible only through cotton khadi.

('81', 381, 11, 20, 637766) 638. SPEECH AT A. I. S. A. MEETING BARDOLI, December 17, 1941 I had received Jajuji’s letter 2 many days ago.

('81', 384, 3, 6, 643941) 640. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('81', 384, 4, 7, 643969) BARDOLI, December 19, 1941 As the war approaches the Indian border, people begin to get scared.
('81', 384, 4, 8, 644065) I have a typical letter from Assam and others from various parts.
('81', 384, 4, 9, 644131) They expect guidance from me as a war resister and director of satyagraha.
('81', 384, 4, 10, 644206) So far as satyagraha is concerned, in areas such as Assam responsible Congressmen should not offer satyagraha but should devote themselves to steadying those who are under Congress influence.
('81', 384, 4, 11, 644398) As to the guidance of those who would listen to the Congress or me, the people will presently have directions from the Working Committee.
('81', 384, 4, 12, 644536) But so far as I am concerned, I am quite clear that the people should refuse to be scared even though bombs may be dropped in their midst.
('81', 384, 4, 13, 644675) For the time being at any rate the danger is to be expected only in the big cities.
('81', 384, 4, 14, 644759) Those who do not wish to run any risk would do well quietly to leave their cities.
('81', 384, 4, 15, 644842) It is wrong to make a rush on every scare and crowd the railway stations.
('81', 384, 4, 16, 644916) The railway staff cannot possibly cope with sudden rushes.
('81', 384, 4, 17, 644975) It is unmanly to rush for saving oneself.
('81', 384, 4, 18, 645017) A wise and brave man will wait till the last man is safely out.
('81', 384, 4, 19, 645081) What I have said applies to all Con gressmen and others.
('81', 384, 4, 20, 645138) I would not like it to be said of us as a nation that we run about like mad men on the approach of the slightest danger.
('81', 384, 4, 21, 645259) We must face bravely any situation that may befall us.
('81', 384, 4, 22, 645314) Congressmen who are war resisters will remain at their posts and offer such assistance to the people as is within their power.
('81', 384, 4, 23, 645441) They will run, at any risk, to the help of those who may be injured.
('81', 384, 4, 24, 645510) Whilst I have been and am still against Congressmen joining A.R.P., I have never thought or suggested that Congressmen should leave points of danger or fields of service.

('81', 386, 1, 2, 647088) 643. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS 1
('81', 386, 2, 3, 647118) BARDOLI, December 20, 1941 I have been asked for a brief statement on the entry of America in the war.
('81', 386, 2, 4, 647221) It is not possible for me to join the chorus of current opinion.
('81', 386, 2, 5, 647286) I cannot welcome this entry of America.
('81', 386, 2, 6, 647326) American tradition singles her out as an arbitrator and mediator between the warring nations.
('81', 386, 2, 7, 647420) By her territorial vastness, amazing energy, unrivalled finan cial status and owing to the composite character of her people she is the one country which could have saved the world from the unthinkable butchery that is going on.
('81', 386, 2, 8, 647649) I do not know whether America could have avoided the entry.
('81', 386, 2, 9, 647709) I have no data for giving a decisive opinion on the question.
('81', 386, 2, 10, 647771) I have only expressed my fervent wish that it might have been possible for her to play her natural part.
('81', 386, 2, 11, 647876) It is tragic to contemplate that with America as party to the war there is no great Power left which can mediate and bring about peace for which I have no doubt the peoples of all lands are thirsting.
('81', 386, 2, 12, 648077) It is a strange phenomenon that the human wish is paralysed by the creeping effect of the war fever.

('81', 390, 3, 9, 653715) 651. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS BARDOLI, December 27, 1941 The action of the Bihar Government in banning the meeting of the Hindu Mahasabha has always appeared to me to be inexplicable.
('81', 390, 3, 10, 653897) 2 Those who had proclaimed their desire to hold the meeting were responsible men and, what is more, so far as I am aware, trusted by the Central Government and known to be pro Government.
('81', 390, 3, 11, 654085) They had and have identified themselves with the war effort.
('81', 390, 3, 12, 654146) Why such people could not be trusted by the Bihar Provincial Government to behave decently passes my comprehension.
('81', 390, 3, 13, 654262) I see that Vir Savarkar 3 had accommodated the Bihar authorities to the extent of postponing the session with a view to coming to an understanding.
('81', 390, 3, 14, 654410) When all attempts at a settlement failed, civil resistance was the only remedy open to the suppressed Hindu Mahasabha.
('81', 390, 3, 15, 654529) And I must confess it fills me with delight to find Vir Savarkar, Dr. Moonje and other leaders being arrested 4 in their attempt to assert the very primary and very fundamental right of holding an orderly meeting subject to all reasonable restrictions about the preservation of the public peace.

('81', 395, 1, 2, 661197) 660. DISCUSSION AT WORKING COMMITTEE MEETING 1
('81', 395, 2, 3, 661244) [On or before December 30, 1940] 2
('81', 395, 3, 4, 661279) So far as I am concerned, even if I was given the utmost power conceivable, even if I was made the Viceroy of India today, would I ask the people of India to take up the sword to keep the Empire alive?
('81', 395, 3, 5, 661481) I for one should feel that I was committing moral suicide in that I would be abandoning the faith of a lifetime, the faith which I had persuaded the Congress to accept for twenty years as a policy.
('81', 395, 3, 6, 661679) The steady unflinching pursuit of that policy has brought us quite close to the achievement of the objective.
('81', 395, 3, 7, 661789) Am I to abandon the very boat which has brought me quite close to the shore?
('81', 395, 3, 8, 661866) Yudhishthira 3 would not forsake his faithful dog and enter the gates of Heaven without him.
('81', 395, 3, 9, 661959) For he knew that the Kingdom of Heaven would be as naught to him without the dog, i.e., his faith.
('81', 395, 3, 10, 662058) Would the Arab (i.e., the Congress) give up towards the end of the journey the faithful steed (i.e., non violence) that had made it possible for [him] 4 to make that journey?
('81', 395, 3, 11, 662233) It would be an act of betrayal or faithlessness on my part.
('81', 395, 3, 12, 662293) Could I, when the war is at my door and when I am in the same predicament as they, forget the sovereign remedy I suggested to them 5 and clutch at the
('81', 395, 4, 13, 662444) 1 In his article “The Month in Bardoli—I” from which this discussion is reproduced, Mahadev Desai gives the following introduction : “Though the actual decision [of the Working Committee] came to be made on the basis of the interpretation of the Bombay Resolution, what was of vital importance was the actual feeling in the minds of men.
('81', 395, 4, 14, 662782) No matter how the Bombay Resolution was interpreted, were we clear about certain fundamentals?
('81', 395, 4, 15, 662877) Were we clear that the policy of non violence that we had followed, to the best of our ability, for twenty years was no religious creed or for no religious purpose, but a wholly political method for the achievement of the political independence of India?
('81', 395, 4, 16, 663132) Gandhiji had no doubt on the question.

('81', 396, 1, 2, 663974) method I have denounced and discarded?
('81', 396, 1, 3, 664013) No matter what the country would say, what should be the attitude of individual Congressmen who had sworn by the method of non violence?
('81', 396, 2, 4, 664150) He was clear that, if it was felt that we had committed a mistake, that it was worth while bargaining a principle for what seemed to be a richer gain, they should declare their conviction, and if and when the objective was gained, they should convert the whole of India into a recruiting ground, ask every man and woman to contribute his or her share in the war effort, and even extinguish themselves in so doing.
('81', 396, 2, 5, 664564) What was needed was downright honesty.
('81', 396, 2, 6, 664603) He at any rate had never conceived this possibility.
('81', 396, 2, 7, 664656) If he knew that some day India would have to engage in a violent war in order to win independence, he would long ago have addressed every youth to go in for military discipline, and he would not have placed tireless emphasis, day in and day out, on the various items of the constructive programme.

('81', 396, 3, 9, 664973) 661. LETTER TO ABUL KALAM AZAD
('81', 396, 4, 10, 665004) BARDOLI, December 30, 1941
('81', 396, 5, 11, 665031) DEAR MAULANA SAHIB, In the course of discussion in the Working Committee, I discov ered that I had committed a grave error in the interpretation of the Bombay Resolution.
('81', 396, 5, 12, 665202) I had interpreted it to mean that the Congress was to refuse participation in the present or all wars on the ground principally of non violence.
('81', 396, 5, 13, 665347) I found to my astonishment that most members differed from my interpretation and held that the opposition need not be on the ground of non violence.
('81', 396, 5, 14, 665496) On rereading the Bombay Resolution I found that the differing members were right and that I had read into it a meaning which its letter could not bear.
('81', 396, 5, 15, 665648) The discovery of the error makes it impossible for me to lead the Congress in the struggle for resistance to war effort on grounds in which non violence was not indispensable.
('81', 396, 5, 16, 665824) I could not, for instance, identify myself with opposition to war effort on the ground of ill will against Great Britain.
('81', 396, 5, 17, 665946) The resolution contemplated material association with Britain in the war effort as a price for guaranteed independence of India.
('81', 396, 5, 18, 666075) If such was my view, and I believed in the use of violence for gaining independence and yet refused participation in the effort as the price of that independence, I would consider myself guilty of unpatriotic conduct.
('81', 396, 5, 19, 666293) It is my certain belief that only non violence can save India and the world from self extinction.
('81', 396, 5, 20, 666391) Such being the case, I must continue my mission whether I am alone or assisted by an organization or individuals.
('81', 396, 5, 21, 666505) You will, therefore, please relieve me of the responsibility laid upon me by the Bombay Resolution.
('81', 397, 0, 1, 666605) 398 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('81', 397, 1, 2, 666647) continue civil disobedience for free speech against all war with such Congressmen and others whom I select and who believe in the non violence I have contemplated and are willing to conform to prescribed conditions.
('81', 397, 1, 3, 666863) I will not, at this critical period, select for civil disobedience those whose services are required to steady and help the people in their respective localities.
('81', 397, 2, 4, 667026) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI

('81', 397, 4, 8, 667170) 662. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('81', 397, 5, 9, 667198) BARDOLI, December 30, 1941 If anyone had thought, as I had thought, that the door to Congress participation in the present war on the ground of Congress non violence was closed for ever by the Bombay Resolution, then they may now know that the Bombay Resolution had not quite closed the door.
('81', 397, 5, 10, 667491) Undoubtedly, as the resolution said, the Poona resolution had lapsed, therefore, the Poona offer had lapsed.
('81', 397, 5, 11, 667600) But the Congress has now, through the Working Committee, made it clear that the door is not barred altogether against Congress participation, certainly not on the ground of non violence.
('81', 397, 5, 12, 667787) The key for unlocking the door remains principally in the hands of the British Government.
('81', 397, 5, 13, 667878) The Working Committtee has very properly declined to state the terms on which that door can be opened.
('81', 397, 5, 14, 667981) It will depend upon varying circumstances, but, in my opinion, the chief circumstance is the Government.
('81', 397, 5, 15, 668086) Having been insulted often enough, the Working Committee would not court any further insult by making any offer.
('81', 397, 5, 16, 668199) After all, its position is absolutely clear.
('81', 397, 5, 17, 668244) Everbody knows what the Congress stands for and what it wants.
('81', 397, 5, 18, 668307) Everyone should, therefore, know that nothing will be accepted by the Congress short of what it stands for.
('81', 397, 5, 19, 668415) Therefore, the burden of the next step is cast on the Government.
('81', 397, 5, 20, 668481) This is the chief thing that is relevant at the present time.
('81', 397, 5, 21, 668543) I have a pressing cable from those English friends who are interested in India’s freedom and who are lovers of their own people.
('81', 397, 6, 22, 668672) 1 For the Congress Working Committee’s resolution in response to this, vide Appendix “Congres Working Committee’s Resolution”, 30 12 1941.
('81', 398, 0, 1, 668811) VOL. 81 : 18 AUGUST, 1941 8 FEBRUARY, 1942 399
('81', 398, 1, 2, 668858) I have not replied to that cable.
('81', 398, 1, 3, 668892) They have reminded me of Mr. Andrews’ legacy.
('81', 398, 1, 4, 668938) Whatever the meaning of their reminder, my mean ing could only be one.
('81', 398, 1, 5, 669009) The one indissoluble bond between Charlie Andrews and myself was that we would never compromise our cons cience on any account whatsoever.
('81', 398, 1, 6, 669148) And, in all that I have done, I can fearlessly claim that I have been guided by my conscience.
('81', 398, 1, 7, 669243) I have made it clear in my letter 1 to the Maulana Sahib that I could not possibly identify myself with the door to participation being kept open in any shape or form, because that would mean, in my opinion, a recantation of all that the Congress has stood for the last twenty years or more.
('81', 398, 1, 8, 669535) I would not be guilty of selling that heritage even for the independence of India because it would not be real independence.
('81', 398, 1, 9, 669660) I feel that if any country has a message for the world, which is groaning under violence unknown perhaps to history, it is India.
('81', 398, 1, 10, 669790) When India, through the Indian National Congress, accepted the policy of non violence, so far as I know, no Congressman had thought that another war—and such a bloody war—was to come so soon as it has.
('81', 398, 1, 11, 669992) The testing time, however, has come for India and I, who have an unchangeable belief in the efficacy of non violence for the present distemper from which mankind is suffering, could not possibly in any manner, directly or indirectly, associate myself with participation in the war; and so I have stood out.
('81', 398, 1, 12, 670299) But the Congress contains men and women holding varying shades of opinion and, therefore, it should be no wonder that the Working Committee represents those varying shades of opinion.
('81', 398, 1, 13, 670483) It has at least three bodies or, rather, it has at least three bodies representing three schools of thought: a minority party, believing in non partici pation on the ground of non violence, pure and simple; the other believing that the Congress should not carry non violence to the point of refusing association in the war under any circumstances and there is the third, which has many reasons almost as strong as the decisive reason of non violence guiding the minority.
('81', 398, 1, 14, 670955) The resolution 2 which has been just handed by the Secretary of the Working Committee to the Press is a resultant of the efforts of these bodies.
('81', 398, 1, 15, 671101) I would like the public and Congressmen to read that resolution in that light.
('81', 398, 1, 16, 671180) I hope everybody will appreciate the fact that the Working Committee has not come to any hasty decision.
('81', 398, 1, 17, 671285) It did not mind what time it took in order
('81', 398, 2, 18, 671328) 1 Vide the preceding item.
('81', 398, 2, 19, 671355) 2 Vide Appendix “Congres Working Committee’s Resolution”, 30 12 1941.
('81', 399, 0, 1, 671425) 400 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('81', 399, 1, 2, 671467) to produce a resolution worthy of the great national organization that it represents.
('81', 399, 1, 3, 671553) I would say one thing to Congressmen that those who are believers in non violence in the same sense that I am, have nothing to fear, as I interpret the resolution of the Working Committee.
('81', 399, 1, 4, 671742) It not only leaves them absolutely free to hold that opinion but to propagate it for the acceptance of anybody who chooses.
('81', 399, 1, 5, 671866) Only they remain in the Congress so long as the Congress is not called upon to participate in the war effort.
('81', 399, 1, 6, 671976) It is open to them to convert all Congressmen to their view.
('81', 399, 1, 7, 672037) I am quite sure that the Working Committee will welcome such a conversion but I would warn Congressmen against indecision at this critical period in the national life and I would warn them also against weakly following this party or that for the sake of gaining power in the Congress.
('81', 399, 1, 8, 672322) Those who do so will miserably fail to gain power for the nation.
('81', 399, 1, 9, 672388) Personally, I would like the Congress, as I would like the whole world, to accept non violence as the law of life in every department, social, political and domestic.
('81', 399, 1, 10, 672555) But there is no room for cowardliness.
('81', 399, 1, 11, 672594) I would far rather that we all became violent than cowards.
('81', 399, 1, 12, 672654) Let me hope, therefore, that every Congressman will have his own convictions and the courage to enforce them.
('81', 399, 1, 13, 672764) The Hindu, 31 12 1941
