('81', 490, 1, 2, 872767) 746. QUESTION BOX
('81', 490, 2, 3, 872785) HINDU MUSLIM PUZZLE
('81', 490, 3, 4, 872805) Q. In your proposed solution of the Hindu Muslim puzzle 1, do you expect all the Hindus to abstain from the legislatures or only a part?
('81', 490, 3, 5, 872942) If only a part, will not the most reactionary Hindus get in and make things worse than now?
('81', 490, 3, 6, 873034) And if you expect Congressmen to affect the Muslim mind from outside, why can’t you do the same and perhaps more effectively by being inside?
('81', 490, 4, 7, 873176) A. I do not expect all the Hindus to abstain.
('81', 490, 4, 8, 873222) I know that all Hindu seats will be filled by non Congress Hindus.
('81', 490, 4, 9, 873289) Congress Hindus, if they go in, will be ground down between the two stones of the communal chakki 2 without doing any good to anybody.
('81', 490, 4, 10, 873424) I do not approach the question as a Hindu.
('81', 490, 4, 11, 873467) I approach it as a Congressman seeking to represent equally all communities.
('81', 490, 4, 12, 873544) But for the artificial system introduced in the composition of the Indian legislatures, all the members would be representing not communities but their parties grouped according to their non communal shibboleths.
('81', 490, 4, 13, 873757) As one repre senting all communities I would expect not only Hindus but Con gress minded Muslims and others too to avoid the legislatures and elective bodies.
('81', 490, 4, 14, 873916) These abstainers will hold the scales evenly between all communities and seek to affect the legislatures from outside.
('81', 490, 4, 15, 874035) Whether they are many or only a few, they will play the role of wise men.
('81', 490, 4, 16, 874109) If all listened to me, the communal question would disappear from our midst.
('81', 490, 4, 17, 874186) By entering the legislatures the Congress Hindus become inter lopers, and act weakly for fear of offending one party or the other.
('81', 490, 4, 18, 874317) This I know, that at the present moment the legislatures are, and must become, part of the war machinery.
('81', 490, 4, 19, 874423) They have no choice.
('81', 490, 4, 20, 874444) They will not be allowed to function, if they obstruct the war effort.
('81', 490, 4, 21, 874515) How could the rulers whose sole occupation is to prosecute the war do otherwise?
('81', 490, 5, 22, 874596) WHY NOT IN HINDU MAJORITY PROVINCES?
('81', 490, 6, 23, 874633) Q. Why not advise Congressmen to withdraw from the provincial legisla tures too where the Hindus are in a majority?
('81', 490, 7, 24, 874749) A. Because I do not want the non Muslim minority parties to act as if they were the majority and carry on the government in these provinces.
('81', 490, 7, 25, 874890) It would be a false position to which the Congress would be
('81', 490, 8, 26, 874950) 1 Vide “Communal Unity”, 20 1 1942.
('81', 490, 9, 27, 874986) 2 Grinding stone
('81', 491, 0, 1, 875003) 492 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('81', 491, 1, 2, 875045) a willing party, if the Congress members withdrew.
('81', 491, 1, 3, 875096) In these provinces, therefore, abstention cannot solve the communal tangle, and will bring about an unintended and undesirable state of things.
('81', 491, 2, 4, 875240) TORTURING THE LANGUAGE?
('81', 491, 3, 5, 875264) Q. Surely you are torturing the language when you use the world “unitary” in the place of ‘unilateral’.
('81', 491, 3, 6, 875368) 1 For that is obviously what you mean.
('81', 491, 4, 7, 875407) A. I must plead not guilty.‘Unilateral’ has a definite legal meaning which does not fit in with what I am struggling to convey.
('81', 491, 4, 8, 875535) It is not onesidedness.
('81', 491, 4, 9, 875559) It is no sidedness.
('81', 491, 4, 10, 875579) It has impartiality implied in it.
('81', 491, 4, 11, 875614) But it is not the method of impartiality.
('81', 491, 4, 12, 875656) It is something more.
('81', 491, 4, 13, 875678) I represent a party, say, the Congress.
('81', 491, 4, 14, 875718) For the solution of the problem I apply a method whereby I seek to affect those who are estranged from me.
('81', 491, 4, 15, 875825) I am not merely impartial, because I may or may not please them.
('81', 491, 4, 16, 875890) Impartiality has to be felt by the aggrieved party.
('81', 491, 4, 17, 875942) I go the utmost length to placate the offended party, and trust my out and out pure conduct to affect them.
('81', 491, 4, 18, 876050) I may not succeed at once.
('81', 491, 4, 19, 876077) But if there is a real sense of justice in the method, it must succeed.
('81', 491, 4, 20, 876149) For want of a better word I have called the method “unitary”.
('81', 491, 4, 21, 876211) The dictionary meaning satisfies my test which I have imperfectly described here.

('81', 492, 3, 4, 876881) Did Gandhiji mean to say that even as khadi saved the Indian mill cloth, the
('81', 492, 4, 5, 876958) protection of the cow would mean the protection of the buffalo?
('81', 492, 5, 6, 877022) Gandhiji said : Yes, but I mean something more.
('81', 492, 5, 7, 877070) I have often said that I should not shed a single tear, if all the mills were to be destroyed.
('81', 492, 5, 8, 877165) I would never say this regarding the buffalo.
('81', 492, 6, 9, 877211) Explaining the matter at greater length he said : No, my point is that, unless we protect the cow today, we will fail to save both the cow and the buffalo.
('81', 492, 6, 10, 877367) And it is not possible to make a combined endeavour to save both.
('81', 492, 6, 11, 877433) The combined endeavour will result in the buffalo devouring the cow.
('81', 492, 6, 12, 877502) The cow is the more neg lected animal, and that is why we should concentrate on the cow.
('81', 492, 6, 13, 877591) But not even if Jamnalalji got a few crores of rupees can we achieve our object until we have converted the people to our view—especially the people who run goshalas and pinjrapoles.
('81', 492, 6, 14, 877774) There is no question of ‘boycott’, much less of the killing of buffaloes.
('81', 492, 6, 15, 877848) Slaughter is a thing that suggests itself easily to Western economists.
('81', 492, 6, 16, 877920) That is why they cut the Gordian knot by slaughtering the inferior breed of cows and bulls.
('81', 492, 6, 17, 878012) But that solution is not good for me.
('81', 492, 6, 18, 878050) It is my firm conviction that, if we master the real science of saving the cow, the science of saving the buffalo and other animals would automatically be revealed to us.
('81', 492, 6, 19, 878221) [Q.] But, supposing you were to boycott all the buffaloes in Sevagram, what
('81', 492, 7, 20, 878297) would happen to them and their owners?
('81', 492, 7, 21, 878336) I promise to take charge of the buffalo in case you succeed in your mission of the cow to that extent.

('81', 493, 1, 2, 878821) close down the mills, I shall dance with joy, but not if the owners of the buffaloes were to slaughter them.
('81', 493, 1, 3, 878930) Western economics is divorced from ethics; our ethics and economics coincide or should, if they do not.

('81', 494, 1, 2, 880749) 749. TO CORRESPONDENTS
('81', 494, 2, 3, 880772) Correspondents will please note that I neither open nor read all the correspondence that comes to me.
('81', 494, 2, 4, 880874) And now that I have taken up the care of the three weeklies, the fewest possible letters are put before me, and even those I often do not get the time to read.
('81', 494, 2, 5, 881034) Correspondents should regard the weeklies as my public letter to them.
('81', 494, 2, 6, 881105) Therefore they may not as a rule expect personal replies.
('81', 494, 2, 7, 881163) Many apply for admission to the Sevagram Ashram.
('81', 494, 2, 8, 881212) For one thing there is hardly room for further admissions.
('81', 494, 2, 9, 881271) Some insist on replies in my own hand.
('81', 494, 2, 10, 881310) It is not possible to satisfy this desire, much as I should like to.
('81', 494, 2, 11, 881379) I would therefore request all correspondents to spare me and my overworked assistants as much as possible.

('81', 500, 5, 11, 890603) 760. NOTES
('81', 500, 6, 12, 890614) MISBEHAVIOUR OF TROOPS
('81', 500, 7, 13, 890637) I have piteous letters from correspondents complaining of misbehaviour by troops, white and Indian.
('81', 500, 7, 14, 890737) There are detailed letters from Dohad and Rutlam stations and others too.
('81', 500, 7, 15, 890811) The troops are said to have molested the hawkers on the platforms, helped themselves to eatables and hit the salesmen who protested.
('81', 500, 7, 16, 890944) The station masters were powerless to afford protection.
('81', 500, 7, 17, 891001) I do not know how much credit is to be attached to the descriptions I have received.
('81', 500, 7, 18, 891086) The evidence is so detailed and given with so much moderation as to command belief.
('81', 500, 7, 19, 891170) Anyway I draw the attention of the authorities to the complaints.
('81', 500, 7, 20, 891236) Any such misbehaviour should be put down summarily and repetition made practically impossible, If panic is to be prevented and bitterness avoided.
('81', 500, 7, 21, 891383) I would advise the aggrieved parties to lodge their complaints to the proper authorities with authentic evidence in support.

('81', 501, 0, 1, 891687) 502 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('81', 501, 1, 2, 891729) Some of the workers of the Hyderabad State Congress which was banned on 2nd March, 1940, offered individual satygraha in the month of September 1940. .
('81', 501, 1, 3, 891881) The Government of H.E.H. the Nizam released them unconditionally on 16th December, 1941. Immediately after the release, I issued a statement saying.
('81', 501, 1, 4, 892030) that it was incumbent upon us to continue the satyagraha till our demend for lifting the ban was conceded by the Government.
('81', 501, 1, 5, 892155) After our release we consulted Mahatmaji and.
('81', 501, 1, 6, 892201) he advised us to abstain from re offering satyagraha at this hour, and directed us to concentrate our energies wholly on the constructive programme.
('81', 501, 1, 7, 892350) We therefore appeal to the people in general and workers in particular to devote their energies to this programme.
('81', 501, 1, 8, 892465) This suspension, however, does not mean any alteration in our goal which is the attainment of responsible government under the aegis of H.E.H. the Nizam and the Asafjahi Dynasty.
('81', 501, 1, 9, 892644) How I wish the Government of H. E. H. the Nizam would remove the ban.
('81', 501, 1, 10, 892714) They cannot wish to prevent people from carrying on a constitutional movement in favour of responsible government under the aegis of H. E. H. the Nizam.
('81', 501, 1, 11, 892867) The recent release of the satyagrahis loses all grace if the ban on the State Congress is not removed.
('81', 501, 1, 12, 892970) SEVAGRAM, February 8, 1942 Harijan, 15 2 1942
('81', 501, 2, 13, 893016) 761. NOT NECESSARILY IMPURE
('81', 501, 3, 14, 893044) Thus writes Shri Shankerrao Dev:
('81', 501, 4, 15, 893077) In the last issue of Harijan, in your article “A Deplorable Incident” 1 you say to the rich: “Earn your crores by all means.
('81', 501, 4, 16, 893202) But understand that your wealth is not yours; it belongs to the people.
('81', 501, 4, 17, 893274) Take what you require for your legitimate needs, and use the remainder for society.” When I read this, the first question that arose in my mind was: ‘Why first earn crores and then use them for society?’ As society today is constituted the means of earning crores are bound to be impure; and one who earns crores by impure means cannot be expected to follow the mantra — because in the very process of earning crores by impure means the man’s character is bound to be tainted or vitiated.
('81', 501, 4, 18, 893763) And moreover you have always been emphasizing the purity of means.
('81', 501, 4, 19, 893830) But I am afraid that there is a possibility of people misunderstanding that you are laying an emphasis here more on the ends than on the means.
('81', 501, 5, 20, 893974) I request you to emphasize as much, if not more, on the purity of means of earning money as on spending.
('81', 501, 5, 21, 894079) If purity of means is strictly observed, then, according to me, crores could not be accumulated at all and the difficulty of
('81', 501, 6, 22, 894204) 1 Vide “A Deplorable Incident”, 25 1 1942.
('81', 502, 0, 1, 894247) VOL. 81 : 18 AUGUST, 1941 8 FEBRUARY, 1942 503
('81', 502, 1, 2, 894294) spending for society will assume a very minor prospect.
('81', 502, 1, 3, 894350) I must demur.
('81', 502, 1, 4, 894364) Surely a man may conceivable make crores through strictly pure means, assuming that a man may legitimately possess riches.
('81', 502, 1, 5, 894487) For the purpose of my argument, I have assumed that private possession itself is not held to be impure.
('81', 502, 1, 6, 894591) If I own a mining lease and I tumble upon a diamond of rare value, I may suddenly find myself a millionaire without being held guilty of having used impure means.
('81', 502, 1, 7, 894754) This actually happened when Cullinan diamond, much more valuable than the Kohinoor, was found.
('81', 502, 1, 8, 894849) Such instances can be easily multiplied.
('81', 502, 1, 9, 894890) My argument was surely addressed to such men.
('81', 502, 1, 10, 894936) I have no hesitation in endorsing the proposition that generally rich men and for that matter most men are not particular as to the way they make money.
('81', 502, 1, 11, 895089) In the application of the method of non violence one must believe in the possibility of every person, however depraved, being reformed under humane and skilled treatment.
('81', 502, 1, 12, 895260) We must appeal to the good in human beings and expect response.
('81', 502, 1, 13, 895324) Is it not conducive to the well being of society that every member uses all his talents, only not for personal aggrandisement but for the good of all?
('81', 502, 1, 14, 895475) We do not want to produce dead equality where every person becomes or is rendered incapable of using his ability to the utmost possible extent.
('81', 502, 1, 15, 895619) Such a society must ultimately perish.
('81', 502, 1, 16, 895658) I therefore suggest that my advice that monied men may earn their crores (honestly only, of course) but so as to dedicate them to the service of all is perfectly sound
('81', 502, 2, 17, 895826) — is a mantra based on uncommon knowledge.
('81', 502, 2, 18, 895869) It is the surest method to evolve a new order or life of universal benefit in the place of the present one where each one lives for himself without regard to what happens to his neighbour.
('81', 502, 2, 19, 896058) SEVAGRAM, February 8, 1942 Harijan, 22 2 1942
('81', 502, 3, 20, 896104) 762. INDIVIDUAL OR COLLECTIVE?
('81', 502, 4, 21, 896135) Shri Jamnalal Bajaj has bravely taken the burden of the great work of cow service (in other words, cattle preservation) on his shoulders.
('81', 502, 4, 22, 896273) The most important question for consideration before the recent Goseva Sangh Conference 2 was whether cow farming should be in the hands of individuals or done collectively.
('81', 502, 4, 23, 896447) I myself had no hesitaton in saying that she could never be saved by individual
('81', 502, 5, 24, 896527) 1 The Hindi original of this appeared in Harijan Sevak, 15 2 1942. 2 Held on February 1, 1942
('81', 503, 0, 1, 896621) 504 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('81', 503, 1, 2, 896663) farming.
('81', 503, 1, 3, 896672) Her salvation, and with her that of the buffalo, could only be brought about by collective endeavour.
('81', 503, 1, 4, 896774) It is quite impossible for an individual farmer to look after the welfare of his cattle in his own home in a proper and scientific manner.
('81', 503, 1, 5, 896913) Amongst other causes lack of collective effort has been a principal cause of the deterioration of the cow and hence of cattle in general.
('81', 503, 2, 6, 897051) The world today is moving towards the ideal of collective or co operative effort in every department of life.
('81', 503, 2, 7, 897161) Much in this line has been and is being accomplished.
('81', 503, 2, 8, 897215) It has come into our country also, but in such a distorted form that our poor have not been able to reap its benefits.
('81', 503, 2, 9, 897334) Pari passu with the increase in our popultion land holdings of the average farmer are daily decreasing.
('81', 503, 2, 10, 897438) Moreover, what the individual possesses is often fragmentary.
('81', 503, 2, 11, 897500) 2 For such farmers to keep cattle in their homes is a suicidal policy; and yet this is their condition today.
('81', 503, 2, 12, 897610) Those who give the first place to economics and pay scant attention to religious, ethical or humanitarian considerations proclaim from the house tops that the farmer is being devoured by his cattle due to the cost of their feed which is out of all proporation to what they yield.
('81', 503, 2, 13, 897890) They say it is folly not to slaughter wholesale all useless animals.
('81', 503, 2, 14, 897959) What then should be done by humanitarians is the question.
('81', 503, 2, 15, 898018) The answer obviously is to find a way whereby we may not only save the lives of our cattle but also see that do not become a burden.
('81', 503, 2, 16, 898151) I am sure that co operative effort can help us in a large measure.
('81', 503, 2, 17, 898218) The following comparison may be helpful: 1. Under the collective system no farmer can keep cattle in his house as he does today.
('81', 503, 2, 18, 898347) They foul the air and dirty the surroundings.
('81', 503, 2, 19, 898393) There is neither intelligence nor humanitarianism in living with animals.
('81', 503, 2, 20, 898467) Man was not meant to do so.
('81', 503, 2, 21, 898495) The space taken up by the cattle today would be spared to the farmer and his family if the collective system were adopted.
('81', 503, 2, 22, 898618) 2. As the number of cattle increases, life becomes impossible for the farmer in his home.
('81', 503, 2, 23, 898708) Hence he is obliged to sell the calves and kill the male buffaloes or else turn them out to starve and die.
('81', 503, 2, 24, 898816) This inhumanity would be averted, if the care of cattle were undertaken on
('81', 503, 3, 25, 898891) 1 The Hindi here adds: “This burden is no doubt beyond the strength of an individual farmer.” 2 The Hindi here adds: “And whatever little he has only adds to his pro blems.”
('81', 504, 0, 1, 899065) VOL. 81 : 18 AUGUST, 1941 8 FEBRUARY, 1942 505
('81', 504, 1, 2, 899112) a co operative basis.
('81', 504, 1, 3, 899134) 3. Collective cattle farming would ensure the supply of veterinary treatment to animals when they are ill.
('81', 504, 1, 4, 899241) No ordinary farmer can afford this on his own.
('81', 504, 1, 5, 899288) 4. Similarly one selected bull can be easily kept for the need of several cows under the collective system.
('81', 504, 1, 6, 899396) This is impossible otherwise except for charity.
('81', 504, 1, 7, 899445) 5. Common grazing ground or land for exercising the animals will be easily available under the co operative system, whereas today generally there is nothing of the kind for individual farmers.
('81', 504, 1, 8, 899638) 6. The expense on fodder will be comparatively far less under the collective system.
('81', 504, 1, 9, 899723) 7. The sale of milk at good prices will be greatly facilitated, and there will be no need or temptation for the farmer to adulterate it as he does as an individual.
('81', 504, 1, 10, 899888) 8. It is impossible to carry out tests of the fitness of every head of cattle individually, but this could easily be done for the cattle of a whole village and would thus make it easier to improve the breed.
('81', 504, 1, 11, 900096) 9. The foregoing advantages should be sufficient argument in favour of co operative cattle farming.
('81', 504, 1, 12, 900196) The strongest argument in its favour is that the individualistic system has been the means of making our own condition as well as that of our cattle pitiable.
('81', 504, 1, 13, 900355) We can only save ourselves and them by making this essential change.
('81', 504, 1, 14, 900424) I firmly believe too that we shall not derive the full benefits of agriculture until we take to co operative farming.
('81', 504, 1, 15, 900542) Does it not stand to reason that it is far better for a hundred families in a village to cultivate their lands collectively and divide the income therefrom than to divide the land anyhow into a hundred portions?
('81', 504, 1, 16, 900754) And what applies to land applies equally to cattle.
('81', 504, 1, 17, 900806) It is quite another matter that it may be difficult to convert people to adopt this way of life straightaway.
('81', 504, 1, 18, 900916) The straight and narrow road is always hard to traverse.
('81', 504, 1, 19, 900973) Every step in the programme of cow service is strewn with thorny problems.
('81', 504, 1, 20, 901048) But only by surmounting difficulties can we hope to make the path easier.
('81', 504, 1, 21, 901122) My purpose for the time being is to show the great superiority of collective cattle farming over the individual effort.
('81', 504, 1, 22, 901242) I hold further that the latter is wrong and the former only is right.
('81', 504, 1, 23, 901312) In reality even the individual can only safeguard his independence through co operation.
('81', 504, 1, 24, 901401) In cattle farming the individual effort has led to selfishness and inhumanity, whereas the
('81', 505, 0, 1, 901492) 506 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('81', 505, 1, 2, 901534) collective effort can abate both the evils, if it does not remove them altogether.
('81', 505, 1, 3, 901617) SEVAGRAM, February 8, 1942 Harijan, 15 2 1942

('81', 505, 5, 8, 901928) 764. LETTER TO LORD LINLITHGOW SEVAGRAM, WARDHA, February 8, 1942
('81', 505, 6, 9, 901994) DEAR LORD LINLITHGOW, As I have suspended civil disobedience, I make bold to write this letter for humanity’s cause.
('81', 505, 6, 10, 902111) The statutory law says that charitable institutions, though they make profits, are free from income tax.
('81', 505, 6, 11, 902216) I am the founder and Presi dent of the All India Spinners’ Association.
('81', 505, 6, 12, 902288) I can give you my word that it is a purely charitable association.
('81', 505, 6, 13, 902355) It exists to serve the poorest in the land through hand spinning and hand weaving.

('81', 507, 3, 4, 905157) CONGRESS WORKING COMMITTEE’S RESOLUTION 1
('81', 507, 4, 5, 905199) December 30, 1941
('81', 507, 5, 6, 905217) The Working Committee have received the following letter from Gandhiji and recognize the validity of the point he has raised and therefore relieve him of the responsibility laid upon him by the Bombay Resolution referred to by Gandhiji.
('81', 507, 5, 7, 905454) But the Committee assure him that the policy of non violence adopted under his guidance for the attainment of swaraj and which has proved so successful in leading to mass awakening and otherwise will be adhered to by the Congress.
('81', 507, 5, 8, 905685) The Working Committee further assure him that it would like to extend its scope as far as possible even in free India.
('81', 507, 5, 9, 905804) The Committee hope that Congressmen will render him full assistance in the prosecution of his mission, including the offering of civil disobedience.

('81', 507, 7, 12, 906022) APPENDIX II CONGRESS WORKING COMMITTEE’S RESOLUTION 2
('81', 507, 8, 13, 906076) December 30, 1941
('81', 507, 9, 14, 906094) Fourteen months have elapsed since the Working Committee held their last meeting and during this period the world has fallen ever deeper into the abyss of war and rushed headlong towards self destruction.
('81', 507, 9, 15, 906299) The members of the Committee have met again on their release from prison and given earnest thought to all the national and international developments during this fateful period of human history.
('81', 507, 9, 16, 906494) The burden of guiding the Congress and the nation at this critical stage, when old problems assume a new significance and war approaches the frontiers of India bringing new problems in its train, is a heavy one which the Committtee can only shoulder worthily with the full co operation of the people of India.
('81', 507, 9, 17, 906804) The Committee have endeavoured to keep in view the principles and objectives for which the Congress has stood during these past many years and considered them in the larger context of world conditions and world freedom.
('81', 507, 9, 18, 907024) The Committee are convinced that full
('81', 507, 10, 19, 907062) 1 Vide “Letter to Abul Kalam Azad”, 30 12 1941 and “Statement to the Press”, 7 1 1942. 2 Vide “Statement to the Press”, 30 12 1941; “Speech at Gujarat Provincial Congress Committee Meeting”, 4 1 1942; “Speech at A.I.C.C. Meeting”, 15 1 1942 and “Letter to C. Rajagopalachari” 12 1 1942.
('81', 508, 0, 1, 907349) VOL. 81 : 18 AUGUST, 1941 8 FEBRUARY, 1942 509
('81', 508, 1, 2, 907396) freedom for the people of India is essential even, and more especially, in the present state of world turmoil, not only for India’s sake but for the sake of the world.
('81', 508, 1, 3, 907564) The Committee also hold that real peace and freedom can only be established and endured on the basis of world co operation between free nations.
('81', 508, 2, 4, 907709) The Committee gave full expression to their attitude towards the war in their statement issued on September 14, 1939, 1 wherein they condemned Nazi and Fascist aggression and expressed their willingness to help the cause of freedom and democracy, provided the objectives of the war were clearly stated and acted upon, in so far as was possible, in the present.
('81', 508, 2, 5, 908070) If freedom and democracy were those objectives, then they must necessarily include the ending of imperialism and the recognition of the independence of India.
('81', 508, 2, 6, 908229) Subsequent pronouncements made on behalf of the British Government and their reactionary and oppressive policy made it clear that this Government was determined to maintain and intensify its imperialist hold and exploitation of the Indian people.
('81', 508, 2, 7, 908476) British policy was one of deliberate insult to Indian nationalism of a perpetuation of unrestrained authoritarianism and the encouragement of disruptive and reactionary elements.
('81', 508, 2, 8, 908655) Not only has every offer made by the Congress for an honourable compromise been rejected, but public opinion voiced by organizations regarded as moderate has also been flouted.
('81', 508, 3, 9, 908832) The Congress was, therefore, compelled, in order to defend the honour and the elementary rights of the Indian people and the integrity of the nationalist movement, to request Gandhiji to guide the Congress in the action that should be taken.
('81', 508, 3, 10, 909074) Mahatma Gandhi desirous of avoiding embarrassment to his opponent as far as possible, especially during the perils and dangers of war, limited the satyagraha movement which he started to selected individuals who conformed to certain tests he had laid down.
('81', 508, 3, 11, 909331) That satyagraha has now proceeded for over fourteen months and about twenty five thousand Congressmen have suffered imprisonment, while many thousands of others who offered satyagraha in the Frontier Province and elsewhere were not arrested.
('81', 508, 3, 12, 909573) The committee desire to express their respectful appreciation of Gandhiji’s leadership and of the response of the nation to it, and are of opinion that this has strengthened the people.
('81', 508, 4, 13, 909759) Throughout this period the attitude of the British Government has been hostile to Indian freedom and it has functioned in India as a completely authoritarian government, insulting the deeply cherished convictions and feelings of the people.
('81', 508, 4, 14, 910000) Neither the professions of freedom and democracy nor the perils and catastrophes that have come in the wake of war have affected this attitude and policy, and such changes as have taken place have been for the worse.
('81', 508, 5, 15, 910217) The recent release of a number of political prisoners has no significance or importance, and the circumstances attending it, and official pronouncements made,
('81', 508, 6, 16, 910376) 1 Vide, Appendix “Working Committe Manifesto”, 14 9 1939.

('81', 509, 1, 2, 910476) make it clear that it is not connected with any change of policy.
('81', 509, 1, 3, 910542) Large numbers of detenus, who are kept in prison under the Defence of India Act without trial, and whose only offence seems to be that they are ardent patriots impatient of foreign rule and determined to achieve the independence of the country, still remain in prison.
('81', 509, 1, 4, 910811) Recent arrests of prominent persons and their treatment in prison also indicate that the old policy is being pursued as before.
('81', 509, 2, 5, 910939) While there has been no change in Britain’s policy towards India, the Working Committee must nevertheless take into full consideration the new world situation that has arisen by the development of the war into a world conflict and its approach to India.
('81', 509, 2, 6, 911193) The sympathies of the Congress must inevitably lie with the people who are the subject of aggression and who are fighting for their freedom.
('81', 509, 2, 7, 911334) But only a free and independent India can be in a position to undertake the defence of the country on a national basis and be of help in the furtherance of the larger causes that are emerging from the storm of war.
('81', 509, 2, 8, 911549) The whole background in India is one of hostility and of distrust of the British Government and not even the most far reaching promises can alter this background, nor can a subject India offer voluntary or willing help to an arrogant imperialism which is indistinguishable from Fascist authoritarianism.
('81', 509, 3, 9, 911853) The Committee is, therefore, of opinion that the resolution 1 of the A. I. C. C. passed in Bombay on September 16, 1940, holds today and defines Congress policy still.

('81', 511, 7, 11, 916319) desirable in itself, and more particularly, suited to the needs of the moment.
